(3.5 ★’s) I’ve never been this conflicted over rating a book. I guess we can say it was remarkable in that sense.
“Lost faith is the roots of a forgotten wood, waiting to thrive once more.”
King of Scars is a book with a lot of great ideas...gone awry. Don't get me wrong, I was impressed me with how it explores the different beliefs and the power of belief; be it in yourself, divinity, or your country. There was a lot of genius in there...but the inconsistency was like an avalanche of rotten dirt, and my realisation that I no longer trusted Leigh Bardugo to tell me a remarkable tale, the shout that would set the burying of my dreams in motion.Here's the thing: it's all about trust—about whether you're sure you're in good hands. And you'd think Leigh Bardugo, one of my faves, would be one I'd trust so much I'd hand her a poisoned dagger and turn my back to drown in her world, mindlessly, knowing she can swim and will always have my back. *sighs* If only that were true...
“It’s the wolves who go unseen that eat the most sheep.”
I did trust her at first, and enjoyed the first half, unconcerned about anything, knowing I was in good hands; but when the veil was literally ripped away and I saw the book for what it was...I didn't find her worthy of my trust, and saw no reason to turn a bind eye to this:We have two characters and an author; let's name them N, Z, and L; author L is supposedly writing a book for N, but she's so in love with Z that she spends half of 500 pages obsessing over her—to a point that she forgets the book's about N at all. And with that infatuation, not only does she fail in telling N's story, she also questions the meaning of a good leader by praising Z for being ruled by anger and arrogance. I love Z, but I don't wanna read a fangirl's biased writing—not to mention being lied to, as it's my fault that I picked this up for N because that's what the title said.I feel deceived, disappointed, and angry with such problematic choices by an author I love. Not to forget the name-dropping of all these mind-blowing concepts and down-playing every. one. Bardugo shook the foundation of the Grishaverse...like a kid who has built this magnificent toy house but gets bored, picks it up, shakes it like a maniac, and leaves a ruin in shambles, scattered and senseless.Important for reading KoS: as a series in Grishaverse, you should read both of the other series in the world to get to this. You can find them at the end of review under ‘related books’.
Storyline

“Something is out there, riding the storm.”
Near 3 years after the events of Ruin and Rising, with more than 6 months since Crooked Kingdom, Nikolai Lantsov has to strengthen his weakened kingdom and prevent a war, all while being secretly haunted by the lasting consequences of what he endured during the civil war. He is drowning—and a scholar monk and cult leader devoted to a dark Saint is the unexpected saviour he's needed to make sense of the clues and embark on a journey to save himself and his people. The truth he finds at the end of the road is astonishing in its impossibility. But then again, nothing is impossible; only improbable.Up in the north, Nina puts herself back together, now on a mission to save Fjerdan Grisha as an undercover agent of the Ravkan government. Her storyline starts slow as she finds herself and her purpose—and a suspicious factory in a small town. There, she lies and deceives masterfully, making Kaz proud.And this is just the beginning; KoS only prepares the stage for a new age on the way—an age of Saints, with players that could destroy everything in their way...
My thoughts:
 putting aside the fact that Nikolai's the story just made no sense in the second half with that twist that was just “ughh what??” there were 2 plot points that ruined it;1) The Great Darkness: one might say Nikolai's grappling with a darkness within him is like Mare in 
Glass Sword
—(view spoiler)[both trying to beat their demons, the book ending with them not completely defeating it but starting to confront it for it to continue in the rest of the series (hide spoiler)]—then why did I adore it in GS but find it a weak point in KoS? Two reasons:a) with Mare we saw her drown in hatred and isolation, Aveyard capturing that state of mind deftly; we saw her desire to kill and hurt, we shared her messed up mind...it was utterly magnificent! However, Nikolai's oh-so-terrifying oh-so-deadly demon is—*audience leans in*—self doubt—*audience starts booing* I do understand how much harm self doubt can cause, specially in a king, but in trying to connect the gloriously terrifying villain who left that darkness and the things he was capable of, with this...small...demon, I come up empty; ridiculous.b) even if we say there was no risk bc of the Triumvirate, the problem is that, again, too much focus on Zoya's arc took a great toll on Nikolai's struggles, making his journey as lacking as an empty cask of water in a burning desert.2) The Chosen One: *in a museum tour-guide voice, pointing to my rotten bones* here we have the remnants of a once great woman, viciously murdered by a Chosen One trope gone so bad even cockroaches fled its overpowering smell *placard reads: blame it on Bardugo, King of Scars did this*I can only say, (view spoiler)[Juris chose Zoya as the one, why? I love her but she sure as hell can't handle that power with so much hate, and does not have the grace and control one needs to be chosen as the worthy one. Why not Nina? She's wiser, more cunning, less prone to recklessness, and generally more of a queen. I don't understand how Zoya was “the one”? (hide spoiler)]
On criticisms about the ending:
 (view spoiler)[people say the Darkling's death had been final and his return didn't fit; I disagree—the darkness in Nikolai couldn't simply vanish, bc it was merzost like the Fold. And if Aleksander had died the Fold wouldn't have disappeared. Actually, I'd predicted the main plot of this book (the darkness returning, Nikolai traveling, a witch deceiving him to resurrect Aleksander) as I'd believed that this mess with parem needed the Darkling to be solved. (hide spoiler)]
Storytelling

Everyone mourns the first blossom. Who will weep for the rest that fall?I will remain to sing for you, long after the spring has gone.
Bardugo's prose is elegant, beautiful, brilliant, and strong, with flowing dialogue and artfully chosen vocabulary. She amazed me with her intrigue, unique scheming, and how she included the contrary ideas and beliefs by bringing in Yuri, a smart scholar that, with logic, questions what our characters believe in.Along with all that, there was the idea of ‘the divine’ and how to manipulate the fear of power and difference, with the insinuation that there could be desperation behind it, or that it's true based on how you define ‘divinity’. The concept of ‘Saints and magic’ reminded me of 
 Shadow Scale
. Now, I hate comparing, but what she discussed didn't quite match the philosophizing Rachel Hartman achieved in her YA novel.
Characterization
Nikolai (POV): cunning, genius, observant, and talkative; I'm proud of his strength, his dedication and devotion, and his compassion. My adoration for him only grew when he questioned his own arrogance and desire for the throne. He pays attention to his people and listens to them, which is the best quality a king can have. One point to Bardugo for getting the qualities of a good leader right, here if nowhere else.Nina (POV): starting from a place of despair, she's still not helpless or clueless. And as the story processes, she becomes even more admiring. I doted on Nina in the SoC duology, and at the beginning of KoS she isn't fully herself, but she is better for it. She is an apt pupil (if Kaz could see her, he'd be proud of his ‘Nina, dear’) and she moves past hatred and prejudices and proves what a queen she is. Because THAT'S what it means to be a glorious strategist and a leader. Not what Zoya is.Zoya (POV): let's settle this; I admire Zoya. And I loved her in Ruin and Rising. And I love her strength and how we learn more of her past. I love angry characters, but I'm not blind to the fact that she's bitter, angry, rash, and full of hate. But everyone appears to be.Imagine loving a YA Fantasy, then see it an award for Best Adult Fantasy. Everything and everyone has their place, and Leigh was passing Zoya as something she wasn't. “She was maturing into a steady, confident leader.” SHE'S NOT. Everyone is so in love with Zoya that they are ignoring an important matter; 
anger, hate and recklessness are NOT good characteristics for a leader!
And as someone who has personally suffered under leaders with the same kind of arrogance, fury, and self-righteousness, I felt infuriated and insulted every time Leigh PROMOTED such behaviour and called her “already a queen” when she's nowhere near there. I love angry, vengeful characters (hence, Mare Barrow) and exploring that hatred because heaven knows I relate—but only when it's actually treated as angry, vengeful behaviour and the character is called out on it.This is problematic. It's in no way an attack against Zoya. As I said, I do love her. But I'm saying she's not in control enough to handle the power Leigh is giving her, while everyone is pretending she is, and was chosen because of it.Also, she stole Nikolai's thunder. If Leigh had named this Queen of Storms (Zoya Duology, #1) I'd have known what I was getting into and wouldn't have been played for a fool. And I hate being lied to for publicity. It felt like someone had forced her to write a Nikolai story (which isn't unlikely).Isaak (POV): my saviour! When I was a little done with how ‘holier-than-thou’ Zoya is, or how obsessed, in need, and in love Nikolai was, there were Isaak's chapters to save the day with their hilarious intrigue and their adorable romance.
“We begin in darkness, and it is to darkness we return. Where else are the rich man and the poor man made equal? Where else is someone judged for nothing but the purity of his soul?”

Yuri:
 no one can deny his character served to add more credibility to Bardugo's tale with how he represented the not-all-evil people that, through logic, believe in taking any measures and doing anything in the name of the greater good. He is an interesting and complex character, smart and, besides his questionable motives, also raises questions about the hierarchy and is a true scholar and believer. I loved his belief and genius.
Relationships

Nikolai's romance:
 in one sentence can I summarise everything I felt about this turn of events: it is as forced as relationships come. I love both of them, but I don't like this ship. Don't like the winds filling its sails or the waves guiding its way. She doesn't respect him. Says she loves him and obeys him as her king, but whenever they disagree, his opinion is to her nothing more than a mere inconvenience that she'll just walk on. I mean, he's your KING. Not your five-year-old brother that doesn't understand anything! So I'm not gonna ship my precious Nikolai with someone who doesn't even respect him. I don't want him to turn into this PATHETIC clueless man—not unless she changes.
Nina's romance:
I'm emotional. Everything Leigh failed to do with Nikolai, she more than made up for in Nina—when Nikolai's romance annoyed me, Nina's filled me with gratitude. I started this wanting Nina as queen (still do). But this line of story for Nina is beyond exquisite.
Isaak's romance:
 is it too obvious I'm a weeping mess? *turns head around, sniffles, cleans eyes with a handkerchief, turns back around* the cutest, most hilarious doomed love EVER.
Worldbuilding

“The Ravkan people like their leaders with just a touch of the unseemly about them. They don’t trust a man of too much virtue.”
What I appreciate the most in high fantasy novels is not the magic, but the building of societies, because the trick of building a whole new world is paying attention to the most fundamental things that make up each world, and the cultures we belong in are one of the most important ones. In KoS, Bardugo flawlessly built that identify for a nation and its people.Grishaverse magic system, now, is one of the best ones I've read yet, but in KoS we learn things about it that just kind of destroy the whole beauty of the Small Science—giving the well thought-out magic system the sense that it's the product of a teenager's unorganized brainstorming.What do I mean? (view spoiler)[Before, we learned how hard Morozova had worked to master all the elements, how special he had been, and I'm not saying it means no one else can do it (and I understand that Zoya is strong and could do it) but it was just stupid to just have Juris say “Hey sup. D'you know there's no limit to your powers? By the way, how about a sword fight? I'm feeling rusty!” and then...poof. She has mastered it. Srsly, WTF? (hide spoiler)]And the concept of magic depending on faith reminds me of  Emperor of Thorns. Again, it was mentioned in passing in KoS and didn't rival Mark's extraordinary work in EoT—more like Leigh just name-dropped the most amazing ideas, but failed to do anything with them.All in all, genius yet disappointing. I just no longer know what to do with myself.

Her writing style is gorgeous, with elegant prose and so many beautiful, quotable lines, while also having so many funny and snarky lines that I absolutely adored. She manages to both tug on your heartstrings and make you laugh. Although, perhaps that may not be the best way to describe the emotional rollercoaster this book is. Seeing him interact with the main characters who lived through Ravka’s civil war was always fascinating. Hanne was another new character, and I can’t wait to see more of her! I only wished we got to see some specific characters I loved, but hearing their names mentioned was good enough for me!“Hope was the wind that came from nowhere to fill your sails and carry you home.”- Conclusion -Pros- Beautiful writing, every character is amazing, fun plotCons- I was such a mess after finishing it. “Most of us can hide our greatest hurts and longings. It’s how we survive each day. We pretend the pain isn’t there, that we are made of scars instead of wounds.”
 ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ incredulous starsInstagram | youtubeI’m writing a trouple fanfic staring Zoya, Nikolai and myself. I am, once again unstoppable. I’m also squealing like a middle school girl. Shadow and Bone ★★★Siege and Storm★★★★Ruin and Rising ★★★Six of Crows ★★Firstly, I think it’s fair to say that this book is far from perfect. On a critical standpoint, King of Scars stands at 3 stars for me, but considering I’ve had tons of fun reading it, the enjoyment rating is 4 stars. I think this might be my favourite Leigh Bardugo book. I mean I haven’t read the Ninth House -which sounds incredible, but King Of Scars feels like a step up for her. The characters are more developed, the world building is expended and well exploded, the plot is politically centred but understandable. SYNOPSIS: King of Scars tells the story of Nikolai, the cynical prince we meet in Shadow and Bone and encounter again, briefly in Six of Crows. 3 years after the Darkling’s death, something dark and twisted awakens in Nikolai as starts to turn into a blood-thirsty beast at night. Facing adversity and threatening coups, Nikolai’s reign is under serious peril as he starts a dangerous journey to kill the beast inside him.➽ Zoya Nazyalensky: the commander of the Grisha Army and personal ego-check to his majesty, Nikolai Lantsov. ➽ Nikolai Lantsov: His majesty the king of Ravka and local Jack Sparrow. ➽ Nina Zenik: Corporalki who used to be part of the Six of Crows squad but is now a spy of Nikolai send to save Grisha in other kingdoms. The character building, as I said in the introduction was incredible. We’ve been introduced to most of the cast in this book beforehand which mean we know a bit about them from before and Bardugo makes sure that the bits you know about them before aren’t the only thing you know after. She brings in quirks, history, more focus on them so it doesn’t feel redundant and it really doesn’t. I wasn’t expecting that. 
“You are the conduit, Zoya. You will bring the Grisha back to what they were meant to before time and tragedy corrupted their power,"
When Zoya shared her story I unexpectedly felt for her. She’s infinitely complicated, I’ll never understand her completely and I feed off that mystery. She’s cunning but devoted to her country. She’s cold but sensitive all at once. And it makes sense when you read her because it’s Zoya. 
“I’d rather look at the thing squarely than let it catch me by surprise.”
  Nikolai was true to himself. Witty, ambitious, and confident Nikolai… Where do I start... Oh yeah, he’s a beautiful boy and he deserves the world. I just want him to rest at some point, it feels like the guy hasn’t had a good night of sleep since Siege and Storm and he deserves better than that. He’s such a just king for someone so full of himself, but it makes sense because it’s Nikolai as well… I longed for this type of character development. 
“All this time, she had wanted to believe that he was still with her, but it had been her voice all along, talking herself through the silence, forcing herself to do the work of living when all she wanted was to let go.”
 Nina’s heartbreak hit the mark for me with spot-on quotes, but she didn’t impact me as much as Zoya and Nik did. Although I do like the blooming romance with Hanna, I think these two are quite opposite so it’ll be interesting to see how it develops later on.The only problem I have with the character building in this book is that Leigh Bardugo is inconsistent with its characters. For example, Zoya, who was a cunt in the Grisha trilogy is suddenly understandable and likeable when she was plain mean-girl Regina George before. But I think it can be partially excused by the fact that before then we didn't focus much on Zoya, and the perception we had of her was painfully altered by Alina's prejudices against the girl. Not only that but it also feels like Bardugo is trying to salvage whatever can be saved from the Grisha trilogy as she grows as an author, which is something I personally endorse. She can't change what has already been published but she can change what hasn't.  
“I’d like to see if an excess of irony can actually kill a man.”
 There’s an incredible balance between our cast’s sarcasm and Leigh Bardugo’s natural fairytale-like writing style. It makes the story much more enjoyable for some reason.
“In death, a man may become anything at all. The Darkling possessed great power and died grandly, sometimes that is enough.”
 The worldbuilding was expended. It was everything I never knew I needed but got, nonetheless. I love the fact that they’re going as far as to question the origins of magic. It gives the story a new depth and a much-needed fresh air to the world is brought up. There’s only so much ‘good vs bad’ stories you can put on someone before they say enough. Bardugo also questions the mystification of one’s death and existence, especially in religion which is another interesting aspect I want to see more off in the next book. I’m also anticipating the wars because there seem to be 3 official wars ongoing and another against the Grisha species happening underground as well; I can’t wait to see how Nikolai and Zoya survive that one. However, the plot wasn't that great. And I'm painfully aware of it. It felt as if Bardugo needed an excuse to write King of Scars. She scrapped what was left in the ashes of her concluded series, glued them together and called it a day. The problem seems to lie in the fact that the characters from different series and have different goals, therefore, Bardugo doesn't seem to know what plot could bring them together. She ended up going for a political intrigue, which I totally stand behind. It was intricate and entertaining but not well balanced through the characters as it didn't matter equally to their individual personalities.  The end was weird as hell. I wasn’t expecting this book to take this turn because I thought it would focus more on the world’s expansion but it seems to have taken a step back to the good old ‘good vs bad’? I don’t know how to feel about that one yet because, spoiler alert, DADDY IS BACK. Also, I've seen endgame yesterday and I don't know how to cope so deal with the gifs please as I'm trying to overcome my multiple endgame grieves.

4 regal stars for the King of Scars, an excellent story of adventure, and vengeance that is gripping, immersive and action packed from start to finish.A dark fairy-tale story that combines political intrigue, a devasting curse, and a battle for control of the districts, with cunning, unpredictable and dangerous characters that bring so much life to the story of the King of Scars.The Plot Nikolai the King of Scars is the young charismatic ruler of Ravka who is living with a devasting curse inflicted on him by the ‘Darkling’. A curse he must keep hidden because his reputation would not survive the truth. With the help from his beautiful commander Zoya, who commands the second army, Nikolai must find a way to replenish the coffers that are all but empty whilst staving off another attack from his enemies who suspect a weakened empire and borders.In a parallel plot, Nina, a Grisha, is trying to locate the source of the “parem” drug. A girl who has gone under a physical transformation to disguise who she is. You will remember Nina from the Six of Crows and the Parem drug that gives extra strengths and powers to the people who use it. A highly sought after and precious drug to control. A fascinating multi-layered plot that just keeps giving, despite flagging a little towards the end of the book. However, the sense of adventure, danger and scheming was lingering and kept you hooked towards that awesome ending that made up for any dips in the reading. Review and Comments Storyline and Plot ⭐⭐⭐⭐ A great fantasy story and yes, it is total Fantasy but gripping, adventurous and spellbindingWriting Style ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ easy flowing narrative. I liked that the names of places and people were not too exaggerated, which is often the case in Fantasy novelsMain Characters ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ Likeable, lovable and even the evil characters were delicious.Dialogue ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ The dialogue was a standout; crisp, sometimes witty, and highly entertaining. I loved the exchanges between Nikolai and Zoya, for example “Why do you never kiss me sweetly in the morning, Zoya?” “I do nothing sweetly, Your Highness.”So, what’s not to like? The book loses its way a little bit two thirds of the way in, faltering towards the finish line and then BAM !!! it ends with a different sound and trumpets blasting as we feast on one of the best endings I've read in a Fantasy novel.Captivating, addictive and thrilling, with great characters and awesome plot and an ending that is wrapped up in a beautiful book written by a new favourite fantasy author Leigh Bardugo.

Dnf. This just wasn't good at all? 🤷🏼‍♀️I feel like this book only works if you're a die hard fan of the grisha trilogy/six of crows and then it works only barely. It's not a book that can stand on its own. You need to have read other books by Bardugo to understand the world and its characters, otherwise it doesn't make any sense.It sort of continues on on important things that happened in other books and characters talk a lot about what happened in the past, like Nina mentioning Matthias 50 times in her first chapter. I get it, she misses him, it's changed her, but if you haven't read Crooked Kingdom or just don't care about it, you won't care about her sorrows either. And since she's like 33% of this book, you kind of want to care about her or you'll be bored to death. Past events aren't explained properly, but they're all this book's about, so it becomes hard to feel invested. There's no plot, there's no suspense. There are endless conversations on the Grisha world and how they're trying to save it, but god it's so boring. It's very .... theoretical almost? No action, no feelings, just characters talking about strategies and neighboring countries and that magic potion thing... The pacing is unbearable and the reason why I did not finish this. It literally made me fall asleep.In the grisha trilogy, Nikolai was my favorite character. He's great. Unfortunately, he's not really much in this? Sure he's there on the page, big parts are about him, but you don't actually see that much of him. It's as if there's a cardboard version of him standing there, with catchphrases coming out when you push a button. All of the characters don't feel very fleshed out. It's as if Bardugo was like 'Okay this is how they talk and this is their personality' and then let a computer write the book. The characters didn't come to life, they lacked warmth (or actual coldness, in Zoya's case). It didn't help that it was expected of us to know and remember all of the characters from the grisha trilogy/six of crows; it's hard to care about them when you can't remember who they are.I've mentioned this before in my Six of Crows review, but Bardugo's banter sucks. Sorry, but it does. It's incredibly unnatural and out of place. You'll have characters making snarky comments in completely serious moments where sarcasm is just out of place. It never properly fits in with the rest of the dialogue or event. The only thing they're good for are stand alone quotes on Goodreads, Tumblr or whatever. They're catchy and not that bad on their own, but in the book itself the 'banter' is awkward, stiff and just weird. The ending's just cheap. It's there so people will read the second book. That's it. (But then again, the world building has always been cheap in these books. Don't get me started again on her use of Russian and Dutch language/culture.) It doesn't surprise me that she's pulling these sort of things to make people interested in another book.This almost felt like fanfiction, like someone writing on because they missed the characters and the world and didn't want it all to end. Not because they wanted to write a good, substantial book that can stand on its own. Honestly, I could go on for hours about the things I didn't like. This whole book feels like it was written for fans who will love everything and anything Bardugo writes. If a new, unknown author had written this, no one would've loved this or even continued on after the first 60 pages.

I imagine it would be difficult for me (or anyone?) to not enjoy a Leigh Bardugo book. As always, the writing style is fantastic and witty and detailed. This book lacks the tense action from previous books, and though I love Nina’s POV and the Fjerdan storyline, I don’t yet see how it was relevant to this book. And it took up half the book. I like Nikolai a lot, but again, we didn’t get to see a lot of scenes that were high stakes. The book still had gripping and shocking plot twists, even the major one I was spoiled on, but I’m rating it so highly just because the world is so fun to read about. I didn’t quite care that half the story seemed aimless and there wasn’t much action because the characters and the world drive this book even with the absence of plot. I definitely wouldn’t recommend reading this without reading all the rest of the books. As someone who remembers nothing from the Grisha trilogy, I felt like I didn’t glean as much meaning from this book as it was meant to have. 'The monster is me and I am the monster.'
The Darkling may be gone, but some of his magic hasn't - Nikolai Lantsov, one true King of Ravka and Supremely Adorable Character Number One of the Shadow and Bone trilogy isn't a monster any more - that spell was broken. At least everybody thought so, until it turns out they were wrong. At night, the king who must heal his broken country turns into a demon that has to be supervised by his most trusted advisors to ensure that he doesn't murder his subjects. While Zoya and the other Grisha try to help him on his search for a cure, Nina Zenik is among her enemies. Heartbroken by the events of the most epic auction in Ketterdam's history (it's in Crooked Kingdom, in case you didn't know. Read that fucking book!), she has left for Fjerda, the land of the Drüskelle who consider any Grisha as a witch waiting to be burned. Working undercover as a spy for Ravka, Nina tries to reveal the dark secrets of the Fjerdan military.
'She wished she had Inej’s gift for spywork or Kaz’s gift for scheming, but she only seemed to have Jesper’s gift for bad decisions.”
 I loved Nina's story arc.  Once again, I could only marvel at how Leigh Bardugo manages to portray Nina's feelings, that overwhelming sense of loss and sadness. She really knows how to make her characters come alive. I also loved the first half of this book, all the intrigues of the Ravkan court, all of Nikolai's ingenuity, all of Zoya's sassy quips. Nikolai was better as a secondary character, I think, but his chapters were still an easy, entertaining read, mediating between his hopes for the country he loves and his fear of the demon inside. I never would've thought there could be something between Zoya and him, but Bardugo narrates their developing relationship as brilliantly as usual, and anyway, by now it seems to be something of a trademark of hers to make all of her characters fall in love with each other. 
'He plucked his wineglass from his abandoned dinner tray and drank it to the dregs. "One day you will overstep and I will not be so forgiving.""On that day you may clap me in irons and throw me in your dungeons." She crossed the room, took the glass from his hands, and set it on the table. "But tonight it is you who wears chains."Her voice was almost kind.'
Zoya and Nikolai aren't a thing yet, but they're definitely on the way there. Speaking of on the way there: they were on the way to unravel the mystery of why there are so many strange things happening all over Ravka when the story suddenly turns for the worse. I love how you can never guess where Leigh Bardugo's stories go, but this time it was too much of 'Just whatever is happening here?' for me. That whole Saints plot was just...er, no. Too much, thanks. And once that part was over and we came for the ending - THAT THING happened. And I hate it! Why? Bloody hell, someone's returning who's supposed to be dead.  Dear authors, don't resurrect your characters! The only resurrection in the history of literature I was ever okay with was that of Gandalf. I'm definitely not okay with what's happened here. IF YOU KILL YOUR CHARACTERS OFF, LET THEM STAY WHERE THEY ARE. Because? Because once you've opened that particular box of chocolates, death loses its meaning for everything you write. The next time you kill somebody, I'll be like 'Whatever, maybe they aren't really dead. They'll come back.' So I won't be happy about a villain's death anymore, and I won't be particularly sorry about a beloved character's death any more - because there won't be a finality to it. Also, I think it's quite petty to bring back old characters - I think Leigh Bardugo is creative enough to write new, memorable characters.  So the ending pretty much felt like a punch in the stomach. However, this was still a far-above-average-book to me for the biggest part of it. I loved Nina's storyline, I loved Nikolai's and Zoya's banter, and I loved the Isaak plot. Five stars for that. Leigh Bardugo remains my Queen of 3rd person narrators, thank you very much...but still, I really disliked what happened to Zoya and Nikolai in the second part. It was just too mad for me (I never thought I'd ever say that. Guess I'm turning into an adult. Maybe. Hopefully not.), and I really, really am not okay with that character returning, not at all. So...maximum three stars for that second half, which adds up to four stars, I guess. Oh, and can I have the sequel already? Please?

It set the tone for the book: Nikolai and his fight against his demon. But soon enough I realized that the first chapters were too good to be true, that the tone was a mislead, because I have been misleading myself. Nikolai and Zoya's plot got progressively worse while Nina's got better, and by the end of the book I was dreading whatever foolery would happen to Nikolai and Zoya while at the same time being delighted with the twists on Nina's chapters. There was clearly more investment from the author's part on one plot while winging it with the other. Leigh is a capable writer, we all know that, but her lack of interest for this book can be noticed. Either she was being lazy or didn't care enough about it, the end result was a mess. She had to shade us in every way she could. Be it from a quote calling us fools, or a cult plot in which every person seemed delusional or something else just as conceited. That did not sit well with me throughout the book. But in the end for better or worse she brought him back, in the most uncreative way she possibly could. And worse, in the process of doing that she sacrificed Nikolai's story. The book that should be his and bears his name was anything but his, and in the end it dawns on you that the Darkling was not the plot device, Nikolai was.At some point, a random character named Isaak got his own chapters. It came out of nowhere, 3/4 in the book. We did not get his chapters before, there was no background, no reason why we should care for him. And by the time Isaak was having a talk with the Shu princess and possible future wife of Nikolai, I felt sad. Because there I was, reading this random dude (no offense to Isaak, he was a stand up guy) doing all the things that Nikolai should be doing were he not preocupied in being stranged in a castle made of sand waiting for the oportune moment to serve his purpose. Isaak did all the politics, the courting, the attempted assassinations... And when Nikolai got back and cleared the air, I felt super sad again because there was so much potential not explored for him in this book. Instead he wandered around, doing what feels like nothing, just wasting time and development. And is worth noting that Zoya was with him all along and how Nikolai did not had scenes with another woman in the whole book, maybe the author really wanted us to buy into his relationship with Zoya. But to me they are not compatible, and only one short moment Nikolai had with another character was enough to scream that. No matter how much time he spends with only Zoya, how many "banters" they have, it all feels too flat, there is no chemistry, there was no real development. Yet another thing in which the author did not tried at all.I am very upset about a lot of things, but mostly I'm sad for Nikolai. He is such a great character, he deserved better than this.The star is solely for Nina. Her plot was great, the side characters were great. I'm rooting for her.

Review first posted on Fantasy Literature: King of Scars, the first book in Leigh Bardugo’s NIKOLAI DUOLOGY and part of the ongoing saga in her GRISHA universe, begins not long after the events in Crooked Kingdom. Readers should ideally have read both the original SHADOW AND BONE trilogy and the SIX OF CROWS duology before picking up this book; there are a lot of references to prior events and previously introduced characters. We return to the country of Ravka, setting of Shadow and Bone, where Nikolai Lantsov is now king. His efforts to mend the major rifts and problems that trouble his country internally, and strengthen it against foreign invaders, are endangered by a lingering curse from the Darkling that has begun manifesting again in recent months. On many nights, Nikolai transforms into a winged, bloodthirsty demon, terrorizing the countryside.Zoya Nazyalensky, his beautiful but caustic Grisha general, and his loyal servants have been protecting Nikolai’s secret and chaining him at night to his bed, but the demon within him is growing in strength each day. It’s only a matter of time before someone is killed by the demon. Strange but disturbing miracles in various places in Ravka, and the appearance of a young monk, part of a cult that worships the Darkling, lead Nikolai, Zoya and their friends on a journey to seek a way to permanently defeat the demon lurking within Nikolai.In the meantime, a group of three Ravkan Grisha is on a spy mission in the neighboring enemy country of Fjerda, a place deeply hostile to Grisha. They’re searching out Fjerdans who have Grisha powers and are smuggling them out of the country. One of these Ravkan spies is Nina, the Grisha Heartrender with deadly powers from the SIX OF CROWS duology, who is still mourning the loss of her Fjerdan lover Matthias. Nina and her two cohorts head toward the Fjerdan town of Gäfvalle to investigate rumors of curses and poisoned rivers, and find a hidden conspiracy festering in an old factory outside of the town. But what can three Grishas do against so many enemies?King of Scars is a clear step above the original SHADOW AND BONE trilogy: better written, more intense and much more creative. It doesn’t reach the heights of the SIX OF CROWS duology, though my judgment on that may change once this Nikolai story arc is wrapped up in the second book, yet to be published (or even named). King of Scars is fairly fragmented in its plot: the two main story arcs never tie together in this volume, and there’s a rather odd section in a desert palace in another dimension that I was never entirely on board with. And after a powerful start the narrative drags somewhat in the middle before picking up again toward the end. I didn’t have any trouble putting it down a couple of times for a day or so, but there was never any question in my mind about whether I would finish the book.The best chapters in King of Scars are truly powerful. Zoya has been a Mean Girl in the prior books, but as her personality, her strengths and weaknesses, unfold in this novel, she becomes a sympathetic character who we can root for. Her devotion to her country and her king, Nikolai, is admirable and tinged with an attraction between the two of them that both hesitate to act on, seeing the futility of a relationship between them. Her story arc is marked by a heart-wrenching flashback chapter that reveals key events and relationships in her past, why she is the person she is. Like Nikolai, Zoya has both external and internal scars.After all this time, she still had not found an end to her grief. It was a dark well, an echoing place into which she’d once cast a stone, sure that it would strike bottom and she would stop hurting. Instead, it just kept falling. She forgot about the stone, forgot about the well, sometimes for days or even weeks at a time. Then she would think Liliyana’s name, or her eye would pause on the little boat painted on her bedroom wall, its two-starred flag frozen in the wind. She’d sit down to write a letter and realize she had no one to write to, and the quiet that surrounded her became the silence of the well, of the stone still falling.Nina’s plotline involves a group rescue mission against extremely long odds, and a more personal rescue mission as she grows close to Hanne, a rebellious young woman lodging at the same Gäfvalle convent where Nina and her friends are staying. Hanne is hiding secrets of her own from her family and friends. It seems clear that there’s a romantic attraction slowly growing between Hanne and Nina, which I found a little disconcerting, especially coming on the heels of Nina’s deep mourning for Matthias and a tearjerker of a scene where she finally lays his (magically preserved) body to rest.King of Scars ends with a surprise twist that I found equal parts frustrating, intriguing, and horrifying. I’m not sure I liked that ending, but I’m definitely planning on reading the next book!Initial comments: Nikolai Lantsov series! *throws confetti in air* This is going to be SO GOOD.

Edit:Okay I just had to add an edit to this review because I re-read some scenes and I think I finally realised what's been bothering me since I finished and why it took me almost a week to finish a book I would ordinarily read within 1-2 days. I've been feeling weirdly uncomfortable since I finished the book and I have realised why.I think I discovered why it felt so much like Nikolai was being sidelined in this book. See, I have a theory that while she was in the process of writing this book, Leigh Bardugo fell utterly and hopelessly in love with Zoya Nazyalensky. So much so that the final product of this book became so much less about Nikolai and so much more about Zoya. And for somebody like me, who was fully expecting a book about Nikolai, it left me oddly unseated and almost cheated in a way.Listen. I adore Zoya Nazyalensky. She's a wonderful character and a well-written heroine. But she was not supposed to be the main character of this book, and I'm sorry but she's not exactly the perfect potential leader of Ravka that Bardugo paints her to be. She's an excellent war general, fitting for what her original position was supposed to be, but she has far too much anger and hate, and allows it to cloud her judgement too much, to be an effective, fair and justly-ruling 'queen'. She's an anti-heroine - and a wonderful one at that - but the problem stems from the fact that Leigh Bardugo appears to be setting her up to become a ruler of Ravka. And before she can be that, she first needs to deal with controlling her anger. And the problem there is that Bardugo hints that we're supposed to believe that Zoya's anger and hate is what makes her a good ruler. It doesn't. Nobody ever calls her out on allowing her fury to get the better of her, on ignoring the express orders of her king and defying him in almost every aspect. In fact, she's celebrated for it. Again, I love Zoya as a character. This is in no way meant to be an attack.And - once again - this book was supposed to be about Nikolai. Nikolai's journey and Nikolai's struggles. I'm not saying he should be the only character the narrative focuses on, but I am saying that, for a character who is literally the title of the book, it felt like he became a side character in his own story. /SCREAMS IN RAVKAN/Things that are flashing through my mind right now:1) They should’ve called this the Zoya Duology instead of the Nikolai Duology.2) Those last two sentences killed me.3) I’m crying... and they’re not happy tears.I really wanted to be able to give this five stars but I’m sad to say I didn’t enjoy this as much as I’d hoped. I mean, I loved the whole switching POV thing in Six of Crows but I think the story didn’t progress as fluently in this one because of that? I thought it was really stilted sometimes.Also, don’t get me wrong, I love Zoya, but I wanted MORE NIKOLAI, because the title makes us believe that he’s the main character but he’s not.

(1) I remember in the first book of this Grisha series, the king and queen of the kingdom were constantly referred to as the tsar and the tsarina (or something similar to that), but in this book, it is completely dropped and Nikolai is referred to as 'king' all the freaking times. You know what, a bit of consistency won't hurt anyone.(2) I had stopped noticing Bardugo's language problems altogether because whenever there are non-English words popping up in the text I just simply ignore it and I simply expect every 'foreign-sounding words' in her books to be incorrect and make-up out of thin air and disrespectful to the actually-existing languages because the woman seemingly wouldn't bother to use Google-Translator. But then Nastassja's Review informs me that 'Korol Rezni' from Russian means King of Massacre, not King of Scars (and I used Google Translator and it didn't take me more than one minute to find 'Korol Rezni' means 'King of Massacre' in Russian, and you know what I don't even know more than five words in Russian damn it). I'm still a bit shocked.....I mean, what kind of author can't get the correct Russian for her book title and her main character?(3) I'd gone through most of the book, I found this kind of story and characters have been done to death and done a lot better by countless Japanese adventure mangas before, I am not impressed.(4) Guess what? If you wanted to court a foreign noble girl, bothering her with poems which she had known all her life, is the right way to go, not trying to impress her by showing her sights only can be found in your own country or doing activities together.(5) Not to mention, said foreign noble girl mentioned at #4 came from a water-downed version of imperial China (or Mongolia), it's so water-downed that it looks really fake and forced.(6) Things are still predictable in King of Scars, so this guy turns out to be a traitor? But hasn't he been like, (view spoiler)["I worship the Darkling and think he is a saint" (hide spoiler)] ever since day one!? (7) You know what? It's completely possible to be strong and kind at the same time. Cruelty and aloofness don't make you strong; plus being nice actually can help winning people to your side. But as usual, YA authors mistook mean girls with awful attitudes for the strong ones, and Zoya actually wants you to believe 'nice girls' are equated to 'weaklings'. I mean, can she just shove this back up her ass?(8) Don't get me wrong, I actually like Zoya better than that annoying Mary-Sue Alina both as a character and as Nikolai's love interest.(9) To be honest, I skipped all of the Nina's chapters (except maybe the first and the second chapter) I don't care about her development, I don't care, I just don't care. Her chapters are all deadweight.(10) As to the characters, I admit I am happy to see how Zoya, David and Genya are doing a few years later but as for Nikolai he and his struggling with his own demon and trying to save his country is just so damn boring. (11) To be honest, the last 30 or so pages are somewhat decent, but this good part of the story comes 'too little, too late', to a point that I only skimmed my way to the ending without bothering to read it word to word.(12) To sum up, it is a completely forgettable cookie-cutter YA novel with badly-put-together fantasy elements and paper-thinned characters trying to be oh-so-funny-and-witty all the damn time. Won't recommend to anyone.(12) Last but not least, bringing up the Darkling all the fucking times is so fucking tiring. All you Darkling fangirls out there, I hope you are happy, but it really weights the story down.

"Re'b Ravka, they shouted. Korol Rezni. Son of Ravka. King of scars."I still can't really believe that Leigh Bardugo decided to be a merciful goddess and grant the fans of her Grishaverse their biggest wish; a book about Nikolai. A book that will probably be just what everyone has been dreaming about. Taking place some months after Crooked Kingdom, we are finally reunited with Nikolai, Zoya and the rest of the Triumvirate. They're all busy trying to help Ravka heal from the damage done by years of war, something that is made harder by the threat of new war from all sides - even from inside the young king himself.Meanwhile, Nina Zenik is on a secret mission, desperately attempting to save Grisha like herself and hopefully recruit them to Ravka's Second Army. But recent events might have changed her in even more ways than she can imagine.First of all, King of Scars is probably everything that I could have wanted. Even though we started off a little bit slow - which I actually didn't mind at all - there was so much to love. We had familiar, loved faces that we get to know on a deeper level, along with more political intrigue, more heartstopping plot twists and that lovely banter which just helps bring out the characters and their personalities even more. Seriously, I love, love the way Leigh Bardugo writes dialogue - it has a flow and charm to it that I rarely see in other authors writing.I loved to see the characters develop, loved to see especially Nikolai and Nina deal with their past ghosts and trauma in a way that felt so utterly believable and that also tore my heart from my chest. Zoya too - I can't believe the way she has grown, while never trying to be anything other than the badass, almost anti-heroine that she is. The way they were all so vulnerable, while still managing to be strong... It felt realistic, and it felt empowering."He would not rest until his country could too. And he would never, ever turn his back on a wounded man - even if that man was him."Cue the tears.Bardugo just keeps on getting better and better in general, and even though my reigning favorite is still Six of Crows, this world she has created continues being filled with life, colour and history. She's doing amazing things with the Grishaverse, and I hopes she never leaves it completely behind. This is a world I need to keep on exploring. Especially after that ending. What. The. Fuck. The sequel is going to be insane.All in all, King of Scars is here to make us all swoon, scream with shock, crush on everyone in it and cry a bit. You're going to love it.

The Secret of the Twins is the first book of the Fairy Oak trilogy, for kids age 9 and up. The story takes place in a magical village, Fairy Oak, named after a talking oak, where Magicals – wizards, witches, fairies – and Nonmagicals – citizens without the ability of magic live in peace and harmony. The story is told by Telli, the fairy nanny of Lavender and Vanilla. The girls are twins, born on the same day, but twelve hours apart. Twins aren’t supposed to inherit magical powers, but their parents and aunt hope that twelve hours make an exception in their case.Years go by, and the hopes begin to fade. But finally, the girls reveal their powers. But an old enemy appears and threatens the peace of the village. Family, friendship, mysteries, magic, mischiefs and gossip make Lavender and Vanilla’s life adventurous and exciting in this lovely story.

This book was a staple of my childhood. The whole series, really, but this one is the one that triggers the most memories, and a significant part of the love that I have for it can be traced back to those memories and the comfort element of a childhood book rather than to its actual qualities.That being said, it's a damn good book, and reading it now, as an adult, I'm even more aware of it than I was as a kid. It's a classic story of magic and wishes and fairies and woods and mysterious enemies, but there's something about it that stands out to me, among all the other magical stories I read as a kid.Every detail, name and image is deliberately quaint and reminiscent of natural elements, scents and visuals - and that, as a kid, used to drive me absolutely nuts, in a good way. I just loved it. So much. It was adventurous and playful, but also so deliciously cozy. And there's a depth of character and variety of relationships here that kind of surprises me even now. It's written like a children's book, with made-up magical words and a lot of exclamation marks, but there's something in it that appeals to the grown-up reader in me, something about the way it explores its characters just as deeply as its fantastical traits in a way that's perfectly understandable to kids and carries a little more intrigue and emotion for the older ones who can catch it.After I closed this one, I was actually excited to read the sequel. For like the fifth time. That's what this series does to me.Oh, also, the illustrations are gorgeous.

Recensione presente anche sul blog Bookish Advisor http://bookishadvisor.blogspot.itHo trascorso la mia adolescenza dichiarando il mio amore per la serie di Harry Potter mentre la mia sorellina non faceva che ripetermi quanto fosse stupenda la serie di Fairy Oak, quando adorasse le protagoniste e i personaggi tutti, e che avrei dovuto leggere i libri di Elisabetta Gnone perché stupendi.Purtroppo non le ho mai dato retta e appena mi è stato recapitato la stupenda ristampa de Il segreto delle gemelle ho iniziato la lettura, eh sì perché non mi sarei mai azzardata a toccare le copie gelosamente custodite da mia sorella, le primissime edizioni con copertina rigida. Ed è qui che scopro quanto abbia perso nel non leggere prima questa serie perché per quanto Fairy Oak sia una bellissima serie Middle Grade è anche una storia che scalda il cuore, che ci fa sorridere, e che ci ricorda quanto fosse bello farsi raccontare da piccoli prima di andare a letto delle dolci storie come questa.Fairy Oak ha il dolce gusto della cioccolata calda, è il caldo tepore del camino in una gelida serata invernale, è una serata in famiglia quando fuori piove, è il profumo di un giardino in fiore ma è più di ogni cosa la felicità e la semplicità custodita nel cuore di ogni bambino che l'autrice riesce a dipingere attraverso le due protagoniste della storia.Pervinca e Vaniglia sono due sorelle che si imbarcano nella grande avventura che è la scoperta dei loro poteri magici ma quando tutto sembra essere normale nel buio tramano le forze del male che vogliono impossessarsi di Fairy Oak, il loro amato villaggio.La storia ci viene narrata seguendo il PoV della fata Felì, una tata fata che ha il compito di vegliare sulle due ragazzine. Attraverso i suoi occhi ripercorriamo la storia delle due gemelline, del loro carattere vivace e spensierato e dalla loro scoperta della magia, dei poteri della Luce e della Notte.La storia della Gnone è caratterizzata dal un worldbuilding studiato ma di facile comprensione, dalla costituzione del villaggio, dalla caratterizzazione della magia e di quei piccoli particolari che di volta in volta vengono introdotti per rendere la storia unica ed irripetibile.I personaggi sono tanti e variegati, ognuno con le proprie caratteristiche e specialità, dalla famiglia delle due gemelle, al gruppetto di fate che veglia sui bambini del villaggio, il sindaco e la sua famiglia, gli amici e streghe e maghi tutti del villaggio e, infine, il grande e antico albero di quercia magico (Fairy Oak) che veglia sugli abitanti della città.La storia dell'autrice è accattivante e avvincente, già alle primissime pagine si è trasportati nel mondo incantato narrato senza sforzo alcuno e, infatti, una volta entrati nella storia non si riesce più abbandonarla se non quando si è giunti alla parola fine.Menzione d'onore alle meravigliose illustrazioni che decorano un già così ricco libro. Variano da vere e proprie illustrazioni a colori su pagine lucide a disegni vari che decorano le varie pagine, l'inizio di ogni capitolo e i fantastici risguardi a colori.Un racconto semplice, quanto lo può essere un libro scritto per un giovane pubblico, caratterizzato da una visione del mondo magico ma soprattutto di un mondo ricco di colori, tutti diversi ma ognuno speciale a suo modo.In un racconto per bambini dove si fronteggiano il Bene e il Male l'autrice definisce il difficile tema della diversità e lo fa con semplicità e quel tocco di magia capace di incantare non solo i più piccoli ma anche un pubblico adulto. In una fase dell'adolescenza in cui si cresce e si cambia e si inizia a definire la persona, ma soprattutto ciò che ci differenzia dagli altri, l'autrice ha trovato il mondo di affrontare il tema spinoso della diversità e lo introduce con maestria portando il lettore a vedere sì il mondo con occhi diversi ma con stupore e meraviglia ma soprattutto accettazione.Una storia magica capace di incantare i più piccini e non, da leggere ai propri figli, da rivisitare per chi è nostalgico come la sottoscritta. Fairy Oak è il libro dove la magia si dipinge di incanto, colori e felicità, quella che i bambini servano nel cuore.5 Magiche Stelle

Todo empieza con la llegada de nuestra hadita narradora a la casa de los Periwinkle antes que nacieran las gemelas. Felí ha sido llamada para cuidar a las gemelas y acompañarlas en este largo viaje que será su vida.A lo largo de este primer libro podemos ver los primeros descubrimientos de las niñas y cómo se desenvuelven delante de las aventuras que vivirán junto con sus amigos. He adorado volver a su mundo y encariñarme con todos y cada uno de los personajes de esta historia (salvo Scarlet Pimpernel, siempre la he odiado y siempre la odiaré).Aunque de las gemelas siempre me he sentido más identificada con Vainilla (y mantengo mi decisión), entre mis personajes favoritos se encuentra Shirley Poppy. Es un personaje que me llamó la atención desde la primera vez que apareció en escena y no puedo esperar a saber más de él. Recomiendo 100% esta historia a todo amante de la fantasía y de las hadas, especialmente a los más pequeños. Aún recuerdo la paz y la tranquilidad que me invadían cuando leía estos libros de pequeña y aunque hayan pasado ya más de diez años, esa sensación sigue en mi al volver a adentrarme en Fairy Oak.

La nota corresponde a toda la saga aunque debo admitir que quizá la nota esté subjetivada por el hecho de ser mi saga fav de la infancia.Este libro ha sido una relectura y la he disfrutado muchísimo a pesar de haber pasado unos 10/11 años desde la última vez.Hay de todo. Literalmente. Hay magia, amistad, hermanas gemelas, brujas, hadas, magos, Luz, Oscuridad, romance, antagonista... Recomendadísimos pero siempre teniendo en cuenta que el público real al que va dirigido es de unos 10 años y por ello no tiene una trama muy compleja.

3🌟Ho questa trilogia in libreria da almeno dodici anni, solo che mi mancava il secondo volume che ho recuperato due anni e mezzo fa. Devo dire che col passare del tempo non l'ho più letta perché è una lettura per bambini, anche se spesso leggo dei middlegrade. Ovviamente non mi sbagliavo, però odio vedere libri non letti che prendono polvere da anni nella mia libreria, quindi ho deciso di leggere il primo volume grazie ad un gdl trovato per caso su Instagram.Devo dire che è stata una lettura molto carina, (non mi capitava da molto di leggere un libro immaginandolo come una serie animata anziché un film) però mi aspettavo un po' di più. Lo stile di scrittura è scorrevolissimo, delicato e leggero, infatti si legge in poche ore.La trama però non mi è sembrata costruita bene, ma più una successione di eventi un po' frettolosa.Una cosa confusionaria è stato proprio lo scorrere del tempo. La storia si svolge in 3/4 giorni (a parte i flashback iniziali sulla nascita di Vaniglia e Pervinca) ma secondo me i tempi sono troppo accelerati, nel giro di qualche riga si passa dall'ora di pranzo al tramonto senza che sia successo molto, mi è sembrato una specie di errore.Comunque per essere un libro per bambini il sistema magico è interessante, e la caratterizzazione dei personaggi principali: la fatina baby-sitter Felì (narratrice in prima persona) e le gemelle Vaniglia e Pervinca è fatta abbastanza bene, si percepisce che sono delle bambine di 9/10 anni con la loro tipica ingenuità e infantilità, però non puoi fare a meno di affezionarti, soprattutto a Vaniglia.Le scene d'azione sono poche e frettolose, anche perché Felì decide di non narrarle, anche se non capisco perché, avrebbero dato più dinamicità alla storia.Apprezzo che comunque si possano trovare insegnamenti di vita per i bambini: il legame tra sorelle, unico e speciale, anche se queste non possono essere più diverse. L'amicizia, la bontà, le buone azioni, l'aiuto che si dà in caso di difficoltà, la diversità e la famiglia sono i temi che uniscono questo racconto. Leggerò il secondo volume col gruppo di lettura di Instagram, e andrò avanti con la storia, perché comunque voglio sapere cosa succede a Vì, Babù e Felì, ed è una lettura leggera che consiglio anche nel periodo natalizio per le sue ambientazioni!

ADVERTENCIAUN POCO DE SPOILERS AL FINALPues con este libro he dado comienzo a esta gran aventura de releer por enésima vez esta maravillosa y hermosa saga de mi infancia que amo con el alma. Pero... tuve que bajarle una estrella😔 LO SIENTO. Al tiro me explico. Solo una eso sí, porque me es imposible darle menos a un libro que me trae tantos bonitos recuerdos y al que le tengo tanto amor.Releer este libro después de tanto tiempo (nótese que ya lo he releído varias veces antes je) fue como hablar de nuevo con un viejo amigo, o volver a casa después de pasar mucho tiempo fuera. Fue tan bonito volver a Fairy Oak y notar que no importa el tiempo que pase sigue siendo tan mágico como siempre. De hecho, al ir pasando las páginas, viendo los bonitos dibujos que AMO, y al ver las páginas a color se me soltaron unas lagrimitas de nostalgia. Por cierto, un gran elemento de esta saga son las páginas a todo color que hay en cada uno de los libros. Son dos secciones como hacia la mitad del libro con unas 6 páginas quizás más, quizás menos. ICONIC. Cuando chica me encantaban, no solo eran muy bonitas, me permitían adentarme más en el Valle de Verdellano. Nunca me aguantaba, apenas tenía el libro en mis manos me iba a ver esas páginas jaja. Me siguen encantando en realidad.El punto es que amo demasiado esta historia y a sus personajes, pero esta vez noté como que faltaban explicaciones. Puede que sea mi impresión no más o parte de la simplicidad del libro, pero de repente me preguntaba como llegaron aquí o cuánto tiempo había pasado. No es realmente importante, aunque me dejaba pensando. También puedo decir que se siente bastante cortito y más bien como la introducción de la historia más grande. Igual es uno de los plus de estos libros son súper rápidos y fáciles de leer. En fin. Igual siempre me gustó esta dicotonomía de la luz y la oscuridad, como una no puede existir sin la otra, y el Enemigo, no como alguien en sí, sino como el mal que te consume. Con cada relectura le doy otro enfoque y la historia me llega distinto. A mi parecer, esa es una de las cosas más increíbles de esta saga.Finalmente decir que le bajé una estrella porque apenas terminé el primero empecé el segundo y se nota distinto. Y mejor. Per me è stata una prima volta. Non avevo mai letto Fairy Oak da bambina e un po’ me ne dispiaccio adesso che l’ho letto. Mi è piaciuto molto lo stile dell’autrice: ho trovato la storia molto ben scritta, soprattutto per quanto riguarda l’ambientazione. L’ho trovata molto scorrevole, una pagina tirava l’altra. Ho apprezzato l’espediente narrativo di far raccontare il tutto da Felì, che posso dire essere stata il mio personaggio preferito❤️. Ho adorato Felì per la sua bontà, il suo senso di protezione per le gemelle, il suo ruolo all’interno della famiglia, il suo essere coraggiosa pur essendo una minuscola fatina, per i suoi racconti, per la sua ingenuità e per tutte le volte in cui è stata rinchiusa nel suo barattolo. Inutile dire che ho adorato i personaggi delle Gemelle😍: ho apprezzato molto l’idea di rappresentare due bimbe all’opposto, con caratteristiche diverse che poi si compensano. Ho trovato ben rappresentato il loro rapporto di amore-odio, tipico dei rapporti tra sorelle (figuriamoci gemelle). Mi ha molto emozionato il punto in cui scoprono di non poter volare insieme🥺. Non vedo l’ora di scoprire come si evolverà il loro rapporto nel corso dei libri.Come già detto l’unico appunto che ho da fare è quello sulla descrizione del Terribile 21 prima e Nemico poi e della battaglia finale. Mi sarebbe piaciuto approfondire di più questo aspetto ma spero venga fatto nei prossimi libri.Per tutti questi motivi per me è un 4⭐️.

Dulce y muy tierno, honestamente uno de los libros más inocentes que me ha tocado leer. Es obviamente un libro infantil y se puede reconocer fácilmente. Muy ligero de leer, las ilustraciones me han encantado, definitivamente tengo algo con los libros ilustrados.El pueblo de Fairy Oak es el más mágico y divertido, me la pasé tan bien con la familia Perriwinkle, con los Burdock y los Pimpernel. La verdad es que no hay cosas que me disgusten de esta historia, la encontré perfecta, una historia que me encantaría leerle a mis futuros hijos. No tengo mucho que decir de los personajes, porque lo mejor es conocerlos tú mismo, solo diré que Feli es la hada más tierna, valiente, inteligente y audaz que he leído. Me encantaría conocerla y felicitarla, porque de verdad que su manera de describir el pueblo de Fairy Oak me ha tocado en lo más profundo del corazón. No puedo esperar para leer el próximo libro.

No le puedo poner menos estrellas por todo lo que significa este libro para mí, pero releerlo de adulto me ha permitido ver muchos aspectos de esta historia en los que no reparé de niña. Hay varias líneas con dejos machistas (cosas que se pasaban por alto fácilmente en la época en que fue escrito), así como plotholes que no tienen sentido, especialmente cuando una ya sabe cómo va a seguir la historia.Aun así, amé demasiado volver a leer este libro, y ver que aun me acuerdo los textos de memoria y los dibujos y los diálogos, incluso lloré algunas veces de la emoción recordando como me sentía leyendo esto de niña, y otras por el hecho de que ya sé que eventualmente no todo es un final feliz.

Lo mejor que he podido hacer este 2019 ha sido releer este libro después de más de 10 años. No me extraña que me gustase tanto en su momento y que me hiciese querer empezar a leer todos los libros que pudiese cuando era pequeña, es una historia demasiado bonita y mágica.Pensé que quizá con la edad que tengo ahora no me gustaría tanto el libro y tenía miedo de leerlo por si destrozaba el recuerdo que tenía de él, pero para nada. UAU..... mas que história :D Fairy Oak é uma aldeia onde seres mágicos e humanos (não-mágicos) vivem em paz e harmonia. Este livro é o diário de uma fada baby-sister chamada felizeusereivolodirei, mas conhecida como Feli.  Feli é enviada para o vale do verdeplano onde será encarregada de tomar conta de duas bebés que em breve iriam nascer, duas gémeas que com o passar dos anos irão mostrar que não são tão iguais quanto todos pensavam, estas gémeas são Baunilha e Pervinca. Baunilha e Pervinca nasceram com uma diferença de 12 horas uma da outro. Primeiro veio Pervinca à meia-noite em ponto e depois Baunilha ao meio-dia em ponto. Mas elas não se diferenciam só pela distância de horas que as separam! As gémeas são bruxinhas, mas um pouco doidas :D Com o passar dos anos, Tomelilla, tia das meninas, começa a ficar preocupada pois não vê sinais de magia nelas, mas quando as meninas estavam no seu décimo aniversário, e os dentes molares acabam de nascer estes sinais começam a aparecer e tudo vai mudar no vale do verdeplano. Um inimigo terrível irá aparecer e tentar destruir tudo no seu caminho. Todos têm de lutar contra ele, mas ninguém imagina que está luta irá revelar muitas incoerências. Mas para saberem mais terão de ler o livro, ah pois ..... achavam que vos ia contar tudo? Nem pensar ainda existe muito a revelar e os segredos mantêm-se vivos até à leitura desta fantástica história contada por Feli.. Venham e descubram tudo. Adorei este livro, está lindíssimo não só em aspecto mas também na escrita. A história é muito simples de entender e muito fácil para as crianças gostarem , e os adultos também. A componente mágica que o livro tem, deixa qualquer um estarrecido. Durante a leitura vamos conhecendo muitas personagens e as suas características. Podemos dizer que Elisabetta Gnone adora caracterizar e sabe fazê-lo muito bem e muito detalhadamente. Mas não é só de magia que o livro fala, ah pois não. Com esta história aprendemos algumas lições, mas existe uma que se destaca desde o princípio e que é muito importante: O amor entre a família, em especial entre irmãos. Com este livro ficamos a conhecer duas gémeas que a nível de feitios são muitos diferentes, mas que apesar de todas as advertências e obstáculos por que têm que passar, o que elas sentem uma pela outro é mais forte e nada poderá destruir isso, muito menos coisas parvinhas (como diria Baunilha). Relativamente às personagens gostei muito da Pervinca, apesar de ter algumas atitudes incorretas, mas a verdade é que adorei Baunilha e identifico-me muito com a personagem dela, não em tudo mas em certas coisas. Baunilha é uma menina muito doce, que adora o dia e o sol, detesta a noite e morre de medo, é apaixonada pelos animais e acha-os a todos muito simpáticos e amigáveis, Baunilha detesta a mentira e está constantemente contra a irmã nisso. Por outro lado Pervinca é muito dona de si mesma, adora a noite, é muito forte mas ao mesmo tempo muito tristonha pois acha que ela tem sempre que esperar por tudo e a irmã não, é uma menina que às vezes se esquece que não é a única no mundo, mas ao mesmo tempo é muito amiga dos seus amigos, é simpática e muito brincalhona, adora pregar partidas a todos. A personagem que menos gostei foi a da Scarlet, esta menina é uma humana não-mágica que detesta as gémeas, faz de tudo para as irritar, é uma menina muito cínica, mentirosa, metida (adora meter-se na vida dos outros), acha-se a princesa do vale por o pai ser o presidente da câmara e quer ser sempre convidada para todas as festas, se souber que irá acontecer uma festa e ela não foi convidada é capaz de roubar o convite a alguém e aparecer na festa . Pata mim é uma menina muito má. No geral amei o livro e quero muito arranjar o próximo volume, apesar de ser car, mas ainda hei-de comprá-lo. Por isso pessoal já sabem se ficaram curiosos por esta história toca a ler e a dar a vossa opinião, acreditem que vai valer a pena. :D

"Da oltre mille anni, a mezzanotte precisa, nelle case di Fairy Oak avviene un fatto magico: minuscole fate luminose raccontano storie di bambini a streghe dagli occhi buoni, emozionate e attente.Insolito, vero?!Tutti sanno che fate e streghe non vanno d'accordo e che alle streghe i bambini non piacciono affatto. Ma siamo nella valle di Verdepiano, nel villaggio di Fairy Oak e qui le cose vanno sempre un po' diversamente..."E' così che inizia la nostra avventura a Fairy Oak, con questo prologo assai magico e curioso.La protagonista di questa trilogia è Felì, una fatina baby-sitter assunta dalla famosa strega Tomelilla per crescere e curare le sue nipotine, le gemelle Vaniglia e Pervinca.Grazie al diario di Felì ci troviamo catapultati nella valle di Verdepiano, dove un paesino vive tranquillo e armonioso: Fairy Oak. Ma anche a Fairy Oak, dove i Magici e i Nonmagici da sempre vivono sereni, la pace sta per essere spezzata, e le gemelle Periwinkle si troveranno ad affrontare qualcosa di potente e oscuro, che metterà a repentaglio non solo loro e il villaggio, ma anche il loro legame.Aspettavo da molto di rileggere questa trilogia, perché come avrete immaginato la adoro. Amo tutto di questi libri.. i personaggi, la storia, l'ambientazione e la sensazione di tranquillità che mi lascia.Fairy Oak è una trilogia pensata per i bambini dai 9 anni in su quindi, come sempre, vi avviso che dovete amare i fantasy per ragazzi per apprezzare questa saga. Se avete voglia di qualcosa di più adulto sicuramente non fa al caso vostro.Lo stile dell'autrice è semplice, ma anche delicato in quanto vediamo la storia raccontata dal punto di vista di una fata, e le descrizioni del villaggio sono fantastiche.La trama ha qualcosa che mi affascina e che non annoia mai, tutto succede ad un ritmo incalzante facendo sì che il lettore resti incollato alle pagine.Ho amato molto il personaggio cattivo della storia perché per una volta non abbiamo a che fare con un'antagonista in carne e ossa, ma con qualcosa di malvagio e crudele che resta però impalpabile.. qualcosa di terrificante che aleggia su Fairy Oak e che si insinua nel villaggio e nei cuori degli abitanti, qualcosa che sembra impossibile combattere.Gli altri personaggi non sono da meno: Vaniglia e Pervinca sono streghe gemelle, ma completamente diverse tra loro e ben caratterizzate. Felì riesce a trasmettere la delicatezza che nelle fiabe rende così uniche le fate, e insieme a loro conosciamo Grisam, Flox e Shirley, amici delle gemelle che avranno un ruolo fondamentale nella trilogia, proprio perché Fairy Oak si basa sul potere dell'amicizia, sulla forza che questo sentimento ha, e su come sia importante avere qualcuno che ci sorregga al momento giusto.Personalmente amo le piccole lezioni di vita che è in grado di trasmettere questo libro, che è importantissimo anche per i più piccoli: la diversità, la solitudine, l'amicizia e la complicità. E questa cosa la dimostra soprattutto un personaggio: Shirley Poppy, una ragazzina che farà amicizia con le gemelle, e che fin da subito svela qualcosa di molto speciale..In ultimo, ma non meno importante: il villaggio. Credo che se potessi andrei ad abitarci anche io. Fairy Oak è un paesino di pietra e sentieri, non lontano dal mare. E' un villaggio che sa di Spumoni alla fragola, vento di mare, torta di more e matite temperate.. un luogo magico, dove la magia crea e distrugge, e dove la forza che unisce gli abitanti spesso risulta una salvezza.

Yo tendría unos once años más o menos, casi doce, pero recuerdo que este fue el primer libro que leí de principio a fin. Desde entonces he releído muchas veces la historia, en ocasiones buscando los recuerdos de mi infancia y, en otras, el amparo del Valle del Verdellano. Sea cual sea finalidad de mis relecturas siempre he disfrutado mucho de esta historia por su sencillez, la calidez que emanan los personajes y, sin duda, por la humildad con la que fue escrita por Elisabetta Gnone. A principios de siglo (XXI) recuerdo que había bastantes historias sobre brujas y hadas en el mercado o, al menos, esa era mi percepción (porque es que yo pasaba el día dibujando hadas y chicas “mágicas”). No creo que Elisabetta Gnone innove de ninguna manera en el tema brujas o la magia, pero sabe coger todos los fundamentos esenciales y escribir algo que acelera el corazón de los jóvenes lectores. Elisabetta Gnone es una autora ligada a nuestra generación, que nos ha impulsado a descubrir historias más allá de Fairy Oak.En el primer volumen de Fairy Oak nos introduce los primeros años de vida dos jóvenes brujas casi gemelas. Pero a pesar de sus poderes, las hermanas Periwinkle son unas niñas totalmente normales: van a la escuela con los demás niños, se enamoran, hacen los deberes, juegan con sus amigos, enferman, ect. Nadie excluye a nadie por tener poderes o carecer de estos, porque en Fairy Oak Mágicos y Sinmagia viven en perfecta armonía. Pero con la llegada del solsticio de verano un enemigo conocido amenaza de nuevo la armonía y estabilidad de los ciudadanos de Fairy Oak, y todos deberán unirse para combatir al Terrible 21. Historia lineal, amena y que se lee en un rato (a mi edad y mi larga experiencia literaria, claro). Evoca tiempos pasados, y no solo porque la narración va ligada a nuestra infancia. Por momentos la historia parece transportarnos a la Cornualles de principios de siglo XX en algunos aspectos, localización en la que estoy segura que la autora se inspiró para crear el Valle de Verdellano. Mis personajes favoritos siempre que releo la historia terminan siendo Babú y Shirley Poppy, tal vez porque la dulzura y candidez de una de las hermanas me recuerda a la mía, y la asilvestrada Poppy me recuerda a mí misma a esas edades, cuando la naturaleza es nuestra mejor amiga y hermana. Me siento llena de esperanza ahora, ¡y con muchas más ganas de intentar escribir historias para un público infantil-juvenil!

Di generazione in generazione, ogni famiglia di Magici tramandava da secoli un solo potere e sempre lo stesso, o Luce o Buio.Buon pomeriggio lettori! Oggi vi parlo del primo libro della trilogia di Fairy Oak: il segreto delle gemelle scritto da Elisabetta Gnone e pubblicato da Salani, una saga letteraria ormai acclamata in tutto il mondo. Purtroppo ho avuto solo ora l’occasione di immergermi in questa storia e ammetto di non saperne il vero motivo. Fin da quando ero piccola mi ha sempre catturata ma non le ho mai dato una possibilità. Forse è meglio così, perché solo leggendo il libro ora ho saputo cogliere molti aspetti di questo racconto che sicuramente passano invisibili agli occhi dei più piccoli. Probabilmente leggere un libro per bambini con la consapevolezza di un adulto permette a quest’ ultimo di scoprire la vera essenza del racconto.  Ma di cosa parla Fairy Oak?Durante la lettura delle pagine del libro, grazie alla voce narrante Felì, una delle tante fatine che avremo occasione di conoscere nel corso della vicenda, facciamo conoscenza del villaggio di Fairy Oak dove vivono insieme umani, maghi e streghe in perfetta armonia. Conosciamo poi le gemelle Pervinca e Vaniglia Periwinkle, cui Felì fa da balia, due bambine simili e diverse allo stesso tempo, con poteri completamente opposti, che si devono preparare a combattere il Terribile 21, un antico nemico del villaggio che cercherà di separare le due sorelle. La storia mi ha catturata fino alle prime pagine; l’ho trovata molto piacevole e scorrevole, perfetta per esser gustata insieme ad una tazza di the fumante al cioccolato e arancia accompagnata da qualche dolcetto. Ho adorato tutti i personaggi, soprattutto Pervinca e Grisam: non vedo l’ora di leggere di loro nei prossimi libri! Seppur si tratti di un libro per piccoli, i triangoli amorosi stanno bene ovunque. La storia sa trasmettere ed insegnare molti temi tra cui: l’amicizia, il coraggio, la tenacia, la forza ma anche la gelosia, la parità dei sessi e l’inadeguatezza. Tutti messaggi che meritano di essere analizzati con più accuratezza: il più importante, secondo il mio punto di vista, è accettare gli altri per quel che sono, per i loro pregi e difetti, per le loro paure e per i loro sogni. Esempio ne è la fata cicciottella, perdonatemi se non ne riporto il nome perché momentaneamente non mi sovviene, che ha paura di volare e, pur disponendo anche lei di ali, preferisce camminare. Ma ciò non è oggetto di derisione.Come sempre un libro, sebbene indirizzato ad un pubblico infantile, può entrare anche nei cuori dei più grandi, e così è stato per me. A volte una storia semplice, ricca di illustrazioni e ben strutturata è quello che ci occorre. È sempre bello tornare a rivivere un po’ di spensieratezza. L’autrice riesce entrare nel cuore di tutti e, cosa più importante, a lasciare un segno.

Per anni ho coltivato il desiderio di leggere questa trilogia, cosa che non ho mai fatto da bambina - a parte il primo libro, "Il segreto delle gemelle". Catturata dagli splendidi disegni e da colori vivaci, ne rimasi incantata, ma non andai mai avanti.Ed ora, eccomi qui. La scorsa estate rilessi la quadrilogia di Sally Lockhart, un altro pilastro della mia infanzia. Questa estate, Fairy Oak. Ho la sensazione che la prossima sarà dedicata a La bambina della sesta luna <3Ma tornando al libro in questione, è una piccola gemma preziosa che sa di torta alle mele e cannella e vaniglia. Leggendolo ormai da "adulta", perdono di realismo il senso di pericolo, i combattimenti non mostrati e narrati rapidamente nell'arco di un paragrafo, così come leggi magiche basate sul non fare qualcosa se non per "il loro bene"... ah, fosse così semplice nella vita! E' però una vera perdita? E' una storia che permea bontà, che preserva l'ingenuità dei bambini, il loro animo curioso, pur cominciando a far intravedere che non tutto è Luce e, allo stesso tempo, anche il Buio può non essere completamente malvagio.Non vedo l'ora di continuare con il secondo libro!

Por favor, ¿de verdad de verdad que era necesario?  Tampoco me gustó que la narradora, que es un hada niñera de un par de gemelas (obv), se decantara explícitamente por una de las niñas, en plan: "mi preferida era esta". 😐🤔😬 No. Los hombres (algunos) del pueblo son bastante machistas, creo que la autora podría haberlo puesto ahí para enseñar a las lectoras cómo defenderse en ciertas ocasiones de tales comentarios, pero prefiero mis historias infantiles libres. Gracias.Es bastante pintoresca y muy de cuento dulce, con árboles que hablan, tartas, valles, ratoncitos... Igual lo termino en mi próximo viaje a la biblioteca :).

Que libro tan guay, que bonito, me ha gustado mucho.
