ALLLL the stars for BLACKTOP WASTELAND by S.A. Cosby—a fast-paced, action-packed, brilliantly written novel.This book publishes on July 14, 2020, so get your pre-orders in or mark that date in your calendar, because you definitely won’t want to miss this one!Blacktop Wasteland follows Beauregard “Bug” Montage as he tries to navigate his life, torn between being the notorious getaway driver he once was, and the honest mechanic, hard-working dad, and loving husband that he now is. Bug is trying to do the best that he can for both his family and business, but it doesn’t seem to be enough because the bills keep piling, the debts keep rising, and it looks as if he will lose them both. Even though Bug is determined to keep his criminal life in the past and make an honest living, an opportunity arises that he just can’t refuse. By doing this job, he would have enough money to save everything that he’s about to lose, and then some. However, when what seems like a well-planned, quick, and simple job takes a turn for the worst, Bug is forced to consider if the risk of returning to the Life was worth jeopardizing the life he’s worked so hard to build.To get right to the point, I could not. stop. reading. this. book. From the very first page, I was completely immersed into the writing, the story, and into the lives of the characters. Cosby’s writing and storytelling is captivating and engaging, and the characters that he has created just pull on your heart strings from all directions. The reader becomes invested in Bug’s situation and family dynamic, and roots for him throughout all stages of the book.Blacktop Wasteland is unlike any other crime thriller that I have ever read, and I’m all for it. It’s gritty, it’s dark, it’s violent and foul, and it reads like an action-packed movie, where you have to hold on to your seat to get through it in one piece. However, this book is also so much more than just a crime thriller. It’s an emotionally charged story that tackles the important issues of race, class, identity, as well as difficult family and father-son relationships. This book and the issues it addresses are complex, but Cosby’s writing approaches these topics effortlessly. I simply cannot recommend this book enough; take the plunge and read it because you will not be disappointed!Thank you so much to Claire McLaughlin from Flatiron Books for sending me the electronic ARC of Blacktop Wasteland by S.A. Cosby and for asking me to take part in the blog tour this month!You can find my full review on my blog!https://rebekahreads.ca/blacktop-wast...

Every time I sit down to read a crime novel Blacktop Wasteland is what I’m hoping for but rarely get. Not only is this an exceptional crime novel, it has the best car chase scenes! I’ve seen comps for Ocean’s Eleven meets Drive and that’s fair but also sells this novel short because it’s infinitely more.Beauregard “Bug” Montage has worked hard for an honest-living life but with the bank calling on his business, his son needing braces, his mom about to be evicted from a nursing home, and his daughter needing college tuition, he’s presented with an opportunity he feels he can’t refuse. And also doesn’t want to. Because Beauregard is the family man, business owner, and honest car mechanic. But Bug is the best wheelman/getaway driver you’ve never met with a crime dad who disappeared in his childhood, and who he’s never been able to shake. So he goes in for one robbery that he plans out to a T, which will solve all his problems and he can continue as Beauregard. It is an understatement to say everything goes wrong…If you’ve been needing to read an excellent crime novel, here are just some of the amazing things this one does: an opening that went not one bit as I expected; the exploration of nurture vs nature and the ghosts of our past; southern noir; an excellent character voice that snatches you from the opening; the action scenes; our ties: family, friendship, and found family; writing that makes you feel, see, hear, and taste every scene. What I’m saying is run to this novel, clear your schedule, and strap in. Also, this BETTER get adapted into a series or film! (TW parent with cancer/ homophobia, racism, slurs/ fat shaming/ torture)--from Book Riot's Unusual Suspects newsletter: https://link.bookriot.com/view/5829db...

The novel opens on a desolate road in an Appalachian wasteland ideal for drag racing, with a one time cheap to hire criminal and getaway driver, Beauregard Montage, is struggling to keep on his reformed path of the straight and narrow. The bills are mounting, for his daughter in college, his mother in a retirement home, two young children and his crumbling auto repair business. Its an encouraging opening, and not just because of the plot, Cosby's theme is race, almost as if he has intentionally addressed the topics from the headlines in the last couple of months. From its promising beginning though, the plot turns hinge on poor decision making by Montage, and it isn't long before he loses any sympathy the reader has built up. Its afterword contains praise from well know authors of similar Southern Noir, Mosley, for example. It struggles to justify this though. The quality of the writing lacks the edge that those greats have with dialogue, and comes over as a tatty impersonation. The driving angle, which may work for some, came over as a type of Fast and Furious in a novel and was unconvincing. Cosby specialises in descriptive similes, sprinkled liberally throught with one every few pages. These typify the writing, and are very hit and miss. It seems he regularly and successfully builds the tension, then smashes it with what comes over a trashy comment. It lacks subtlety. The door opened like a crypt. At the time, it didn't fill him with tic-induced anxiety. A red flower bloomed on the man's chest as he fell like a marionette whose strings had been clipped. Her prodigious breasts spilled across her belly like an avalanche. There are very many of these. Some work okay, but some I had to re-read, and thought 'What?'

Still waffling between 4 and 5 stars. Beauregard “Bug” Montage’s has big problems: ripped off at an illegal road race, the loan on his auto repair business is past due and there is new competition, his kid needs braces, and his mother's failure to disclose a life insurance policy has stopped Medicare paying for his mother’s nursing home. So, he goes back to his criminal past -- planning a crime and driving the getaway car against his wife's strong advice. Worse yet, the big heist is brought to him by someone who badly screwed up another rip-off. Things go wrong with the robbery, leading to innocents being killed, and Bug and his team have unknowingly ripped off a major criminal. After demonstrates his wrath, the boss forces them to ripoff his primary competitor by hijacking some contraband. Seems like everyone is in the game for themselves. Gritty and raw, Bug is the guy everyone is rooting for, especially when the violence touches his family. Excellent debut by S.A. Cosby.

Buckle up, because S. A. Cosby is going to take you for one hell of a ride in Blacktop Wasteland, one that will stay with you long after it is over.This was a buddy read with PorshaJo and when I first started listening I briefly thought this book was not really going to be my thing, so how did a book starting out about muscle cars quickly become my favorite of the year? This book will rip your heart out, as you find yourself rooting for the protagonist in a heist gone bad, stealing to make ends meet to protect and provide for all he loves. This is such a well written, fasted-pasted novel of what poverty and desperation can do to a man. We listened to the audio, which only enhanced the story. The narrator was absolutely brilliant in bringing the characters to life. I could not stop listening. Blacktop Wasteland was so atmospheric and had so many beautiful quotes, I only wish I had the paper version to highlight them.Highly recommend. I’m still thinking about it.....

This is a really terrific book. I wanted to read something different, something new. This book was satisfying. But of course I thought it insanely long. I got temporarily sick of reading things from the 1950s. I should read more work by living authors. But I'm having to get used to reading books not written to be sold on newsstands.

Blacktop wasteland. A stretch of desolate road. Ideal for drag racing. Or getaways. Presumably a metaphor for the life of the somewhat amusingly albeit memorably named Beauregard Montage, a one time low rent criminal, getaway driver extraordinaire, who left the Life in favor of the straight and narrow and is now a failing autoshop owner and a family man in desperate need of money. So how does one get back up financially? Well, since this is apparently once a criminal always a criminal sort of story, Mr. Montage decides to commit more crimes. And mind you, he has other options, legal options, such a remortgaging or (as per his wife’s insistent suggestion) selling his beloved muscle car, but he vehemently refuses both, the latter on account of a potently sentimental attachment to his daddy, another low rent criminal who has disappeared on his wife and son when Beauregard was 12 and needed his dad the most. Despite all that, our protagonist is profoundly hung up on his daddy, ghost conversations and all. With a man of low character and a lead foot, who drove well, charmed easily and left once and for all. Way to pick your role models there. So needless to say, baby Montage grows up into some version of his daddy and, though he tries to be a good man, just can’t seem to stay away from the Life. Oh, how often everyone mentions the Life. That means there are guns all over his doublewide, despite having two young children around. That means hooking up with criminals so trashy they make the Montages look like high society. Mostly that means making stupid decisions that endanger those around him, over and over and over again. Oh, Beauregard makes excuses for himself, it’s genetic, he believes, the Montages propensity to violent conflict resolution, so now you have three generations of Montage criminals…because of anger management…seriously, that’s pretty lame. And that’s essentially the protagonist of the book here and since he is the main attraction and literally and figuratively the driver of the story, the reading enjoyment will be directly proportional to your enjoyment of Mr. Montage. So for me it was somewhat reduced. I certainly wouldn’t garnish it with praise like some well known authors. Southern Noir they say, yeah, maybe. It’s dark and testosterony. But it’s also oh so trashy, country fried trailer trashy, between the Southern accents and the low end lingo, some of the most brutal crimes of this book are those the characters commit upon the English language. The driving angle is fun, I actually read this the day after watching Ford/Ferarri, another testosterony action fest so there’s that racing element to get the spirits high, although the movie did a nicer job of putting you in the driver’s seat. But who wants to read Fast and Furious the novel. Well, maybe someone does. And maybe that someone also likes the soul searching criminal, the man at war with himself and too dumb to win sort of stories. It isn’t just stupidity either, we are told over and over again that are protagonist is in fact smart, demonstrated outwardly by his ability to do some basic math mentally and remember things well, plus he really knows a lot about cars. It’s also that misguided sort of pride, the fronting and posturing. In the very first scene, Beauregard wins a drag race to make some much needed money instead of taking it and leaving, he gets into a completely unnecessary conflict to defend his integrity presumably and is almost immediately liberated of his winnings. You know, like that saying…fool and his money. So you know right away the sort of man you’re dealing with here and as the book proceeds he only seems to double down on this. Devoted father and spouse scenes alone aren’t gonna cut it to offset the balance. The daddy’s footsteps…or tire threads…are too irresistible. So anyway, I’ve beaten up on Beauregard enough. And frankly the novel dishes out enough abuse on him already. Guess the gist of all this is…the story didn’t quite work for me, the characters were too trashy. It’s like whatever the opposite of Ocean’s movies as far as crime novels go. The writing was pretty good actually, consistently and at times distractingly smarter and more eloquent than the novel’s denizens and, since it is Southern Noir, it’s littered with funky and/or odd metaphors and such. But in the end, it’s basically fast and Furious Dumb and Dumber style. Overtly masculine energy, lots of violence and action and significant literary pretentions, it’s certain to attract some fans though. And some who'll like it best in the rear view mirror. Thanks Netgalley.

I had seen a lot of rave reviews for this novel and I can't quite square them with what I read. The plot and characters are generic -- almost a paint-by-numbers of every trope from crime and or heist fiction. What makes this all the less palatable is the incredibly poor writing. The book is PACKED TO THE GILLS with bad similes. The writer just can't seem to help himself at some points with paragraphs carrying 2-3 "like" or "as" statements. I lost track of how many there were but noted some (these are directly from the text): "made her jump like a long tailed cat in a room full of rocking chairs."“The couch looked like a clown had thrown up on it.”“His mouth tastes like the bottom of an oil barrel.”“spare time was scarcer than hen’s teeth.”“The garage was as busy as a one-legged man in an ass-kicking contest.”“Fast as a knife fight in a phone booth”"A rakish smile that spread across his face like spilled milk."“...as mean as a rattlesnake dipped in arsenic.”And finally these two that describe the same object, and appear ON THE SAME PAGE:“The lid of the trunk was bouncing like a stripper on the pole” and "The lid of the trunk was bouncing up and down like the mouth of a huge puppet.“The author also leans heavily on constantly bringing up the lack of AC or struggling AC every time a character is in a new building or car. Every time a character is driving a car (which is often) they spin out.This is a bad book. I have no idea what reviewers were reading (or if they even read it for that matter) before heaping praise on this.

Someone PLEASE make this into a movie! My husband use to build race cars & was a competitive drag racer (the legal kind) when I met him, winning many awards. (see blog post for my fave pic of him back then). He is also obsessed with the whole 'Fast & Furious' franchise, so I KNOW he would love 'Blacktop Wasteland' (the movie, if it existed), but sadly, he is not a reader..Cosby has pure talent as a vividly descriptive storyteller & this will certainly be the most talked about noir, crime thriller of 2020. Buckle your seat belts & hold onto tight, 'Blacktop Wasteland' will have your heart-pounding & breaking at the same time. (And you will love Bug!) Fast-paced, atmospheric, gritty & pitch-perfect writing, I highly recommend this one! It's available as of 7/14! More info & links available on my blog Momlovesreading.

A very good-solid -gritty story.The story follows a black man named Beauregard who has a skill driving cars. It is more or less present day( 2012)in the Virginia area, in a small struggling town, and he is trying to keep his small auto shop a float.He has spent time in prison, his Dad took off when he was young, so he has a hard life. He has a family now with a wife and kids. Things get hard, he doesn’t think he can play it straight and keep things going financially. He does what he thinks he has to do, being the bad person he didn’t want to be.The book is well written and has a good pace.

This was just like Fast and Furious but in a book form. The straightforward crime parts of the novel were good but the more slow paced parts about a struggling man and his daddy issues didn’t sit right with me. There were far too many metaphors that sounded out of place in the sentences. The descriptive prose seemed to drag the story when I wanted it to just dive straight into the action and raw emotions of the characters.

fresh, lovely, fun and great read. a real nice noir, full with action and emotions. characters with no exit from cycle of life but in the end maybe only one solution family and love have to win all. it is a nice race of cars, action, bad guys with never almost leaving the pedal of gas. loved it.

This book is about Beauregard aka bug. He is a husband, a father, a friend, a business owner. He's also a Wheelman or getaway driver. He's the best around, he can out run the devil on the highway to hell.. his business isn't going so well when a new garage opens and draws a lot of this business and big accounts so he must make the choice of taking one last job to eat at his debt and save his business I listened on audible and this was my first experience with this author and narrator. I thought it was beautifully written and I liked the dialog. The narration was great. It seemed like a very real story to me. I thought Beauregard was a really deep character. He's made mistakes and he's not the best husband or father or business owner for that matter but he can drive his Plymouth duster better than anyone around so he does what he has to do. I thought this would be a regurgitation of your basic heist story but man was I wrong, great story

“Listen, when you’re a black man in America you live with the weight of people’s low expectations on your back every day. They can crush you right down to the goddamn ground"
3.8/5Everything seems to be going wrong in Bug's life, especially when he runs out of money and the bills continue piling up. Living in a small town in North Carolina left behind as a wasteland with the development of white cities nearby, Bug struggles to make an honest living as a mechanic. His role model since childhood has been his father, a phenomenal getaway driver, who passed the skill and the car over to Bug before his disappearance. We are introduced to a character with two opposing identities: the honest and familial Beauregard and Bug, the criminal enjoying the thrill of a fast drive. This story is hard to get into at first because we meet a couple of random characters and the plot seems stagnant. The story begins to come together as Bug is pulled into a robbery heist. Could things finally look up in Bug's life with the promise of a huge cut of money in his last criminal act? A story of suspense and thrill, Blacktop Wasteland was hard to put down and I rushed to finish to find out how everything turns out. I really enjoyed Bug's personality and believe he was written with great depth. Definitely not a book for the faint of heart as it does contain a lot of violence, so I would recommend this to those looking for a thrilling read that highlights racial injustices.

Wow! Mr. Cosby you blew me away. S.A. Cosby that is lol! This book was soooooo entertaining. Intense, gritty, violent, thoughtful and emotional, a slow burning thriller that goes from 10 mph to 125 by the end and the last few hundred pages are major page turners! You got one of the most morally grey characters in fiction, Beauregard aka Bug who is just like a character out of a Tarantino flick, a guy you root for and don’t at the same time that isn’t portrayed as a villain. He’s a pretty bad guy but at the same time he’s trying his best to be a good family man, but it’s hard once you’ve entered the criminal life because the only way to really leave it is in a box. You understand why he does what he does but his consequences are severe and damaging. I loved all of the musical references in this too, from Geto Boys to Elvis Presley, from Al Green to M.O.P. Cosby has a good taste in music. The action in this will have you on the edge of your seat, luckily this is being adapted into a movie because if it wasn’t it would be criminal! We don’t need another Fast & Furious movie damnit!! It was cool to this was set in Virginia where I’m originally from, I recognized some of the places he mentioned. Overall, an insanely entertaining book that does not shy away from violence but at the same time it’s an emotional drama of a man that tries to be two people, Beauregard the loving father/husband and Bug the brutally violent criminal. Bravo Cosby! I need more books from you man!

I've given Blacktop Wasteland five stars, although if I could have given six, I would have. I'm not generally an effusive reviewer, but this is the best book I've read this year. It was an exciting ride from the opening chapter featuring a drag race, to the final relentless, violent showdown. Unlike some of the other crime novels I've read this year, Cosby manages to masterfully balance testosterone fueled action, with the emotional journey of a flawed father, husband, friend, citizen, so that at all times the book delivered on dramatic tension and emotional engagement with Beauregard (Bug) Montage.The writing is razor-sharp and economical. There is no superfluous description or detail - everything is focused on the action of the story, resulting in a read that offers the power of a cinematic experience. Cosby can turn a phrase too, in a way that I really enjoyed. Some of my favourites:  He would sweet-talk her until she had Type 2 diabetes if he had to, but he couldn't let her back out.You let them into your heart and they cased the place. They knew what made you feel weak and what ticked you off."Wait, what time you get off?""About fifteen minutes after you roll off me and go to sleep," Jenny said and hung up the phone.The needle on the temperature gauge was so far in the red, it needed to file for bankruptcy.I read this novel into the wee small hours of the morning. For those that care, there is drug use and violence. And fast cars. And chases. And I loved every minute of it. One not to miss.

Let's not mess around. BLACKTOP WASTELAND isn't a book you read, it's a book you DRIVE. This thing moves like a bucking bull with a rocket in its ass shooting down a slithering ribbon of dark highway at a hundred miles an hour. You'll have tread-marks on your fingertips turning the pages of this rocking and rolling, violent and bloody, gut-shot and gut-wrenching odyssey of crime and terror and balls-to-the-wall hyper-adrenalized propulsion. But be warned: when your heart isn't racing it's breaking, because you get ATTACHED to these characters and when they're bones break you feel it and when they're hearts shatter you feel that, too. And when the blood splashes off the paper and sprays your face with a warm mist you'll laugh with wild-eyes and keep going until you finally hit the brakes and end the ride, so be sure to clear your calendar, because once you start you're not stopping until the final twist in this nightmare journey -- don't crack that spine until you ask yourself the same question Bug's father asked him: "You ready to fly?"
I just love the way this author writes his thrillers and crime spree books. They keep you entertained from the beginning to the end. Really enjoyed it!

Hands down one of the best heist books I’ve ever read. Made better by the fact that to class this as “just” a heist book feels woefully inadequate for a story that is also a fascinating character study, a heartfelt examination of whether we can ever truly change who we are, and just an all around fantastic novel. For those who are here for the heist plot, you won’t be disappointed. Cosby’s cleverly orchestrated heists (yes, there’s more than one!) are beautifully choreographed and compelling, sort of like watching a ballet...if the stage were on fire and the dancers had to dodge bullets while executing perfect fouettés.But don’t sleep on the character-driven component of this story either. Beauregard “Bug” Montage is one of the most enthralling protagonists I’ve encountered. His fascinating backstory and struggles to reconcile how Beauregard the family man and Bug the wheel man can exist as the same person are complex, compelling, and not just a little heartbreaking. The secondary characters also don’t disappoint, from the ones you love to the ones you love to hate, Cosby has put together an action/thriller that somehow doesn’t include a single phone-it-in stock character. Even those who follow hero/villain archetypes are uniquely wrought individuals in their own ways. Finally, I think this book presents a great opportunity to encourage everyone to read more books by authors of color other than just the ones that are specifically about race. Obviously I encourage everyone to educate themselves on racial issues, preferably via OwnVoices books. However, I also think it’s important to not limit ourselves to reading authors of color only when they’re teaching us about racial inequality. There are so many amazing books out there by authors of color (both fiction and nonfiction), which everyone should read just because they’re damn good books. To support authors of color, we need to value their voices when talking about things other than just their race. And there are so many authors in this category doing incredible work who make this easy for us. Cosby’s Blacktop Wasteland is an exceptional example of that. I’m already eagerly awaiting his next novel.*I received an ARC of this book in exchange for an honest review.*

Call it 3.5 stars.Blacktop Wasteland does a lot of things well. It is a gritty crime novel that exists somewhere between hardboiled and noir, featuring a down-on-his-luck African American mechanic in the South who dives down a criminal rabbit hole in a desperate attempt to resurrect his fortunes and rescue his family. The world of the protagonist is painstakingly crafted with loving detail. The characters are rich and memorable. Poverty and systemic racism loom through the pages. Conceptually, it is a wonderful undertaking, and a contribution to the mystery/crime genre the likes of which we badly need more of.Alas, Cosby lets the narrative unravel as it goes. While the novel begins gritty and reasonably realistic, with a dimensional and flawed protagonist and a complicated network of vivid characters, the events of the story take on successively over-the-top dimensions, until it winds up straining credulity altogether. The conclusion still provokes empathy, but the story by that point has hurdled through so many implausible twists and turns that it is hard to retain edge-of-the-seat engagement. Moreover, the unraveling feels especially odd and frustrating because Cosby takes such careful pains to craft a tight, gritty world in the early going. By the end, everyone gets away with murder, coincidences and absurd action sequences are common, and I was left shaking my head.The core strength of Blacktop Wasteland is in the first hundred pages, and based on that power alone, I would recommend it to a general audience, especially to mystery and crime fiction readers. The unraveling toward the end robs the whole effort of the clarity and beauty that the novel deserves, but there is enough to like in these pages that I will certainly look to see what else S.A. Cosby writes.

I am glad I picked this one up. The premise is the same ol' story of a man trying to provide for his family but S.A. Cosby has given a new and refreshing action packed noir thriller. The base for a thrilling ride was set right in the first chapter. It made me think the entire book is going to be about races and fast cars but it takes a turn to the slow moral dilemma of a common man struggling with daddy issues and money problems. Next, it is all about him and his life. The point to note here is the author's detailing of the area and the life there. All the characters were unique and deep. Everyone was relatable and simple. People with simple emotions and simple desires. I felt that every character had their own style of humour. And author had his own style. While we are digging deep into the lives of these characters, the action starts. The heist sequence was so fast paced and thrilling, it was better than any visual scene. In between the action, the human quotient was explored deeply about friendship, betrayal, love and duty.In most parts, the story was suspenseful. But for me, the writing was difficult to comprehend. Maybe because it has so many details about things that I didn't know about. The cars and their parts etc. It takes some time to get accustomed with the lingo. It is not difficult but not a breezy read. I invested some time and effort in this book to mainly understand the setting & the life and I guess it was worth it. Towards the end, I did feel there was too much detailing at some places that came in the way of the action because I just couldn't wait. But that is just my preference. It is a perfect noir story and can I also consider this a coming-of-age because our "Bug" finally finds what he wants in the end!!!

Why Did I Read Blacktop Wasteland?The early reviews have been amazing for Blacktop Wasteland! How could I not get pulled into wanting to read it? The majority of my friends have given it 5 stars and the rest a solid 4 stars.The StrengthsI went into Blacktop Wasteland pretty blind outside of just knowing how well it was being received. Blacktop Wasteland turned out to be a really great crime novel. It was full of action and full of consequence, and I loved S.A. Cosby's voice.Blacktop Wasteland had a lot of surprises, too. I'm certain I said "noooo" out loud more than once!There was a lot of heart in Blacktop Wasteland. It makes me excited to see what Cosby does next.The WeaknessesHere is the part where I get purely subjective. Pretty early on I had Blacktop Wasteland pegged as a heist book. I am such a huge fan of heist stories, and I've been really craving them lately. I see now that Blacktop Wasteland is being billed as part Ocean's Eleven which is fair since my own mind went there (more specifically Ocean's Eight). I'm glad I didn't see the comparisons ahead of time, though, because my heist expectation would have been even higher. My mind kept expecting the plotting and the pacing of a heist novel but was being given a great crime novel that was something else altogether.Final ThoughtsIf you love a good crime story, I wholeheartedly recommend you pick up Blacktop Wasteland. I will not be surprised to see it on a lot of favorites and awards lists for this year.3.5 starsReview copy provided by publisher

No ifs, ands, or buts about it! 5 stars hands down!! Whew!! Oh my gosh. Talk about being immersed into a whole new world. What an exhilarating ride. I found myself letting go of breaths held throughout multiple chapters. This was such a glorious, heart wrenching, anxiety ridden story. Bug is the best wheelman out there, some will say better than his own father. The story starts out with an illegal street car race out on a deserted highway. Bug being the person he is couldn’t pass up a good street race. For Bug there’s just something about feeling the rev from an engine climb up from your feet all the way up and through your body. After finding himself in a financial pickle there was no way he was passing this race up. Things go awry, plans crumble, and men are crossed then double crossed. Head shaking, eyes bulging, mouth gaping throughout this story. Do not miss out on this novel. There’s no way you won’t want to put this one down.

My full review is up on www.inkheist.com Here’s an excerpt:Wasteland has garnered well deserved starred reviews, a mention from Stephen King, as well as innumerable shout-outs from readers and reviewers across genres. While this book is firmly within the crime genre, it encapsulates pieces of horror, literary fiction, and raw human experience. It is, quite simply, masterful.Simply, this book is fast-paced, fraught with emotion, and expertly written. On a deeper level, every reader is sure to have different takeaways depending on the lenses with which they view the world. While this may be true for all pieces of literature, it is unavoidable with this one. This is life, bled onto a page, and offered up for us to take from what we will. Personally, I will read whatever this author publishes from now on.

Well, damn, that was an incredible book! I inhaled Cosby's book in 2 days, couldn't put it down. The prose are so sharp, the characters so deep, and the plot is tight. I guess this gets one star as I did not like it and would not recommend it to others. The book reads like a B movie script with a shallow conventional troubled protagonist and accessory characters who are about as deep as a shot glass and are only mentioned to give the threadbare plot an ounce of dimensionality. Wow. What a ride. Literally. S.A. Cosby has created that outlaw character that we ought to abhor, but who we come to root for in this (let's see how many car/road metaphors I can employ), fast-paced, fuel-injected, eight-cylinder, rubber-burning plot, with complex characters. The author emerges us in a world that most of us don't inhabit, and haven't dreamed of. Bravo.

So vivid was the world of Blacktop Wasteland that I could feel the rumble of every engine, I could taste the spray of every droplet of blood, I could smell the burning rubber hanging in the air, and I felt desperation and heartbreak that encompassed it all, settling like melted tar on my soul. My first by SA Cosby. Really liked his writing style. Gritty, southern trashy, loved the plot and story of Bug, how he got to be the person he was, and how he battled the two beasts, and how he maneuvered through his life challenges. Good stuff, I will definitely read more from SA Cosby
Shawn Cosby has penned a top-notch thriller. Fast paced and slick, Blacktop Wasteland is an action packed, hard boiled, adrenaline pumping thrill ride with heart.

“It’s a crime that history repeats itself”I have only featured a small fraction of the many excellent and compellingly observational, quotable and meaningful lines, with which this book is satisfyingly replete, although none of which are included without great thought and placement, in direct correlation with the story.This book pushed all the buttons and hit all the hot spots for so many reasons, although after reading a couple of the earlier reviews, I feel that the storyline took me on a completely unique and individual journey, which may not have been the same as so many others, or indeed that which the author had in mind for me to take.There are, under varying circumstances, three or four defining markers, which for me make a complete and satisfying read – A decisive and scene setting opening, which this high octane beginning definitely was – A well constructed strong storyline, which this unequivocally had without any argument – A definitive and conclusive ending, which was much more difficult to achieve with this particular storyline, but which was dealt with in the best possible way given the circumstances and offered quite a satisfying outcome, but no ‘happy ever afters’, if that’s what you are looking for! – Oh! and you can’t be dead! which Beau manages, but only by the skin of his teeth, and leaving a trail of bodies and destruction in his wake!This is a multi-layered, multi-genre, multi-generational story, which encompasses so many historical, cultural, economic and societal issues, that it is difficult to define them individually. Better perhaps to treat them as an overall study in human behaviour, cultural mores, and social history and commentary. It is masterfully written from the heart, with total authority, compelling confidence and raw passion, which sets the author up as a consummate exponent in the art of storytelling and skilled in the imagery of words, affording an added dimension to the depth and range of the reading experience for me.This story was an intensely intuitive, atmospheric mix of plot and character driven elements, each fluidly fuelled by the other. As a hard-hitting, action packed, gritty thriller, with a strong narrative and dialogue, this one effortlessly hit the spot full throttle, grabbed me by the throat and never let go until the last baddie was scuppered and wasn’t going to be coming back for more any time soon. A gripping story, rich in detail, of cross and double-cross, non violent crime turned into a blood bath, taking Beau along with events, as he would have me believe, against his will, but with him all too easily reverting to flashbacks of his former lifestyle, with some of the breath-taking, ‘need for speed’ car chases he took me on. This motley team of would be thieves, have convinced themselves that money will solve all their ills, magically change their lifestyles, better their life chances and buy them out of the dire situations in which they find themselves. However none of them are able to function at a basic level and realise all too late and at a terrible personal cost, that money alone can’t work miracles.I became completely invested in the sprawling cast of multi-faceted, diverse and complex characters, who were easy, yet not always comfortable to connect with. Even though they were well drawn and defined, none of them were particularly engaging, as the school of life had taught them all the hard lesson of self protectionism, whilst cruel and often brutal family histories, together with harsh and destructive upbringings, had left them feeling worthless, forgotten and searching for a sense of belonging, although most would probably never have admitted it.Beau isn’t a stupid person by any means, although he has convinced himself that he is a direct reflection of his fathers influence and legacy, despite his best efforts to change his ways. Even with the demon on his shoulder egging him on, I was quite surprised by the level of violence which Beau was prepared to adopt in order to protect his family, although to witness his inner turmoil, was quite heart-wrenching at times, as he was almost having to try and deny the true bond of love he felt for his father, despite knowing that he would never have been a good or stable role model and that he had been quite prepared to run out on his family and abandon them to their fate, whilst accepting that he is a product of that man and the sins of the father are often visited on the children. In Beau’s own children, without imminent intervention, it is so easy to see the next generation forming in exactly the same way, so it is now up to him to turn things around, set the ground rules and sow the seeds of a better future for them as a family. He should never forget his father and the undoubted good times they shared, but he needs to shake that demon off and carve a new and different path for the Montage family.For me personally, although race and ethnicity were an obvious focus of the entire piece, they weren’t the most outstanding features of the work. It was more a nuanced examination of the effects of poverty and deprivation, on a small rural community of various ethnicities and cultural backgrounds, in a landscape which time forgot, or even worse, simply chose not to remember!As well as being a first rate crime thriller of course!This is a book not to be missed and a storyline which begs being adapted as a screenplay and optioned for film.

Wow! This book was amazing. I first heard about this author when his most recent book Razorblade Tears began getting hype last year. That book is still on hold at my library. In the meantime, I found a copy of this book, his second, at a thrift store and figured I'd give it a try. And I am so glad I did.This is a crime novel. It takes place in the modern day in rural Virginia. Beauregard is a man in his mid thirties with a past. He currently runs a mechanic shop and has a wife and some kids. He believes he has left the Life, as he calls it, behind, but specific economic circumstances convince him to do one last job, and of course, things don't go as planned.The book reminds me of things that Elmore Leonard used to write, but with a more modern sensibility. The tone is dark, and there is a ton of violence. No one here is an angel. They all have made bad choices, and done things they regret. Yet, this is not a novel that is despairing of humanity. Cosby's vision is not nihilistic. I would call it darkly pessimistic and cynical.At one point in the novel, one character comments to Beauregard how messed up the world is, and Beauregard says, "The world's fine Ronnie. It's us that's f----d up". That about sums up this novel.If you like books that are fast and smart and dark, you will love this book. I will definitely be reading more of Cosby's work.Highly recommended.

This is another one of those books receiving many positive critical reviews and strong word of mouth. After putting it on my reading list, it eventually came up on Amazon’s daily discounted and I bought. Then this month, S.A. Cosby was the prairie author interview in my “Mystery Scene magazine”. I found it so interesting that I watched a recent interview with him on the internet. After that, I had to read this book, and after finishing it, I am so dang happy that I did. I really hesitate to say much more abut the plot beyond what is described the book cover, because I don’t want to risk giving too much of the story and its many twists and turns throughout. The less the reader knows is the best approach to immersing yourself in this multi-layered story of crime, family, culture, and overcoming the past. This book is a fully immersive 305 pages, a fast thrill-ride from beginning to end. This is the story of Beauregard “Bug” Montage. Beauregard is many things. He is the son of a father who left him as a young boy. He is a husband of Kia, a wife he loves greatly. He is the father of two young sons, and an older daughter trying desperately to get into college. He is a business owner of his own car repair shop and an excellent mechanic. But he has a secret. A big one. He is a getaway driver. Not just any wheelman. He is the best driver there is on the entire east coast. However, Beauregard has left that life of crime behind him with the intention of settling down, becoming a family man and business owner in his small-town community. He is never going back to that prior life. That is until the economy, business competition, medical bills, and his aging mother, start to overwhelm and force him to reconsider the one option that his special talents can be used for … Let me be loud and clear. This was an amazing and mesmerizing read. It was a downright heck -of-a-suspenseful ride. Cosby pulled me in on the first page one, introducing me to a world that I honestly have never been a part of, but it captured my whole-hearted interest. I felt like I was grabbed by the throat, my participation demanded, and nothing less than my full-attention all the way through to the very last page was allowed. And let me tell you, I was a willing participant the whole way.Cosby delivered a gem on all three fronts – characters, plotting, and setting. His characters were real and multi-dimensional in ways that I have truly not experienced. They had strengths, weaknesses, and human foibles that challenged them in Shakespearian dramatic themes. Their relationships were authentic and reflected the struggles of real-life fears and challenges. Cosby’s plotting was second to none. It reminded me a bit of Scott Smith’s “A Simple Plan” with a touch of Stephen King’s new novel “Billy Summers”. However, Cosby brought a rawness and violence that is distinctly his own. His plot twists and surprises were laid out and flowed as well as the last two minutes of the Eagles rock classic “Hotel California”. Everything was believable and delivered by someone in command of his craft. Cosby’s setting was an incredible stark and contrasting world built upon real and painful issues, including poverty, racial, and family issues. He exhibits a strong understanding of those themes and explores them brilliantly in a crime fiction framework, including the relationship of son to father, father to son, husband to wife, and friend to friend. Cosby has a unique voice and use of language. It is direct, authentic, and starkly powerful in conveying the story’s themes on a personal and emotional level that requires all of the reader’s senses. For me, the buzz around this book is real and well-deserved. It is a fresh, quality read. His ability to transition between the characters, plotting, and pace was smooth and natural, and he had me reflecting on my relationships with my father, my wife, and my daughters. How am I doing in relationship to Beauregard. Overall, this was a powerhouse of a read. A strong and compelling read. Definitely worthy of all the accolades it has received. Cosby has a powerful and engaging voice that is unique and insightful. A voice that is his own and a masterful storyteller in his first published novel. As soon as I finished this book, I reserved his second novel, “Razorblade Tears”, at my local library. But truth be told, I am not sure I can wait that long. I am already scouting it out on Amazon for reading on my Kindle.Hands down, this is a 5-star book that delivers an awesome reading experience. This would have been on my top ten lists of 2020 had I read it last year. Now it will be on my top ten list for 2021. Read it and you will know why.
Cosby proving once again he is a master of words when it comes to crafting novels.

Blacktop Wasteland by S.A. Cosby is a crime thriller involving Beauregard "Bug" Montage. Bug is the owner of a small auto repair shop, trying to make ends meet and live what many consider a normal life when financial problems keep landing at his doorstep. In what seemed to be a past life, Bug was known to be one of the best getaway drivers in the East but has since turned from that lifestyle to raise his two boys with his wife, Kia, while operating his business. Mostly beyond Bug's control, financial difficulties continue to mount, causing Bug to reconsider his choice of the retirement of his getaway driving skills. Soon, because of limited financial paths, Bug is enticed into entering into what has been described to him as a "sure-thing" heist with two white trash, pecker-wood brothers. Not long after, because of his enticement and how things rarely go as planned, Bug is soon involved with two groups of even more dangerous criminals, with few places to turn. Blacktop Wasteland contains a wide range of well developed supporting characters and a tinge of generational history to Beauregard "Bug" Montage to add interest to his story. As the novel unfolds, Cosby creates a likable Bug as a man trying to do the right things and where readers hope for a positive outcome, while at the same time, the reader feels an impending doom is more likely. This is the first novel I have read by S.A. Cosby and it was such a pleasant surprise. The story moves along at a fast pace and like clockwork without seeming to be a cookie-cutter like assembled crime novel. While reading the novel, it was easy to picture what was being read in a cinema-like fashion. On top of that, due to the cover illustration, through the novel I kept picturing the actor Sterling K. Brown as Beauregard "Bug" Montage (hopefully it won't be long before a movie studio picks up the rights to this novel).It is also easy to predict, Blacktop Wasteland by S.A. Cosby will be on many top ten lists as the end of the year approaches. Blacktop Wasteland is highly recommended to fans of crime thrillers, Grit Lit/Southern Noir, and novels from authors such as George Pelecanos and Dennis LeHane.An ARC was provided by Flatiron Press/Netgalley for the promise of the return of an honest review.

"The thing about loving someone was that they knew all your pressure points. They knew all the spots that were open and raw. You let them into your heart and they cased the place."BLACKTOP WASTELAND has been praised to the firmament and promoted to the farthest reaches of the universe, and while that's a lot for a novel to live up to, S.A. Cosby's crime novel deserves all of it and more. It not only affords a new angle on America from the 10,000-foot view as well as the 1-inch level, it is pure high-octane pleasure on every page, delivering familiar pleasures in fresh packaging. No need to unpack its smart authenticity about how the deck is stacked against blacks in America in 2020; that's been done better by better people, and the white man that I am can't come close to replicating, let alone improving, on their insights.Inside, I'll take a different tack. I usually despise tropes in crime fiction, as they're often used in the service of paint-by-numbers plotting and cardboard characterizations to create a sense of commercially palatable comfort that's calculated to move units. But BLACKTOP WASTELAND is a different beast — it leans into its tropes with such sincerity and weight that they become features, not bugs. To be more specific:— The Heist. There's not a lot here you couldn't find in, say, CHARLEY VARRICK. There's a team, and the team has a leader, a weak soldier, a more-clever-than-smart lieutenant that's holding back something unsettling about their motive, the girlfriend who can't be completely trusted, etc. Something always goes wrong; somebody always gets killed.— One Last Job. The hero knows it's stupid to get pulled back into the life he's been trying to leave behind. But he needs the money, he feels forced into it by scary people, and whether or not he can admit it, he's addicted to the thrill of the planning and execution.— Daddy Issues. The hero feels he has to live up to what his daddy is, or what his daddy expects of him, or what his daddy has decided he isn't capable of. He knows it's emotional stupid, but he's in the grip of it nonetheless.— The Yappy Wife/Girlfriend. The women in male-centric crime novels are always on the sidelines, always nagging their man to do the safe but boring thing, always pummeling them with rage and tears, always threatening to leave and take the kids. They're always right, too. Except for ....— A Man's Gotta Do What A Man's Gotta Do. Yes, he should walk away. But he can't. Not when he's gotta provide. Not when his manhood is being challenged or taunted. Not when his Daddy Issues dominate him. Not when he has to do One Last Job because His Past WillNever Leave Him Be. But most of all, because he needs to feel like a Man.Alone, these tropes are usually annoying. Together, they're all but unbearable, because usually the author doesn't unpack them — they just drop them flat on the page with little explanation in the expectation that the reader will find them instantly sympathetic and thus sublime company from page to page. These are almost everywhere in the contemporary suspense/thriller moment: My Sister Was Murdered Twenty Years Ago; My High School Secret Won't Stay Buried; My New Husband and Wife Is Keeping Something From Me; I've Been Cheated Upon and Need to Start Over in My Small Hometown; Why Is the Sexy New Au Pair Looking at Me With That Sly Insinuating Smile, etc.But S.A. Cosby doubles down them these tropes with such utter pain and sincerity that they become utterly necessary and plausible. The circumstances that lead Beauregard "Bug" Montage to decide the financial gain from a jewelry-store holdup are laid out in patient detail that should resonate with anyone struggling to keep a family maintained or a business afloat. The circumstances are so pressing and the payoff so enticing that they not only lead Beauregard to look past the loose ends of the One Last Job that threaten to pull apart the fabric of the heist plan, but the loose characters on which he has to depend. We don't learn about these unreliables in passing; we get to see the irratuonal justifications of the unreliables in their own voices.The Daddy Issues seem decorative until they are unpacked in a flashback scene that shows, completely convincingly, how Beauregard's formative years were torn apart by the need to live up to his Daddy's reputation and the knowledge that any credible future he has depends on shedding his patriarchal skin and going straight. You can't read that scene and not understand the good and bad angels sitting on Beauregard's shoulders and shouting into his ears every waking second of every day.And The Yappy Wife/Girlfriend trope is redeemed in the final pages: when he most needs to firmly grasp the wheel of his future and decide whether to turn one direction or the other, Beauregard stops shining on his wife and pretending to pay attention to her, and for once actually listens, and finds defining wisdom in her words. It was a brave choice that redeemed the Man's Gotta Do trope.Much of what is being said about BLACKTOP WASTELAND will, justifiably, focus on its window into Black America, its canny empathy with economic inequality, its spotlight on systemic unfairness. But I hope some see the novel for the superiority of its craft and the sincerity with which it's practiced. These things are what gives this wonderful novel the emotional burst that engages with the story like a supercharger engages with a car at high speed. BLACKTOP WASTELAND not only fires cleanly on all cylinders, it boils the road of its genre and leaves most other crime novels still trying to get off the starting line.

Overview: Beauregard “Bug” Montage is a loving husband, hardworking father and honest mechanic. Bug knows there is no future in the man he was previously known for, “Best Wheelman on the East Coast”.He left all that behind him, but as his new life starts to crumble and things become financially too tough, Bug is drawn back into the “life” of cars and guns. When a past associate comes around talking about a super easy jewelry story heist, Bugs feels he has no choice but, to join in. Constantly haunted by the ghost of his past (his father), Bug must navigate the blacktop wasteland or die in the process as his family and new life depend on it. He will do whatever it takes. Thoughts: I hope you put on a seat belt because this one is a wild ride!!!!! I wish I could give 6 stars for this! I had to take an entire day to process this one. It is utterly fantastically written with hidden messages, action scenes (there are A TON) and heart racing acts of violence. This will DEF. be made into a movie!I have never read anything by S.A. Crosby but, after this I will continue too. His writing is wonderful. His character is development flawless. There was so much substance and real life issues sprinkled throughout this novel that can be easily missed due to the action or taken at face value. The constant theme in the novel is the systemic issue of poverty and demographics. It shows how poverty and bad luck can follow you throughout a family and generation. It shows the rat race that one can get into when poor and how hard it is to climb out of a hole and live. It’s a common story and one we have all either heard, read or lived through but, it’s beautifully told. It’s a great crime drama that will make you hold on to your seats and turn those pages faster than Bug revs his engine!

Wow, that was an amazing roller coaster of a ride we went on with Beauregard ‘Bug’ Montage - car mechanic, small business owner, father, husband and occasional, brilliant getaway driver. Bug is doing his best to lead a good life and be a good father but he’s stressed and facing a massive dilemma - bills piling up, a bigger business competitor who is taking many of his clients, a daughter from his first marriage who needs money for a decent education and two young boys from his current marriage who have a variety of needs. His wife Kia is a rock who always supports him no matter what but there are only so many hours she can work whilst being the main carer for the boys. Some low life criminals Bug knows from his previous life tempt him with what is supposed to be an easy diamond heist and all he has to do is drive the getaway car, something he can do blindfolded just about. This is an answer to his financial woes. Kia is onto him and begging him to stay clean. Will he succumb and agree to the job? Will his demons come back to haunt him?I loved the journey S. A. Cosby took us on here. It is non-stop action packed, very gritty and had such authentic characters. You really end up barracking for Bug and hoping he ends up OK. Woven in with all the action are strong themes of father-son relationships and the intergenerational poverty facing African Americans. Surely the film rights will get snapped up for this one. I would just caution that there is plenty of explicit and graphic violence in the book but I hope that doesn’t put you off, it’s a great addition to the crime genre. Highly recommended.

This book had me weak in the knees. 
 You gotta drive like don’t nothing else matter except getting to that line. Drive like you fucking stole it.   ... Beauregard slammed the gas pedal to the floor. Wheels spun, and white smoke plumed up from the rear of the Duster.  ... he jammed the car into second as the Duster’s front wheels grabbed the road like a pair of eagle’s talons.   The trees on both sides of the road were shimmering blurs as he tore down through the night. S. A. Cosby has written some of the best car driving scenes I’ve read in a long time. BLACKTOP WASTELAND reminds me of the one hot summer when I lived in a hick town at age 17. Nothing to do but drive recklessly down those two-lane country roads. I’ve always loved the thrill of controlling a vehicle to hug the blacktop and negotiate the turns at the fastest speed possible. Alas, those days are long gone. But I digress...Ronnie was screaming in his ear. No words, just one long nonsensical wail. They were doing 60, hurtling towards an unfinished section of road.Backwards.This book concerns a family man, Beauregard “Bug” Montage, whose car repair shop is losing business to the fancier new shop that has come to his very small town in Virginia. His mom is in a senior assisted living center and his daughter needs money for college. His salvage yard-owning mentor, Boonie, has no money to lend him. He can think of no other way to get an infusion of money than to yet again be the getaway driver for a heist. Things go terribly wrong. The rest of the book is Bug dealing with the aftermath of the heist. There are several evil characters that we don’t get to know intimately but Bug and his close friends and family are fairly well characterized. Mrs. Talbot didn’t like his mother and Beauregard couldn’t really say he blamed her. At the same time, it was no need to make it sound like his mother was a thief. Cruel, insensitive, manipulative, yes. Thief, no. The Montage men held down the thievery crown in his family.Bug doesn’t want to end up like his father, who was also a criminal and left his family high and dry when Bug was young. His wife, Kia, wants Bug to stay out of the Life permanently. He likes the excitement of fast driving and has no compunction from using violence on those who have done him wrong. Isn’t he already like his father?Bug wrestles with leaving his family so they won’t endure repercussions from his recent criminal activity. He knows the effect his father leaving had on him as a son. Why doesn’t he realize they will still endure hostility if he flees? What about his oldest boy? He’s already broken the law and he’s still a kid. Doesn’t he need a father? Doesn’t his wife deserve a partner? Why can’t he own up for what he’s done?Be warned there is a lot of swearing and graphic violence.Despite the violence, which is part of this type of life, I really liked all of the action in this high octane story.

This was great.Bug, a reformed convict winds up reverting back to old ways when he winds up with his back against the wall...He's already barely getting by living above board, always coming up just a little short or a little late but managing to scrape by. That is until he bets on a street race thinking he'll be able to make some extra money to cover both his rent AND his son's much needed eye glasses, and then wins, gets to enjoy approximately two minutes of relief and happiness over his win until low and behold, some "cops"appear on the scene and shake them down for their winnings, only within a few minutes of being let go they start thinking a little more rationally and put two and two together-they were in fact not cops, they we're just two white dudes who decided they could pretend to be white cops, knowing the black men would almost certainly acquiesce & submit, typical black man white cop dynamics and all. Once they realize they've been swindled, Bug tracks down his fellow black man who participated in the scheme & basically sold them out, exacts some poetic justice, but doesn't manage to get back his full winnings and so sadly is still coming up short in the $$ department. There is still rent to be paid, a kid that needs glasses to be able to see clearly, etc etc. So when a friend from his former shady criminal life shows up and makes him an offer to join in on a "job," it is truly an offer that Bug cannot refuse. Naturally the job does not wind up being the seamless, one and done pop off that Bug was hoping for beyond all reason, which is very bad for Bug but very good for myself the reader who delighted in reading about the misadventures of this not so reformed convict. I totally dug it. I loved Bug as a character, loved most of the characters actually even the "bad guys." But mostly I loved how different this felt than every other domestic thriller I've read. This was an entirely different brand of domesticity, this was dad duties but in the world of a black hick from the south pretty much. Not your typical MC, & not your typical thriller. A very very solid 4 star read.

4/5Being a big fan of gritty crime or crime noir with media such as The Criminal series from Brubaker/Phillips, Breaking Bad, Quarry, True Detective etc. etc. this novel by S.A. Cosby popped on my radar and I'm certainly excited to say it stands shoulder to shoulder with the best the genre has to offer. The story involves Beauregard or "Bug", a black mechanic living in small-town Virginia (this leads to some interesting interactions as to be expected), scraping by as a small-business owner of a mechanics garage -- he has a second wife with two kids, another kid from a previous relationship when dumb and young, a waspy mother, and father who exited his life as a young kid. Life seemed to be going swimmingly until his past as a criminal comes rearing its ugly head, flipping his life upside down and putting a ton of stress on the fella. Cosby has a knack for cutting prose and pitch-perfect dialog, capturing the feel of the southern states and criminal element. He also excels at an interesting plot without losing plenty of feeling. Bug is a complicated character to be sure, both with a complicated relationship with his father (idolizing him in some ways but cursed by him in others). Action is also well-wrought with tons of high speed chases, heists, and gun-play. There's hardly anything to knock on this one, and while not life-changing, it is extremely entertaining and surprisingly heart-felt. At the end of this one I'm still unsure what to think of Bug. Very much recommended and it will have you flipping pages faster than Bug drifting around a corner in his muscle car.

I don't get it. I feel like I'm missing something here. I was incredibly excited to pick this book up based on the rave reviews from leading literary lights - noir and otherwise. The first chapter is a delightful rocket out of hell - desperate, detailed, and gripping.Then after the scene break in the middle of the second chapter, this became an entirely different novel. The narrative voice meanders and loses the sweaty immediacy of the first chapter. Sentence structure and rhythm becomes distractingly atonal. Cosby bludgeons the reader with strained simile. Descriptions of locations and emotions become maddeningly vague. It feels like a series of massive failures of editing. Cosby clearly has a cinematic vision for the novel. Some set pieces, particularly a couple action scenes, come together nicely. The plot is well-constructed and the right beats happen at the right times. There are moments of razor-sharp, incisive dialogue. But even that is inconsistent, and Cosby frequently succumbs to cliche. The characters are completely two-dimensional and rote, pastiches of Elmore Leonard or George Pelecanos creations rather than believable people. There's no distinction between the narrative voices of major characters. Similes and thoughts are laughably out of place - far too verbose and sophisticated for sorry rednecks, for example. Bug and Ronnie shouldn't think in the same voice.Cosby's obvious talent shines occasionally, but this feels like an early draft. So much of this feels like corners were cut. Disappointing and confounding.

The combination of beautiful prose, high octane action, and deeply relatable characters makes Blacktop Wasteland one of the best books of 2020 and it's author S.A. Cosby a must read for me.Beauregard Montage is a loving father and husband, a loyal friend, and honest mechanic. Bug, like his father before him, is a virtuoso wheelman and adrenaline junky who is prone to fits of violence.In artistically describe settings that touches on each of our five senses, we watch the internal battle between Beauregard and Bug play out. Readers are treated to a variety of action sequences worthy of their own summer blockbuster on the big screen, with muscle cars rocketing down the road, meticulously planned heists, and ever changing allies and foes. Underneath all the kinetic energy of the men and machines, the deep connection between Beauregard and his family is constantly felt, bubbling just below the surface... raising the stakes and spiking our emotional tachometer into the red.I will admit that this novel had slipped down my To Be Read pile for some inexplicable reason, it wasn't until the other reviewers at Best Thriller Books nearly kicked me out of the group that I quickly got my copy and slammed through it in under 24 hours.Don't be like me... read this book ASAP!

Everyone has been raving about BLACKTOP WASTELAND for months, and now I finally see why! Beauregard “Bug” Montage, who used to be known as the best getaway driver on the east coast, has since given up that life for his wife and kids and honest business. But when several situations converge at once to put him in financial constraints that could keep him from providing for his family, he agrees to take one last job. The jewelry store heist, which seems like a safe enough bet, soon goes south, putting everything Bug holds dear on the line. This book is gripping, heart-pounding, surprising, and immensely moving. At the center of the story is Bug’s struggle to decide what kind of man he wants to be, or what kind of man it’s in his DNA to be. And even though most people reading this book will have never been in the exact situation Bug finds himself in, that core question of identity—and of what you’re willing to do when your back is against the wall—is one that will resonate with many readers. SA Cosby beautifully depicts Bug’s family dynamics, which made the threat to his family even more impactful. The writing is filled with inventive similes and spare but lovely turns of phrase, and the driving scenes are explosive and exciting (even for someone like me who cares nothing of cars or fast driving). I flew through this book in just a couple days; it’s definitely a 2020 standout.

A man can't be two types of beast.Beauregard "Bug" Montage is hanging on by a thread. His mechanic shop is losing business to the new shop in town, his daughter needs college tuition, and his mother lied about her income and now is getting kicked out of her nursing home. He needs money, bad.But there's one thing Bug is really great at, and that's driving fast and driving well. So when he's offered a job as a getaway driver in a diamond heist, he has a hard time saying no. It wouldn't be his first time, and if he calls the shots, what can go wrong? And can he convince his wife that this really will be the last time - there's no way he's going to turn into his father? This book was a really excellent surprise. I hadn't heard of this author, but it was on my TBR list and I needed a title with a color in it so I picked it up. I couldn't be happier about it. Bug is a terrific, conflicted character who doesn't always make the right decisions. He's smart, but sometimes not smart enough. The central/southeast Virginia setting felt authentic, especially with the racial tension and the dynamics between the haves and the have-nots. The action is well-written and compelling. This story is grimy and gutsy and harrowing and it doesn't want to let you go.I listened to the audiobook, which I thought was very well done. There's also a nice interview with S.A. Cosby at the end.

Beauregard “Bug” Montage is your average guy: a mechanic, a husband and a father. He's also a retired getaway driver that's known as one of the best drivers on the east coast. Bug is going through a really rough time when a former associate approaches Bug with the offer to drive for a jewelry store heist. Bug then makes the hard decision to come out of retirement to drive again for one last heist. Will everything go as planned or will something go wrong like it did when Bug's dad was a getaway driver?This book covered everything: race, family, poverty, and crime. I couldn't stop reading it and it was hard to put down! The writing was amazing, S.A. Cosby really knows how to weave a story together and make you feel all of the emotions. The pacing of the book and the plot were also 100% on point. I'll definitely be reading anything else he writes in the future!The thing I loved most about this book was how it read like a movie! If you love crime, thrillers, or mysteries or you were a fan of the movie Drive or Ocean's Eleven, you'll really love this book too! You won't want to miss out on reading this one, I HIGHLY recommend it!!!Thank you to the publisher and NetGalley for the e-arc!
