text: Action-packed crime fiction.Bug Montage was the best wheelman east of the Mississippi. It's in his blood: his daddy was the best wheelman before him. But all that's in the past; he hung up his nitrous tank and now he's a family man with a wife and three children he loves. He's gone so straight he even owns an auto shop and runs it with his cousin.Things oughta be good for Bug, but he just can't seem to catch a break. A big, new shop has opened nearby and they're stealing his customers. His mom's nursing home is going to kick her out for non-payment. His mortgage is 3 months behind, and his daughter plans to put off college for a year because tuition's so expensive. When an old associate offers Bug a third of the take on a jewelry store heist, he realizes the payout would go a long way to digging him out of the hole. He reluctantly accepts the job, never realizing how much it's going to cost him...If you like movies like Dead Presidents or Baby Driver, you'll like this. It's gritty and actiony with plenty of car chases to keep your adrenaline and interest high. I couldn't put it down.

This is a galloping, heart thumping ride through high tension crimes, but it's far more than that. In Beauregard "Bug" Montage, the protagonist, S.A. Cosby has created a Black man who not only has had to face the world's prejudice, but struggles with his own personal demons, trying to leave behind a life as one of the best drivers for criminal capers in his part of the South, and uphold his wife Kia and his two sons by running a legitimate repair shop.Then quotidian disasters come calling. A chain auto shop opens up, siphoning off vital business. His hard-bitten mother is about to be kicked out of her nursing home, and his daughter from a previous relationship needs tuition money. That's when redneck Ronnie Sessions approaches him with a surefire diamond heist.Beauregard reluctantly agrees, but of course, things do not go according to plan, and the "easy" job brings unwanted attention from a truly brutal gang, and after that, it's one white knuckle moment after another.A tremendously well written, violent thriller, with characters that have real lives and emotions. Drive, do not walk, to read this.

We may not all drive getaway cars or kill badguys, but I think most of us can relate to the protagonist of this book. You struggle and struggle to build a decent life and keep your business running, but s*** just keeps happening. Kid needs college money, kid needs glasses, insufferable mother "forgot" to tell Medicaid she had a life insurance policy--thats an asset--and now she owes $40,000 or they're going to throw her out of the nursing home and she'll have to come live with guess who? This tough but good hearted former getaway driver has tried so hard to go straight and be a good husband and dad, but things are unraveling and he gets sucked into to doing just this one job so he can get caught back up....and to put it nicely, things do not go smoothly.This novel moves right along and the descriptive writing is golden. This was our last read-aloud book and husband also really enjoyed it. Violence, fast cars, double-crossing cohorts and a wife who is fed up with it all...what's not to like?

Wow, I loved this! Blacktop wasteland is a beautiful character study within a thriller. The whole time I was reading it I thought, this would be an amazing movie. It takes place all around rural Virginia which was fun for me.My favorite thing about this book is that on the surface level, it’s about fast cars, crime, etc.—but actually the heart of the book is the heart of the main character. I appreciated the cracking wide open of the stereotype readers might be tempted to put the main character into; Cosby probes questions of family, masculinity, love, and commitment on basically every page. His writing is seriously lovely and I underlined multiple sentences bc I loved the prose so much (again—in a book about “fast cars”! So impressive).This book left me saying “damn that was so good.” Officially a big fan of Cosby! My one warning with this book is: there’s a lot of car talk, so if you’re not into that, DON’T be put off by it. It feels heavy at first but then the balance is perfect.

I don't know if it's accurate to call BLACKTOP WASTELAND S.A. Cosby's a debut, but if so, this is one of the best debut novels I've ever read. I haven't enjoyed a new author like this since I read Jack Carr's THE TERMINAL LIST.Beauregard "Bug" is an amazing character. He's not only incredibly dynamic, but it feels like you literally see the character develop right before your eyes. This book felt like a biography or memoir, and it was so real. This novel kept the petal to the floor - figuratively and literally. I steered through this book in one day. It flew by just like the asphalt underneath Bug. This book has accelerated to then top of my 2020 Reading List as one of my favorites, and it will be one of those books I plan to revisit again and again. It was captivating and was a non-stop thrill ride. Okay, enough with the puns.Fantastic novel! Highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys thrillers!

“Listen, when you’re a black man in America you live with the weight of people’s low expectations on your back every day. They can crush you right down to the goddamn ground. Think about it like it’s a race. Everybody else has a head start and you dragging those low expectations behind you. Choices give you freedom from those expectations. Allows you to cut ’em loose. Because that’s what freedom is. Being able to let things go. And nothing is more important than freedom. Nothing. You hear me, boy?- Beauregard "Bug" MontageA man named Beauregard “Bug” Montage who commits a crime at the cost of his life, his job and his family. Blacktop Wasteland is a mystery thriller that deals with social issues such as racism, class and identity. Dark, Gritty, emotionally charged and action packed. We see Bug struggling with who he is, who he was and who he thinks he will be. Thanks to Netgalley and Flatiron books for the E-ARC.

Beauregard 'Bug' Montage has worked hard to turn his life around. He has a family, a small repair shop, and a fine place to live. He's a happy and law-abiding citizen. It wasn't always like this though. He used to be in the life, working as the best getaway driver in the area. When a series of bad life situations occur that threaten to destroy the life that Beauregard has worked so hard to build, he has to take on one last job to get the money he needs. Cosby is an incredible writer and Bug is an incredible character. I love how Cosby made Bug this complex man that is simultaneously hard and soft, tough and sensitive. This book blew me totally away. It's in competition for the best crime/heist novel that I've ever read. It's full of relatable and hateable characters with complex motivations and deep backstories. The action scenes are riveting, the plot is entrancing, and the characters are compelling. Simply put, I loved this book.

Beauregard “Bug” Montage wears a lot of hats in this story. A troubled son, a devoted husband and father, a struggling small business owner, and formerly known as the best damn wheelman on the East Coast since his father Ant went missing. His old life tugs at him. He struggles to be a better man than his father was. He’s trying to do the right thing when life keeps kicking him in the teeth. And Bug can only take so much before he has to rise up and be what he’s best at…taking scores and driving like a bat out of Hades. As fast as he drives, Bug can’t escape his past, present, or future.Blacktop Wasteland goes on my Mt. Rushmore of wheelman novels next to Duane Swierczynksi’ “The Wheelman”, Andrew Vachss “The Getaway Man” and James Sallis “Drive”. S.A. Cosby’s book is that good. He explores the weight of being good at something society deems bad. The cost crime has on him and his family. Cosby takes uneasy themes and makes us yearn to read more.

It's hard to root for a main character who kills and steals in the name of providing for his family, but I jumped on board when it comes to light that this is a guy who's trying to overcome the past but the present keeps throwing obstacles in his way.Auto mechanic Beauregard (Bug) is likeable, tenacious, violent, smart, and funny. His driving skills are legendary and over-the-top extraordinary. He gets in deep with the wrong people and things get bloody in a hurry. The supporting cast tends toward the one-dimensional, but they add a lot to the story and show us the tender side of Beauregard. This one is gritty, profane, and tough to read in places. It's also got heart and a flawed hero who is trying his best to deal with the crummy hand he's been dealt. I enjoyed the ride despite the lack of believability. Who knows, perhaps there are people in this world who can drive backwards and fly over unfinished bridges?

This is a fabulous read. Breathtakingly fast with a gritty story line and dangerous characters. Beauregard is the key character; a not quite good guy, who, on the surface, is trying to be better but is forced back into the life of a wheel man for a robbery which, inevitably, goes wrong. The thing about Beauregard though, is the fact that he misses his life driving fast getaway cars so although his need to provide for his family is the main reason for joining a new crew, he is also drawn back into his old life (and that of his father) in order to satisfy his need for an adrenaline high. It' makes for a wonderfully complicated relationship with his wife and family and is a key component of the story. This is a pacey thriller taking place in a background where violence is never far from the surface; a glimpse into a scary world. Very well written with a main character you can engage with straight away. Well worth the read.

High octane plot and prose. (some of the latter borders on comic book splash, but it works.)Some of description in key action scenes a bit convoluted, too elaborate for its own good (at least for my diminished ability to track slick maneuvers with multiple moving parts), especially chase scene with multiple vehicles pulling off a kind of high-speed shell game that left me scratching my head. I never did figure out the timing or who was driving what and when.Complex characters with real family problems keep it from being all thrills and spills.So with all this carping, why 4 stars? It is damn entertaining, and I cared about what happened to characters. I would've been happy to see them in future books, but apparently it's not a seriesLook forward to reading his latest Razorblade Tears.

A high octane, intense, fast paced crime and thriller novel. Beauregard “Bug” Montage is a man trying to make an honest living running his own garage and leave his past behind him. As Bug tries to live an honest life, be a good father to his children, run his own business, and pay for his mother’s care at a nursing home his financial woes start to mount. His small garage business now has competition from a bigger company, the utility bills for his garage are adding up, his mom may be ejected from the nursing home, and his children have needs as well (new glasses, money for college, etc.) Bug finds himself in dire straits when an associate from his past offers him a job that will make him cash and fast. As Bug gets pulled back into the life he thought he left behind he finds he kind of misses aspects of that life, but his past and those associated with it have a huge impact on his family. S. A. Cosby really knows how to create characters that you want to see succeed and Adam Lazarre-White does an amazing job of bringing Bug to life and makes you feel as if you’re riding shotgun with Bug through this entire novel.

"My Daddy? My Daddy was like a thunderstorm in a world of gentle breezes. That's the way he tore through life. That's the way he raised me."Wow. 2 for 2 S.A. Cosby. The start to finish suspense and action. The strong male driven character. The greed, struggle & family ties. The yearn for redemption. I loved it.And all the car details that would usually bore me ?? I was engaged to the very end.I need more from this author. SN - Kelvin, my heart🥺

I really am not sure how this book ended up in my reading queue. I must have read a note about it at some point that convinced me it might be something I would enjoy reading. It certainly isn't something that I would normally have picked to read, but I am trying to diversify my reading this year, so maybe that's why I included it. It seems to have been written for men who like fast, loud cars, and who really get off on driving them. It is basically a heist story and the main protagonist is a getaway driver extraordinaire. Nobody can catch him when he's behind the wheel.That protagonist is a Black man called Beauregard "Bug" Montage. He has a checkered past, but now he's attempting to go straight. He has his own garage. He is a family man who is trying to take care of that family and set a good example for his two children. But he has money troubles and one of his former associates takes advantage of that. He offers him a chance to make one big payday. All he has to do is drive a getaway car once again. The job is a sure-thing jewelry store heist that promises a big payoff for everybody involved. Bug's back is against the wall and he feels he has no choice but to go for it. After all, nothing could possibly go wrong. Until, of course, something does.Bug has a car that belonged to his father, a man who disappeared from his life when he needed him most, and whose ghost still haunts him as an adult. The car is a Duster. (I looked it up - it's an old model of Plymouth from the '70s.) Bug loves that car more than life itself. It's a juiced-up model that he has tricked out as a drag racer. When he runs in drag races he always wins. No one can touch that car. It would probably be worth $25,000 and his wife begs him to sell it in order to wipe out his debt, but Bug refuses. He'll take the job as a getaway driver instead.The jewelry store heist turns out to be a bit more complicated than advertised. The jewels actually belong to a really bad guy and he takes offense at having his property stolen. Revenge is on his mind and Bug's family is in the frame as one of his targets. The whole thing gets really tangled and Bug has to agree to do another job to get himself and his family clear. The results could easily have been predicted by anyone who was paying attention.There are some nice moments in the book. The core of the story is about father-son relationships, race, class, family, and identity. Some of this might have been developed for deeper exploration had this been a different kind of book, but the writer obviously had other goals in mind. His goal seems to have been to write a hard-driving, testosterone saturated gritty crime thriller, and, to some extent, I suppose he succeeded in that. Obviously, I was not the audience he had in mind for his book, but I expect the target audience loved it. And if you are up for such a story, well, here's your book!

4.5 starsA high-octane thrill ride, as a man goes to extreme lengths to save the life he built for himself.Beauregard "Bug" Montage knows cars.How to build them.Fix them.And especially, drive them.The words "need for speed" should have been burned onto the Montage family crest.When strapped for cash, he uses that last skill in some illegal ventures. His skills as a driver, being widely known, are how a new "opportunity" crosses his path.I thought this story would center on one crime, as Bug and two low-lifes, Ronnie and Quan, plan to rob a jewelry store. But this is no Ocean's Eleven. It seems everything that could go wrong, does, and the bulk of the story is on everything that followed that crime.While Bug makes a lot of bad decisions, he is clearly the only one with brains in the trio, and it is also clear, the other two men are the reason why everything continues to go south."The world's fine, Ronnie. It's us that's fucked up."Bug was a fascinating character, the perfect protagonist for this story. He's got so much potential but uses that potential in all the wrong ways. He recognizes his own flaws, something he attributes to his upbringing, and it was fascinating to read how he evaluated his own behavior and decisions as everything falls apart."But my Daddy was right. You can't be two types of beasts. Eventually one of the beasts gets loose and wrecks shop. Rips shit to Hell."I stumbled upon this book after seeing it highly rated by someone on my Goodreads TL. It isn't a genre I normally read, but I enjoyed it immensely. If you are a fan of crime novels or just looking for something different, this fast paced adrenaline ride is worth checking out! *An ARC was received via NetGalley for an honest review.For more reviews, visit

Blacktop Wasteland shouldn't work. It just shouldn't. I must have encountered at least 5 or 6 overly used and abused tropes within the first few chapters that had me worried they would surely cause the demise of this book. I have never been more relieved to be proved wrong. S.A. Cosby has created a masterpiece with his gritty, intense crime fiction novel Blacktop Wasteland. Cosby took every single tired trope, cut them up into pieces, threw them up in the air only to intricately weave them back together but into something fresh and unique. On top of feeling like this story was a unicorn, I literally could not put it down. Beauregard “Bug” Montage is a character that I will not soon forget and just might be one of my top 10 favorites. I've always had a soft spot for tortured heroes and I found myself in several shades of emotions throughout the book. There were moments I rooted for him. Moments my eyes got blurry with tears. My heart hurt for the child inside the man that just wanted to be enough for his daddy. My heart ached for the husband and father who tried to live on the right side of the law but continually got the shitty end of the stick. Moments of despair when I thought maybe, just maybe there was no coming back after fully embracing all that darkness.Blacktop Wasteland is the full package--from the clear voices of the dialogue, to the relatable characters (Kia, Kelvin, Boonie) the exhilarating and nail-biting heist to quieter moments in the novel, flashbacks that are perfectly placed and eventually lead up to one of the most pivotal moments in Beauregard's life. Add to the fact that this book read like a movie. From the very opening scene to the very last page, I could visualize the entire cinematic experience in my mind. Idris Elba or Mahershala Ali as Beauregard. Directed by Jeff Nichols. Well written, intense, storytelling at its best, Blacktop Wasteland is the onion of all onions-- so many layers that can appeal to so many different types of readers. Whether you are looking for your next crime novel fix or want to delve deeper into the psyche of the African American male experience in America, what it means to be born into a life where society already expects you to fail. I'll be keeping my eye out for future S.A. Cosby novels as well as catching up on his backlist!

Blacktop Wasteland went very quickly from a book I’d never heard of before it came out to a book I had to have once the initial reviews began pouring in. How rare is it for a story like that to live up to the hype? But that’s exactly what Cosby’s book does.If one were forced to pigeonhole the book, you might say it’s a heist novel, but it goes far deeper than that. Characterization is at the forefront for Cosby, and the book centers around one of the most complex characters you’ll find in the crime genre. Beauregard “Bug” Montage is kind of a badass, but where some authors quell the character development there, Cosby digs quite a bit deeper. Bug leads a dual-life, a man of violence, or maybe more aptly a man of doing what needs to be done to get by. He’s also a family, demonstrating from the first appearance of Kia and his children, his devotion and willingness to take care of them at the cost of everything else.You take the action, the fight scenes, the pulse-pounding driving scenes, and the tension out of this story and you still have the story of a flawed character doing the best he can with the cards life has dealt. But why on earth would want to take those other things away when they’re so well done? The driving scenes are written with a cinematic flare and genuine thrill. Just try reading them from anywhere but the edge of your seat.The setting is a massive contributor to the overall feel of the story. So many plot points stem from money issues, which stem from the difficulties of being a black-owned mechanic in a town where the cookie-cutter assembly line type of mechanic shop opens up. Seeking opportunities to better your situation, but society seems to be doing everything in its power to hold you down. I’ve already written at length about Bug’s character development, but this picture of rural black America lends a great deal of credibility and authenticity to Cosby’s portrayal.Blacktop Wasteland is equal parts compelling, thrilling, and surprising. It’s a rare book that keeps me drawn to every page, unable to let my reading attention jump stories. I swallowed this thing up in two days, and only wish I could experience it again for the first time. With one book, Cosby has cemented himself as a must-buy author and I’ll be picking up his next offering, Razorblade Tears, on day one.

Five high octane stars! I think it was somewhere around page 100, (and this wasn't a bad thing - still very interesting) author S.A. Cosby stepped on the gas and from then on, barely took his foot off. Only a bit of braking and then whoosh, the narrative sped along and I swear there were sirens woo-wooing, the squeal of rubber tires, and blue lights flashing in my bedroom as I read this energizing story. There was so much to love, and now I've caught my breath, it's like I want to get all breathless again talking about Cosby's story. I loved some of his metaphors. The plot was tight. Beauregard needs money. He's got a family, and two boys who need the things growing boys need, a daughter who wants to go to college. He runs an auto-mechanic shop, but thanks to Precision, they're taking all his business. The crickets are busier in "Bug's" shop than he and his cousin, Kelvin are. Bug has been in trouble in the past. His daddy disappeared on them when he was a kid, and he has, rightly or wrongly, put the man on a pedestal even while he mostly brought them trouble. Bug is sure he's cut out to be just like his father. Bad = Bug. And so far, he's trying to balance his two selves. The bad Bug, the good Bug. But. Debts. On top of everything, his auto-mechanic's shop rent is due - past due actually, and his mama's assisted living is about to boot her out due to a snafu in Medicare.Yeah boy. Problems. So an opportunity comes by way of somebody he ought to know better than to trust. Good ole Ronnie and Reggie Sessions, two a**backwards thinking winners, I mean losers. But, Bug needs to do something. Off they go. They're in the money! It gets sprinkled where it needs to and puts out the immediate fires. Only, then it goes bad. Then it gets worse. Then it gets EVEN worse. And you wonder how in the world can any one man stand it? You will have to read to figure out all that happens. I wish there was a way to hook up a reader to a device to measure heart rate and blood pressure while reading such novels as this. Meanwhile, I'll be over here trying to calm down.Highly recommend!

I am clearly in the minority here.This book was a frustrating read that frequently resulted in me massively rolling my eyes as the audiobook steamed ahead. My recurring thought was that this author must have recently completed a high school English course and was applying what they discussed in class that day.It felt as if the author struggled with how to share details with the reader. Objects and events were described three times over in a variety of ways when one would have sufficed. Attention to detail is great, but saturating the text with pinpoint focus overwhelms the reader and completely destroys the momentum. Thugs arrive with guns akimbo? Time to take two minutes describing their outfits. Climactic car chase that could change the course of the main character's life? Let's spend a paragraph reviewing their stick shift maneuvers.The use of constant and overextended metaphors/similes also consistently pulled the reader out of the story. Had they been interspersed over the course of several pages I would have valued their impact more. However, it was rare to find a page that didn't have at least two uses of figurative language that didn't quite hit the mark.The author employed a strange use of perspective, causing the reader to struggle with the narration changing between first and third person. I was frequently re-listening to blocks of passages attempting to determine whose thoughts were being shared. Often, what could have passed as beautiful internal self-talk became forced and pompous self-revelations laboriously spelled out to another character.Finally, I felt that the character of Bug was played up to be almost omnipotent. The speed at which he constructs flawless and perfectly timed criminal plans was meant to demonstrate that he was "part of the life", but really it just came off as sloppy characterization. Not to mention that Bug has the incredible ability to self-heal, because none of his numerous injuries (which are vividly described then promptly forgotten) impact his performance.Coupled with wholly one-dimensional side characters and an unsatisfying ending, I walked away from this book with bad taste in my mouth.

As a big fan/connoisseur of crime fiction, Blacktop Wasteland, by S.A. Cosby, did not let me down. Indeed, it set the bar higher for any writer tackling Southern Noir. Readers are taken on a hell of a ride with racer/former get away driver, Beauregard, who finds himself torn between who he was, where he comes from and who he wants to be all while navigating horrendous potholes that have become his life on the backroads in small towns of Virginia. The journey that author S.A.Cosby takes us on is much like a race itself, beginning at a speed that gives us time to fully invest in Beauregard's life and the myriad of other characters who play second fiddle to this larger than life protagonist. By the middle of the book, much like when racers are part way through their turn on a drag strip, the story cranks up to a full throttle pace and doesn't let up until the unprecedentedly epic ending.  Many authors in the noir genre make the mistake of too much action and not enough character development. This is not Cosby. He makes no mistakes and shows off his skills in his ability to do both equally well with sections of stunning prose intermingled with savage grit. He's a masterful craftsman with the way he makes the reader pause for reflection with impressive one liners, greatly adding to the reading experience. One of my favorites was "Terror had a way of making smart men stupid". Through Beauregard's character, Cosby shows us not only what it must be like to be a man with a past they can't quite get out from under, but also sheds a much needed light on what it's like to be a black man in America. There are few writers who could do this with the challenging, yet straightforward way Cosby has. Blacktop Wasteland is a book that many will be talking about for years to come. I feel sure it will serve as a modern classic and my only disappointing moment while reading it came when I realized I was on the last page.

READ THIS BOOK Beauregard Montage is the man. This book has nonstop action and doesn't let you go until the last second. SA Crosby is a masterful storyteller. If you want car chases, shootouts and intrigue, this is the book for you. Mr. Crosby will be an automatic read going forward.

A blast of a thriller, Blacktop Wasteland douses the classic heist novel in gas and flips out a zippo... Clean prose, sharp dialogue, an unexpected setting (rural Virginia), and some serious novelistic craft on display throughout. If the narrative bones are familiar--hard times demand hard crimes, and everything that can go wrong must go wrong--focusing on a getaway driver trying to juggle his natural calling with middle-aged responsibilities works surprisingly well. It's a bit less of the moody, existential noir that I was hoping for--I'm a defective reader in that this is the only kind of crime fiction I gravitate towards--but instead it's an excellent heist thriller with a healthy dose of realism, sharply drawn characters, and a backdrop that feels surprisingly relevant and new. Rather excellent for what it is.EDIT: I realize I didn't mention the obvious fact that this is also a novel about race, to the extent it's foregrounded by the experience of being black in rural America. While not the overall focus, there is a persistent thread of the type of casual, every-day racist bullshit from some of the white characters. And the forces driving the protagonist's "hard times" clearly boil down to structural racism, wealth inequality, and everything else that's top of mind in the current national discourse. But as much as this is a novel set against that reality, it's not focused on social justice. The focus is on individual characters, crime, family, the impact of hard choices against a backdrop of very human struggles. All of it is informed and given added weight by the carefully-wrought context, and I think anyone reading this in 2020 will bring some of the current moment to the experience of the novel, but the book itself trains its narrative eye on something slightly different, and it feels more personal as a result.

Thank you Flatiron Books for my copy of Blacktop Wasteland by S.A. Cosby in exchange for my honest review.  This title published July 14, 2020.Adrenaline pumping: CHECKComplex & flawed characters: CHECKPage turning premise: CHECKWell executed pace: CHECKS.A. Cosby wrote a real winner here and tells the story of Beauregard, aka "Bug", a former criminal who is just trying to live life on the straight and narrow but quickly realizes that old habits die hard.This book has all the ingredients for the perfect binge read.  With a cast of complex and flawed characters and a timely and compelling premise, I flew through this book in no time.  Cosby's writing is so visual and cinematic and the entire time I was reading I could see the story play out like a movie reel.  It's a dark and gritty story withBug's character and his story is one that will stick with you long after you finish reading.  I found myself rooting for him right from start, despite some of the bad decisions he was forced to make.  He was truly trying to do the right thing but kept being put into situations that he just couldn't get out of without some repercussions.The story revolves around a major heist that is being set up, for which Bug has been recruited, begrudgingly and the choices he must make to get out of it alive and to keep his family safe.A powerful story of one man's struggle with who he is (a father and husband), who he was (a criminal) and who he thinks he will be (a better man than his father), Blacktop Wasteland was emotionally charged and thought-provoking and explored important social issues such as racism, class and identity.   I highly recommend adding this one to your TBR.

Bug used to be known has the best getaway driver, now he’s just an honest mechanic trying to make ends meet for his family. When another shop opens up in town, Bug’s business comes across hard times, especially in a city filled with racial prejudices. When a job comes along that could solve his money problems, Bug is pulled back into his old career one last time. I loved Blacktop Wasteland. This was a fast paced, gritty, and fun, novel that covered just about anything I could want from it. It manages to balance out Bug as this fantastically capable getaway driver grappling with being a good father and good family man, dealing with family history and historical problems arising from him being Black. It’s fun because of the scenes too, some of the driving scenes are wild, and the writing is just so good it feels like you’re watching them. I adored the characters in this. Cosby has not only managed to write a book that manages action packed scenes well, but his characterization is just perfect. All of the characters feel like fully fleshed out people, that you know, that you could one day know, and even those you really don’t want to know. Plus, I have to give a nod to the names - Bug and Ant? Perfect nicknames. There are definitely some hard to read parts too though, it’s a violent story at times. Yet this too felt so balanced with the kind of man Bug was. The violence never felt over the top despite being horrifying, it wasn’t gratuitous , it just was, because that’s the life Bug came from and what he was back to. I can’t speak highly enough of this book, and if you’re a fan of heist stories, you really can’t skip over this one. This is an especially wonderful book if you don’t find enough excellently written characters in your action packed stories.

****4.5****Whew! This intense, incredibly gritty thriller hooked me with the precise writing and richly developed characters. Do I care about race cars? Gem heists? Gangs? Retribution? Not usually....but S.A. Cosby captured me and MADE me care with his introduction to his main character Beauregard "Bug" Montage. Beauregard, a reformed criminal driver, who now runs a mechanic shop is really down on his luck after having several pretty good, above-board years. Cosby tackles the tricky subjects of the poverty cycle effect and racism in the South by showing us exactly how Beauregard wants to be a better man, provide for his family in a legitimate way and be able to raise his kids to overcome the criminal life he thought he had put behind him. Family patterns are impactful, though. The specter of his criminal father, long gone, still has a pull on Beauregard Montage. It seems his world is about to fall down with a daughter who has to postpone college due to lack of funds, a mother about to be released from her assisted living facility due to lack of funds, his garage payments due and his work struggling due to the opening of franchised garage across the street from his garage, his son needs braces.....and the list goes on. "Bug" has a choice. He can sell his beloved car that once belonged to his father, or he can do just one last criminal job with a redneck criminal Ronnie "Rock & Roll" Sessions. What can go wrong....? Well, everything!!The Audible narrator, Adam Lazarre-White is SO VERY GOOD! I highly recommend listening. **Be forewarned, though. The violence is heavy and intense. Lots of details of gang-style torture and death, in great detail and more than I care for by a long-shot.**

Wow. I finished BLACKTOP WASTELAND last night and it’s still sitting with me this morning. And as the story centers on the complicated elements of father/son relationships, what an excellent book to review on Father’s Day.Beauregard “Bug” Montage is a black man in rural Virginia, a husband and father of three, a man who can rebuild a car to ultra power capacities, and a man who can drive like Steve McQueen in a movie car chase. Bug drives so well that when times get tough financially for his family, he will skate over the line and take a job as a getaway driver in a crime. The money is good and Bug is so good, he has yet to be caught. An underlying force behind Bug’s decisions is his history with his absent father Anthony, whose poor decisions Bug is inevitably replicating.Blacktop Wasteland is not for the faint of heart. The violent scenes are frequent and detailed. Cosby’s writing however, in this Southern noir/crime thriller is fantastic and it’s worth skimming those scenes if you are squeamish in order to get to the heart of the story. Cosby weaves a compelling tale of the rural poor as well as the prevalence of racial profiling in the south, and the impossibility of finding a way out for a better life. Bug, despite some questionable choices, is a big hearted, kind man with an eidetic memory who you want more than anything to come out on top. As a side bonus, Cosby references many classic R&B, hip hop and rap songs that I played on Spotify while reading. All the stars for this one!
Starts - then kicks off and is relentless until the end. When they make a flick out of this can it star Daniel Kaluuya and Walter Goggins as Lazy?

I won this book in a Goodreads giveaway.It's not a book I would normally pick up off the shelf. Just not a genre I normally read. BUT all over Bookstagram, I kept hearing how great the book was! Everything I saw on it raved about how great it was and I didn't see anything negative. SO - I went in with high expectations, which, at times, can be bad. BUT this time, it didn't let me down. It was as great as everyone said.I was coming out of a reading slump and trying to fit one more book in by the end of the month, so I'm glad it was this one. I really liked the main character. Even though he was a criminal, he really tried to be a good man. He had left his life of crime and started a family and opened a business and was doing well, but then a rival business came to town and took all his business and he was left in financial trouble, on the verge of losing everything and had to make a hard decision to take an illegal job to make some fast cash to pay off his debtors so he didn't lose his house and business and his Mom wasn't kicked out of her nursing home. It weighed heavy on him, but you gotta do, what you gotta do.I loved the descriptions of his driving and and was yelling at the book at certain points. Towards the end, I was on the edge of my seat and had all sorts of emptions flowing through me! I was mad, shocked, cheering, sad, happy, you name it!I kept thinking of people I needed to recommend this book to as I was reading it. :) I highly recommend!

Synopsis: Beauregard "Bug" Montage is a mechanic, small business owner, devoted dad, and caring husband. But he's also a prodigious getaway driver, a skillful tactician, and a brilliant mind. After multiple financial setbacks, he plans to hit a lick ( heist) and leave the life. But can he escape the game? 🚗 Blacktop Wasteland is a crime-action novel. Cosby's action sequences were stellar - car chases, shoot-outs, and fights. The book is unfiltered and unapologetic, with character dialogue devoid of politeness. Yet, the prose is sophisticated in parts, creating a heady atmosphere. Set among the backdrop of a fictional rural town in Virginia. It is refreshing to see a rural crime novel centering on a Black protagonist and perspective. 🚗 Cosby formulates a riveting character-driven story to accompany the heist-action plot. Through Bug's eyes, the readers experience poverty intimately, forcing the audience to empathize with the characters' plights. Even if you don't understand Bug's choices, you'll root for his success, mourn his failures and yell at his obstinance. Cosby threads racism, rural life, and fatherhood as well. Like a vitrine, Cosby displays Bug's collection of fallacies. The streets call, and he can't reconcile with answering.🚗Bug joins Easy Rawlins, Alex Cross, Detective Virgil Tibbs, Grave Digger & Ed Coffin, Mama Candi, Blanche White, Tamara Hayle, and Marti MacAlister. I hope this isn't the last we see of him. 🚗I need a movie. ASAP.

Powerful story of how one man ("Bug" or more formally, Beauregard) struggles to overcome a family history of violence and crime, is ensnared in his struggle against poverty. Layer on an undercurrent of racism, and you get well developed characters and a compelling narrative.Inevitably, Beauregard falls back on crime to solve his growing problems caused by poverty. He got out of the crime business years ago, used the proceeds to buy an auto repair shop, and started a family. Then a larger, better financed company bought a competing auto repair shop in the same small town in rural Virginia, and his business imploded. He stood to lose his business and his family home. To raise money, he tried auto racing, but was cheated of his winnings. So he turned to crime.This is where the story really picks up, as one crime leads inevitably to more entanglements, and Bug's attempts to escape those entanglements only dig a deeper hole. The resolution is a page turner--full of fast cars, violence, and (some) justice.Saying more would inevitably include spoilers...so I'll just conclude by saying this book is well worth a read, and I very much look forward to reading anything else Cosby has written.

This is not a book I would normally read but even though it was dark and gritty and more of a man’s read, I am definitely glad I picked it up. It is a classic crime thriller with heart that will literally take you on the ride of your life. This sad realistic story reminiscent of heist films from the 70s is about Beauregard (Bug) Montage, a man desperate to hold on to the honest life he was finally living. An honest life he wanted to keep so his wife and children would not have to suffer like he had, living with an outlaw Dad. In order to do this he reverts to his former life – the life he had sworn to give up to when he was finally able to put money down on his own garage. One bad break after another and he was on the verge of losing his garage and his respectability. He was desperate so he took one last job as a getaway driver. The writing is fabulous. It would have to be for me to actually enjoy reading all about fast cars, driving and racing. Bug is portrayed in such a convincing way that you can’t help but root for him even when you hate him for what he is doing. Fans of Ocean’s Eleven, Elmore Leonard, and Breaking Bad will love this southern noir classic.

This is a fast-paced thriller with heart and soul and one of the most compelling heroes I've come across in a while. Beauregard "Bug" Montage owns an auto shop and has a loving wife and two adorable boys. He's left his old life as a wheelman behind. But when bills begin to pile up and his carefully built life begins to crumble, he's lured back with one last big heist. This isn't your typical "one last job" storyline. It's so much more. The writing is raw, honest, and gorgeous. Bug is a flawed hero who struggles between who he wants to be and who he knows he is. It's a story about a man who wants to do right by his family but can't hide from the wounds he inflicts upon himself. I'm blown away by Cosby's writing with lines like these: "...the sun cast elongated shadows against the front of the garage. Narrow black fingers squeezing the building in their grip." This book has earned a lot of buzz and rightfully so. My expectations were high but Cosby blew them out of the water. The ending was heart-breaking and achingly real. A devastatingly beautiful rollercoaster ride of a book.

4.5 stars Thank you Macmillan Audio for the free ALC in exchange for an honest review. All opinions are my own. What an intense and compelling read! I loved the narrator’s voice immediately. It’s got that deep, raspy quality that was meant to be heard!This story wasn’t like anything I had imagined. I definitely read the synopsis at some point when I first saw it popping up all over bookstagram, but I somehow ended up with a completely different idea of what it was about in my head. My misconception did not have any kind of negative impact on the way I felt about it; I just remember being surprised once I figured out what was actually going on.The writing was incredibly descriptive. As a slight trigger warning, there are some violent scenes that are very, very graphic/detailed.It was definitely unlike anything else I’ve read. It reminded me of an action movie, and I love a good action movie! I don’t think I read many books that I would consider action packed in the way that this one was though. Maybe I need to change that. I would certainly read more of this author’s work.

S. A. Crosby's debut novel Blacktop Wasteland is fresh and exciting, with ruffian yet engaging characters that will have your eyes moving across the pages as quickly as the story's tantivy cars.Beauregard has a past that he vowed never to revisit, but he is also a family man who would stop at nothing to support his family. He loves his dad, who is but a flashing memory when he gets into the Nova. When bills start piling up, and mounds of pink papers and final notices litter his desk, will Beauregard evolve into the man who is but a vision who occupies his thoughts when he steps foot in the Nova? How far will Beaugard go to support his family? I have enjoyed this book and look forward to reading more by this author. If you are one who likes crime fiction, I suggest giving this book a go.

Blacktop Wasteland was an enjoyable story, but the writing left a lot to be desired. I found myself caring about the main character, Bug, and wanting to know how his story would end. However, S.A. Cosby's overuse of simile was incredibly distracting. Take, for instance, the below, all of which appeared in the span of three pages:(1) "[T]he concussive force hit...like a sledgehammer."(2) "The lid of the trunk was bouncing up and down like a stripper on the pole."(3) "...like a dire wolf in the recesses of a cave." (4) "The lid of the trunk bounced up and down like the mouth of a huge puppet." (Me: Again with the trunk?)(5) "...like 2,000 pounds of thunder and steel."(6) "...like the eye of a demon..."(7) "The rear end fishtailed like it was salsa dancing." Three pages. Overall, an enjoyable story, but it could have been so much more.

This book should be a movie. Full Stop (with all the force of standing on the brakes after driving a van into the back of a rolling truck at 60mph).It's like Fast & the Furious + Oceans 11, but with really solid character development, subtle examination of racism, and a strong sense of place. Before reading this, I would've dismissed heist plots as "not my thing." But this is so much more than that. It's riveting. The protagonist is complicated and sympathetic and talented, and the supporting cast of characters are all flawed in different ways. I don't think I've ever read a book set in Richmond, North Carolina and the Blue Ridge Mountains, but having spent a lot of time in those places, this book did a great job capturing the vibe and making me realize what might be happening just out of sight. SA Cosby is a great writer. I look forward to reading more of his books.

This one was pretty hyped. I've seen S.A. Crosby's image everywhere and it was covered review-wise by all the big ticket spots, including The New York Times. I've had my eye on Crosby for a while, even though I had yet to read him. A chance encounter at the library helped me nab this one.It absolutely meets the hype. Crosby's prose is smooth, his protagonist complex in all the best ways, the crimes are as high octane as one can expect. The driving and action scenes absolutely crackle. And every time I thought I was zigging with the plot, Crosby would zag but not in a gratuitous way. It's an exciting, star making story written by a writer who I hope we get more of in the coming years.

4.25 stars for Blacktop Wasteland. This book was gritty and thrilling to read. The characters were written so well, and the story is saturated with action and scheming. If you enjoy watching heist movies, are a Fast and Furious fan, and you like reading, this book is DEFINITELY for you. I enjoy all of those things, so I really loved this book. I was on the edge of my seat, rooting for Beauregard.On a deeper level, this is the story of a man struggling to understand and accept who he is as an individual, as a husband, as a father, as a son, and as a friend. Beauregard's battle with himself is engaging, enlightening, sad, but also hopeful. A wonderful book by S.A. Cosby - I wholeheartedly look forward to reading more of his work.

One simple word: Wow! I listened to this on audible and, as we know, a narrator holds in his/her hands the power to make or break the story, even if it's well-written. I must say that not only is the story top-notch, the writing crisp, but the narration was spot-on. Adam Lazarre-White is a first-rate narrator with a voice I never grew tired of and he brought each character to life without being over-the-top. Blacktop Wasteland is a crime story that has fast cars, great characters, and a lot of violence but it kept me glued - I couldn't wait to hear what would happen next. Highly recommended. S.A. Cosby is an author to watch.

BLACKTOP WASTELAND was exactly what I needed to get me out of a reading slump. I adore heist themes, so I was intrigued by the premise of this novel the moment I heard about it. Throw in some powerful Fast & Furious vibes, characters who are vivid, real, and flawed... and, well, I couldn't put it down.Beauregard's world is gritty, violent, and unforgiving. And yet, I couldn't wait to dive back in every time I set the book aside. The writing is superb. Cosby brings a sense of place to the story that's almost uncanny in its accuracy. The character development feels so on-point. I can easily see this book adapted for the big screen. It would make one heck of a movie.

This is a mystery/thriller in the noir tradition that takes you out of the city and into rural black America, specifically the southeast where blacks and whites might coexist, but slavery and the confederacy still linger. There is some extreme gun violence which I didn’t think was gratuitous. It and the language seemed to fit the time, place, and world that the author created. I highly recommend Blacktop Wasteland and want to read more from Cosby.Read my full review here: https://chriswolak.com/2020/07/14/bla...

French: Anéantir; English: "Annihilate"Houellebecq loves to cause scandals, and for this book, he came up with a real shocker: He is now a romantic! Yes! Still an existentialist romantic, but „Anéantir“ is a political thriller, a roman à clef, a family novel and a love story that makes references to all of the great master’s fictional work – and in the end, the author, 65 years old, hints at quitting his profession, after only eight novels. Non, Michel, ne quitte pas!!„Anéantir“ is set in 2027, Emmanuel Macron is approaching the end of his second five-year term. Our protagonist Paul Raison is the personal adviser to the Minister of Economy and Finance, Bruno Juge (Houellebecq is a good friend of the real minister, Bruno Le Maire, who, before the book’s publication, helped spark rumors about the content). While seeking a new Presidential candidate and preparing for the election, international terror attacks shake France and other nations. Who are the terrorists, and what are their aims? The secret service investigates.This plotline becomes less and less important as the story progresses though. Paul’s marriage to Prudence (yup, a Beatles reference!) is in decline, but, in what in the context of Houellebecq can only be read as a surprising plot twist, the two try to revive it in the face of tragedy: Paul’s father, a former secret service agent, suffered a stroke. His partner, a simple, but dedicated and loving woman named Madeleine, cares for him, the family fights again a n anonymous, commercialized health care system. Paul’s unhappily married younger brother Aurélien falls in love with a nurse from Mali, his older, deeply religious sister Cécile tries to stand by her unemployed husband, a notary with connections to right-wing Catholic circles. This family story about, believe it or not, the power and tragedy of love, is the heart of the novel. From there, he investigates a plethora of themes, from tech to terrrorism, from sex to spirituality, from politics to literature. Houellebecq completists (like me) will find references to all of his novels in this book. I was particularly impressed by the way he incorporates Philippe Lançon's Le Lambeau into his book, a book about the Charlie Hebdo terrorist attack, probably the most traumatic experience in Houellebecq’s life. His sparse, sober style works well with this story, focusing on the intricate plot and, per usual, refraining from a lyrical language: Houellebecq stays true to his matter-fact-tone. The story culimates in personal sadness and the possibility of happiness, both at the same time, while the political threat rages on. It will be interesting how the book will be discussed in the context of the upcoming French election, and it will be great fun to search for and investigate the connection to the other seven novels. Published in a lux edition in France, because “Le livre, c’est un de mes objets préférés dans la vie” (same, Michel, saaame!) – the design makes a reference to the Beatles‘ „White Album“, which also plays a role in the novel. The Beatles made some important albums after this, and Houellebecq’s statements aren’t always the most reliable, so let’s see what happens.

Στις ευχαριστιες του, στο τελος του βιβλιου, ο Ουελμπεκ αναφερει οτι ειναι "ωρα να σταματησει" και πολλοι εχουν ερμηνευσει αυτη τη φραση ως τη δηλωση του οτι η εκμηδενιση ειναι το τελευταιο του βιβλιο. Αν ισχυει κατι τετοιο, σιγουρα θα λειψει πολυ σε πολλους, ωστοσο αν οντως επιθυμει κατι τετοιο, δεν υπαρχει κατα τη γνωμη μου καλυτερος τροπος να ριξει την αυλαια.Η εκμηδενιση ξεκινα σαν ενα κλασικο, αγαπημενο βιβλιο του Ουελμπεκ. Δριμύτατη κριτικη στη συγχρονη κοινωνια, στην πατριαρχια, σεξ τρομοκρατια, πολιτικη, το βιβλιο περιλαμβανει ενα πολιτικο θριλερ που εξελισσεται πριν τις εκλογές στη Γαλλια του 2027..και ενω αισθανεσαι οτι βρισκεσαι σε γνωριμο εδαφος και κουνας συγκαταβατικα το κεφαλι, ξαφνικα το τελευταιο κομματι του βιβλιου ρίχνει μια γερη γροθια σε οσα νομιζες οτι προεβλεψες. Γιατι ο Ουελμπεκ πλεον ειναι ενας ανθρωπος που οπως λεγεται βρισκεται στη δυση της καριερας του, οπως και στο σημειο της ζωης του που ο ανθρωπος αναλογιζεται το πριν και κοιτα με θαρρος το αναποφευκτο του θανατου. Κι εκει βλεπουμε εναν ηρωα που λυγιζει σε ενα τοπιο θανατου που σε κανει να ασφυκτιας, που αισθανεται την αναγκη για στηριξη, αγαπη, συντροφικοτητα, που στρεφεται στην οικογενεια. Οι περιγραφες για το πως ενας ισχυρος ανδρας περνα στην πληρη εκμηδενιση του σωματος του, αλλα διατηρει πληρως τα συναισθηματα και την αντιληψη του, ειναι πραγματικα αριστοτεχνικη.Το βιβλιο αυτο οπως ειχα αναφερει, με διελυσε με εναν τροπο μοναδικο, με συγκινησε, με προβληματισε... Ειλικρινα ευχομαι να μην ηταν αυτη η τελευταια κουβεντα του Ουελμπεκ, ωστοσο αν οντως συμβει κατι τετοιο, τι σπουδαιος τροπος να κλεισεις μια σπουδαια καριερα... Υποκλιση...❤️Χωρις αμφιβολια, μολις θρονιαστηκε στην κορυφη της - μικρης ακομη- λιστας, ως το αγαπημενο βιβλίο του 2022.🌟🌟🌟🌟🌟/5 αστερια"Ποσος καιρος του εμενε ? Ενας μηνας? Τρεις? Ενας χρονος? Επρεπε να ρωτησει τους γιατρους. Και μετα, το τιποτα. Ενα τιποτα ριζικο κι οριστικο. Δεν θα εβλεπε πια τιποτα, δεν θα ακουγε πια τιποτα, δε θ'αγγιζε πια τιποτα , δε θα ενιωθε πια τιποτα, ποτε. Η συνειδηση του θα εξαφανιζοταν ολοσχερως, και θα ηταν σαν να μην ειχε υπαρξει ποτε... Ο κοσμος θα συνεχιζε, τα ανθρωπινα οντα θα ζευγαρωναν, θα ενιωθαν επιθυμίες , θα συνεχιζαν τις δουλειες τους, θα εκαναν ονειρα. Ολα αυτα ομως χωρις εκεινον. Θα αφηνε ενα μηδαμινο ιχνος στη μνημη των ανθρωπων κι επειτα κι αυτο ακομη το ιχνος θα εσβηνε. "

Τελευταία φορά που διάβασα μυθιστόρημα του Μισέλ Ουελμπέκ ήταν τον Μάιο του 2019, τότε που διάβασα το (πολύ καλό κατά τη γνώμη μου) "Σεροτονίνη". Είναι το τέταρτο μυθιστόρημά του που διαβάζω (και πέμπτο βιβλίο συνολικά), και χωρίς αμφιβολία είναι το καλύτερο μέχρι στιγμής. Η αλήθεια είναι ότι εδώ ο Ουελμπέκ είναι λιγάκι διαφορετικός σε σχέση με τα προηγούμενα βιβλία του που έχει τύχει να διαβάσω, είναι κάπως λιγότερο καυστικός και κυνικός, μάλλον κομματάκι πιο ανθρώπινος και πιο... ρομαντικός; Είναι ποτέ δυνατόν; Ναι, είναι! Γιατί όχι; Σίγουρα θίγει πολλά ζητήματα της σύγχρονης γαλλικής κοινωνίας (και κατ' επέκταση όλου του Δυτικού πολιτισμού), όπως για παράδειγμα η πολιτική, η σύγχρονη τεχνολογία, η οικονομία και οι οικογενειακές και ερωτικές σχέσεις, με το γνωστό του στιλ και τη γνωστή του κυνική και ίσως πεσιμιστική ματιά απέναντι στους πάντες και τα πάντα κρίνει και κατακρίνει την παρακμή του Δυτικού ανθρώπου, αλλά παράλληλα μου φάνηκε πιο ανθρώπινος, πιο προσιτός, κατάφερα και διέκρινα μια χαραμάδα ελπίδας, μια ακτίνα φωτός μέσα σε όλο το σκοτάδι. Ο Ουελμπέκ με καθήλωσε από την πρώτη μέχρι και την τελευταία σελίδα και με έκανε να διαβάζω το βιβλίο σαν θρίλερ, αν και σίγουρα οι ρυθμοί ανάγνωσης πρέπει να είναι πιο ήρεμοι, πιο αργοί, για πλήρη κατανόηση του τρόπου σκέψης του και όλων αυτών των θεμάτων που αγγίζει με την πένα του. Ναι, την λάτρεψα την Εκμηδένιση, με έβαλε σε σκέψεις, μου χάρισε εικόνες και συναισθήματα, και σίγουρα θα μου λείψει...

L’economia è diventata il sottoprodotto della tecnologiaSe alcuni fatti sono inaccurati, non è dovuto solo a eventuali errori da parte mia, ma soprattutto a distorsioni volontarie della realtà. Dopotutto questo è un romanzo, la realtà è solo un materiale di partenzaParto dalla nota finale presente nei ringraziamenti perché mi ricorda qualcosa di simile scritto da Marías, sul fatto che i romanzi aiuterebbero ad esplorare le possibilità di vita che non si sono concretizzate, ciò che avrebbe potuto essere, secondo lo spagnolo, è importante quasi quanto ciò che è stato.Sempre nei ringraziamenti è presente un altro punto cruciale:Se scrivo che Astrid Nielsen si prende cura di suo marito con coraggio, non sarà contenta; quindi non lo scriverò, ma ne approfitto per dirle un’altra cosa, che non ho osato dirle a voce: è stato mentre tornavo di notte alla stazione di Thionville, dopo la giornata trascorsa a casa sua, che ho sentito per la prima volta che, qualunque cosa accadesse, dovevo portare a termine questo libroQuale libro? Quello che finisce con la sezione 5 o quello che inizia con la sezione 6? C’è un disegno enigmatico a carboncino che precede la sezione, pare raffigurare una coda. La coda di questo romanzo, per quanto triste è la sua parte migliore, ci consegna un Houellebecq diverso dal solito, meno amaro, meno cinico, per quanto sempre lucido. Se avete cinquant’anni la possibilità che esplora vi sembrerà tutt’altro che remota, è probabile che vi rivediate a leggere un referto in una mattinata soleggiata o in una serata umida. Le parole sono importanti, anche quelle nebulose del linguaggio medico, codificate in un modo che disorienta il paziente di per sé intimorito.Quella che a me è sembrata una coda è comunque ben saldata al corpo della narrazione, ancora una volta (marchio di fabbrica di Houellebecq) posticipata di qualche anno rispetto al presente. I fatti si svolgono fra la fine dell’anno 2026 e l’inizio del 2027, con la Francia in campagna elettorale per le presidenziali. Houellebecq è sempre prodigo di riferimenti alla cultura francese, quando invece che storici sono di cronaca, si fa un po’ più di fatica a seguirli, si può trovare per esempio l’accenno ad un ignoto conduttore tv, o ad un giornale indipendente. La Francia però è membro a pieno titolo del blocco occidentale di cui anche il nostro paese fa parte, dunque le disquisizioni sul capitalismo, l’immigrazione, il terrorismo non risentono della francesità e si fanno leggere con interesse. In questo romanzo Houellebecq interseca alle vicende di Paul Raison e della sua famiglia a quelle di un disegno terroristico che vorrebbe annientare il mondo tecnologico in cui stiamo vivendo, servendosi proprio della tecnologia. Sono presenti i canoni del thriller, quelli della spy story, vi sono inserti filosofici, letterari psicanalitici (i sogni di Paul Raison, mai banali, assurdi in modo controllato, indirizzato, sono la cosa che mi è piaciuta meno del libro). È un’opera ambiziosa e ben scritta, che con le sue 550 pagine supera il cabotaggio medio delle opere di Houellebecq (attestato intorno alle 250) senza mai far pensare che una sforbiciata sarebbe stata proficua. Dubito che il 2022 letterario ci offrirà un romanzo migliore di questo, io però avevo già apprezzato L’estensione, Serotonina, Sottomissione e Piattaforma, dovete chiedere anche a qualcuno meno schierato.Ho trovato interessante questo articolo in merito ad una frase che anch’io avevo faticato ad interpretare [l’articolo contiene SPOILER]https://www.totalitarismo.blog/michel... Annientata Effettivamente capisco, a lettura ultimata, come si possa pensare che questo romanzo non sia frutto della stessa penna che ha concepito Le particelle elementari , Sottommissione  o anche Seratonina .C'è una mestizia dolce che pervade l'intero romanzo, una dolcezza e una malinconia mai trovate tra le pagine di MH che, straordinariamente, a mio parere funzionano benissimo.Come ha detto chi mi ha preceduto, il romanzo è pure scritto benissimo, e i temi che affronta risultano essere straordinariamente attuali per chi, come il protagonista, ha il cinque ( o un numero maggiore di cinque) nelle decine dell'età - difficile essere passati indenni dalla perdita o dalla malattia, da una delusione d'amore o da un sentimento d'amore che ha retto nonostante la brutalità della vita.Tante le frasi che ho sottolineato tanti i pensieri su cui mi sono fermata. “Alla fine, ci gettano un po’ di terra sulla testa, ed è finita per sempre.”

«Εν προκειμένω, σχιζοφρενική ήταν η πραγματικότητα»Και αυτό που νιώθω μένοντας πάλι χωρίς Ουελμπέκ:«Αυτό που δεν άντεχε, όπως είχε συνειδητοποιήσει ανήσυχος, ήταν η ίδια η παροδικότητα, η ιδέα ότι κάτι, οτιδήποτε, τελειώνει· αυτό που δεν άντεχε δεν ήταν παρά μία από τις βασικές συνθήκες της ζωής.»
Η πιο ρομαντική πλευρά του Ουελμπέκ. Καλύτερο από την Σεροτονίνη, χωρίς βέβαια να φτάνει το ύψος του Χάρτη, της Δυνατότητας και των Σωματιδίων.
Μας ισοπέδωσε ο Μισελ, έργο ωριμότητας, βαθιά συναισθηματικό χωρίς να χάνεται και η καυστική κριτική της δυτικής μας πραγματικότητας.

Lascio l’esegesi del testo agli specialisti houellebecquiani, che già si stanno affannando (è meno lui? è sempre lui? si è imborghesito? è diventato buono? è diventato solo meno provocatorio e più perfido - e questo libro è in realtà una trappola a trabocchetto? il matrimonio lo ha reso romantico? oppure gli ha solo messo le pantofole ai neuroni? o invece ci sta prendendo tutti perculo, giocando a spiazzarci? è più o meno profetico? è più o meno disperato? eccetera eccetera). Dico solo (e non è poco) che per tanti aspetti, per un certo umore di fondo soprattutto e per l’angolo visuale dal quale si guarda il mondo che c'è fuori, mi ci sono sentito tristemente, dolorosamente, ma anche dolcemente in sintonia. E confesso che la cosa mi ha sorpreso e un po' spaventato. Bisognerà che me lo rumini bene. Al di là delle interpretazioni e senza pretendere di dover pensare al capolavoro, è un romanzo da leggere perché è scritto benissimo, come al solito. E al di là dell’apparente affastellarsi di temi e scenari l’architettura tiene e funziona. Poi, come tutti i romanzi scritti bene, crea un ambiente, un mondo, con i suoi umori, sentimenti, colori.A tratti andando avanti nelle pagine e in quelle atmosfere ovattate, tra ospedali, RSA, case grandi e silenziose, boschi autunnali e lungofiumi nebbiosi ci si sporge pericolosamente verso un accenno di noia, di quasi assopimento. Il pilota automatico si affaccia a proporsi: “vado avanti io?”. La lunghezza del libro e la mancanza di certi eccessi di furori acidi e scorrettissimi, a cui Hb ci aveva abituati, accentua la percezione di un calo di tensione. Ma dura poco. I capitoli brevi, gli incastri degli diversi scenari e una frasetta giusta che improvvisamente illumina tutto un panorama mentale, rompono la monotonia. Al pilota si risponde “lascia stare, che questa è roba che mi riguarda”. E così si torna alla tensione di lettura giusta. Forse proprio in quel vago senso di noia morbidosa (e nel primo sogno nella casa del padre), sta nascosto il segreto di questo romanzo.Tirando le somme. Come ho sempre detto, parlando dei libri di Houellebecq: ad avercene, di romanzi come i suoi.

Attesissimo, il 2022 comincerà nel segno di Michel Houellebecq. Annientare, il suo nono romanzo, sarà pubblicato il 7 gennaio da La Nave di Teseo (tr. Milena Zemira Ciccimarra), in contemporanea con l’uscita sugli scaffali francesi. Diciamolo subito e senza indugi: Annientare è un grande libro, in cui lo scrittore francese 65enne - l’autore di Piattaforma (2001), Sottomissione (2015) e Serotonina (2019) - si conferma una delle voci più importanti sulla scena narrativa internazionale, capace di cogliere le istanze nichiliste che devastano la società e la crisi della civiltà liberale che si frantuma contro i dogmi religiosi dei fanatismi. Annientamento è la parola d’ordine del futuro cui stiamo andando incontro e Houellebecq, coerente al proprio pensiero, lo conferma sin dal suo esordio nel 1994, con Estensione del dominio della lotta. Nel nuovo romanzo la scena si apre in Francia, negli ultimi giorni del 2026. La nazione transalpina sta vivendo un prepotente riscatto economico che le permette di sopravanzare la Germania nel mercato automobilistico, sfidando apertamente la Cina nell’approvvigionamento delle materie prime, grazie all’impeto di Bruno Juge, il Ministro dell’Economia. Al suo fianco, ecco il protagonista assoluto, Paul Raison, stretto collaboratore, confidente di Juge che affiancherà nella sua corsa alle presidenziali francesi del 2027 (in ticket con un presentatore tv, un burattino ammaliato dal prestigio) rendendo l’Eliseo, il potere politico e la sua percezione sociale ai giorni nostri, come uno dei perni del romanzo.Oscillando fra pubblico e privato, scopriamo presto che Paul, in crisi con sua moglie Prudence (immaginata nella copertina, «come fonte di luce e resistenza» nelle parole della Sgarbi), correrà al capezzale del padre, colpito da una ischemia cerebrale; ciò ricongiungerà i tre figli aprendo degli spaccati sulle loro esistenze, dalla grande fede di Cécile alla mesta vita del terzogenito, Aurélien, impelagato in un burrascoso matrimonio. Ma l’attualità politica è un filo conduttore e alzando lo sguardo dalle quotidiane battaglie dei suoi personaggi, Houellebecq segue le vicende di una minaccia hacker globale, una forza entropica che potrebbe sconvolgere le basi della società civile, con un susseguirsi di attentati a navi portacontainer e banche di liquido seminale, accompagnati da video-messaggi in cui ricorrono pentacoli, richiami al Diavolo e alla magia nera, sconcertando le forze di pubblica sicurezza per l’assenza di rivendicazioni.Non fatevi spaventare dalle 746 pagine, Annientare ha un narratore in terza e una prosa sempre fluida anche capace di far sorridere, alternando lo scenario internazionale con un ristretto nucleo di personaggi, mescolando lutto e desiderio, ambizione e innamoramento, mostrando l’incapacità della razza umana di comunicare, una sorta di inadeguatezza alla felicità che conduce verso il suo annichilimento. Ciò diventa evidente quando l’autore narra il destino degli anziani nelle Rsa, preda del lucido razionalismo del sistema sanitario, sfociando nella sorte di Paul, con una forte svolta intimista nel suo sguardo che azzera la distanza dalla pagina.Annientare è un romanzo duro e cupo eppure colmo di bellezza, tramite il quale il suo autore conferma il proprio estro, sempre capace di infilare considerazioni nichiliste sul senso della vita, incastonando pensieri misantrope e misogini con una naturalezza unica, senza giri di parole, senza sensi di colpa, senza farla tanto lunga, insomma. Ciò dona al lettore una chiarezza attesa, una voce chiara da seguire dalla prima all’ultima pagina. Ammettiamolo, sembra dire l’autore, pensiamo alla morte e al sesso nel corso delle giornate e riuscire a far coesistere la complessità umana sulla pagina, i pensieri nobili e quelli gretti, è una dimostrazione di stile.Houellebecq osa e sfida i nostri tabù - sessuali e religiosi - riuscendo a cogliere le istanze in arrivo. Non a caso è considerato uno scrittore profetico: è accaduto con Sottomissione, intuendo l’islamizzazione della Francia mentre in Serotonina narrava l’avvento dei gilet gialli e d’una protesta dal basso e violenta. Accade anche in Annientare: gli attentati internazionali e gli hacker scuotono la Francia, «la democrazia è morta come sistema, troppo lenta, troppo pesante», ormai svuotata di significato, ferita a morte dallo svilimento dell'informazione a vantaggio dei social media. Accadrà? Houellebecq ci invita ad aprire gli occhi: sta già accadendo e non solo in Francia.Profetico o meno, lo scrittore francese che riempie i teatri con le sue poesie, omaggia Lovecraft e rilegge la Commedia di Balzac, inevitabilmente ci costringe a notare che in Italia non mancano certo le voci di talento, semmai, sembriamo aver smarrito l'ambizione di voler scrivere un romanzo internazionale, una storia che sfidi il mercato e vada oltre la commedia, i commissari di quartiere e i consueti schemi da dramma familiare che rassicurano ma annoiano perché zeppi di cliché. Nessuno come Houellebecq è capace di titillare le nostre paure, facendosi e si fa beffe di chi, un libro dopo l’altro, lo accusa inutilmente di machismo. Pur se avulso dal circo dei social è sempre capace di polarizzare l'attenzione mondiale dei media, basti ricordare che Emmanuel Carrère lo omaggia apertamente. Houellebecq dimostra che un vero scrittore deve “semplicemente" scrivere. Senza paura, illuminando la tenebra che ci circonda. Il resto, è rumore di fondo. Annientamento.

Mi ci è voluto un po' di tempo, ce ne vorrà ancora, per metabolizzare un romanzo come questo. H. è il solito mostro, anche se cambia stile, se scrive un libro lontano dai suoi precedenti, se ha troppe pagine in più, se il cinismo viene mitigato dall'età e forse dalla comprensione dell'amore, se mai fosse possibile.È un libro spiazzante, che mischia la politica alla tragedia personale, il mondo fuori con quello contro cui dobbiamo inciampare ogni giorno dentro di noi. Le ultime 50 pagine di una difficoltà personale estenuante. È che invecchiare fa mediamente schifo, e ognuno di noi si aggrappa dove può, dove sa ma il più delle volte non basta e la scelta di come andare avanti diventa estremamente complessa.Ho quasi 50 anni, e la malattia, la morte, la paura, lo strazio sono toccati a me come quasi a tutti i miei coetanei, poi certo, devi essere H. per saper scrivere così anche quando la prosa, come in questo caso, è semplice, al servizio della trama, piegata al volerti trascinare tutto sommato facilmente per 700 pagine, perché vuoi sapere quale sarà la sorte del protagonista. Ho letto H. migliori, Serotonina mi ha fatto gridare al capolavoro, quando non ho certo urlato. Ma penso a questo libro ininterrottamente da una settimana e credo questo basti a renderlo un libro notevole, uno di quelli da mettere in libreria e guardare ogni tanto con rimpianto.Ho brindato alla difficoltà della vita, nonostante tutto, con un Valpolicella corposo che mi ha riappacificato con i ricordi e spinto alla riflessioni come solo i rossi eccellenti sanno fare. Leggetelo, che la vita non va sempre bene.
Nur sehr ungern lese ich Romane, in denen es hauptsächlichum Krankheiten geht.Aber Houellebecq zieht hier alle Register und überzeugt wiederum durch seine Radikalität.
