There is a Hebrew saying that "if you seek revenge, build a grave for two." When Don Winslow writes of revenge, gravediggers are lined up for miles awaiting the assignment they know will come to them shortly.The Power of the Dog is modern day Bleak House, with characters so well developed and plots so sizzling and well-written that the book grips you from the start and only a late hour that cannot be ignored forces the reader to stop.The scenes are rivetting for 500 pages, and well edited, with near perfect grammar, like this:"Adan sees them coming and gets up to head for the back, slips and falls, gets back up again,and when he does a federale points a rifle in his face and smiles, and Adan is dead, except the federale's smile disappears in a whirl of blood and Adan feels someone grab his wrist and pull him down and then he's in the water on the floor, face to face with a Yanqui who says, "Get down, asshole. . . Adan glances down at the dead federale, and to his horror, sees that the crabs have already scuttled over his feet at the gaping hole where the cop's face used to be."Winslow's plots are complicated, and the reader never really knows who's good and who's not, and so a reader finds himself making constant comparisons in these life and death struggles which occur frequently. He writes about the evil of the drug wars and the US government plots to disarm regimes it doesn't like, undertaken without the support of the law and certainly without the support of the people.Each of Winslow's characters struggle with an evil side, and with decisions--some small, some not--that reject moral boudaries and where some struggle until the end of the book to make up for the evil they've created. Even Art Keller, the central figure, who we want to believe is a good man is not. As Winslow makes it clear in all his works, if you are determined to eradicate evil, you become evil yourself. It is only Father Juan who escapes this, and to some extent, Nora, the high end escort, who loves Father Juan unequivocally in a platonic sense, who seem to escape judgment, although Nora has her moments when she, too, is unlovable and evil. Winslow manages, though, to keep us in constant search of redemption, and, in a meaningful way, this work has a deeply spiritual message. It also keeps the struggle between good and evil front and center.Winslow's work is so well researched that the fictions become believable. In my view, he has it all as a writer. Not to mention moral compass. When you seek revenge, dig a grave for two. Revenge, the power of the dog, the enemy of goodness everywhere.

Glaubt man der Kritik ist „The Power of the Dog“ Don Winslows Meisterwerk, auf dem Rückseite werden gar Vergleiche mit „Krieg und Frieden“ herangezogen. Nun ist dies mein erster Winslow, eine Einordnung in sein Gesamtwerk kann ich also nicht bieten, aber ein Meisterwerk ist dieser Roman für mich eindeutig nicht, auch habe ich gute Gründe anzunehmen dass einige seiner weniger umfangreichen Werke durchaus besser sein könnten. Was nicht heißen soll dass „Tage der Toten“ ein schlechtes Buch ist, ganz und gar nicht, tatsächlich ist es sogar richtig gut: Es ist über weite Strecken wirklich spannend, sehr gründlich recherchiert, und bietet einen umfangreichen Überblick über den Amerikanisch-Mexikanischen-Drogenkrieg zwischen 1975 und 1998 in Verbindung mit Politik, CIA, der kolumbianischen FARC und vieles, vieles mehr. Und genau da beginnen für mich auch schon die Probleme: Winslow hat unglaublich viele Fakten zusammengetragen und war offensichtlichen von dem Wunsch getrieben sie möglichst alle unterzubringen, was leider dazu geführt hat dass man sich in vielen Kapiteln eher vorkommt als würde man ein Sachbuch lesen und keinen Roman. Zugegeben, ein durchaus interessantes Sachbuch, aber viel zu oft wird sichtbar gewollt eine Verbindung zur Handlung oder einen der beteiligten (sehr vielen) Charakteren konstruiert, nur um dann eine seitenlange Geschichtsstunde abzuhalten. Das kann man so machen, aber übermäßig geschickt wirken diese Passagen nicht in den Roman eingeflochten. Daher vermute ich sehr stark dass Winslows andere, kürzere Werke, in denen er einfach nur eine spannende Geschichte erzählt zumindest mir deutlich besser gefallen könnten. Denn spannend schreiben kann er! Die andere große Schwäche sind leider die Charaktere. Es sind einfach zu viele, und die meisten davon bleiben bis zum Schluss ziemlich eindimensional (wenn ich mich selbst auf Seite 400 zunächst nicht erinnern kann wer eine bestimmte Person jetzt eigentlich noch war, ist das kein gutes Zeichen …). Die vier zentralen Hauptcharaktere haben mir am Ende aber deutlich vor Augen gestanden, ein weiteres Indiz dafür dass der Autor sich mit der Komplexität der Materie ein wenig übernommen hat. Da das Buch aber nahezu überall auf einhellige Begeisterung stößt scheine ich das alles ein wenig zu kritisch zu sehen und würde daher auch niemandem abraten „Tage der Toten“ zu lesen. Einen spannenden Thriller bekommt man allemal, und zwischendurch etwas zu lernen hat schließlich auch noch nie geschadet … 3,5 Sterne

Gritty. Don Winslow knows how to do "gritty," and The Power Of The Dog is that, and more. Intense; Epic; Sweeping. Sure, I could add adjectives, but you get the picture.I've read "The King Of Cool" and thought this was superior. If there is any complaint I had, it was the length. This is a mighty lengthy book and at times, I thought, one that could have been trimmed a bit. Nevertheless, if you're willing to maintain focus and keep characters straight, the pay-off is worth the ride.A historical fiction about the Narcotrafficantes in Mexico, the DEA's "war on drugs" and the futility therein-- that's the overview of what this is about. But the real beauty of this work isn't this tried and true plot concept. Rather, the beauty of Winslow's writing lies in his characters:DEA agent Art Keller is determined to bring down the Barrera brothers and their drug empire. He becomes obsessed with the family when he loses a fellow agent to them, and vows vengeance, at any and all costs. Adán and Raul Barrera are studies in opposites, one cerebral, the other cruel in his physicality. Both bring something to the table and rise in power to essentially rule the Mexican channel for drugs into the U.S. Nora Hayden is a stunningly beautiful teenager who becomes a high-class hooker and ultimately plays an essential role in the story. She is jaded beyond the pale, yet harbors an abiding love for:Father Parada, an incorruptible Catholic priest who gains power in order to do good for the people. And we meet an Irish kid named Callan, who becomes a very feared and skilled mob hitman in NYC, but manages to become involved in the story unfolding in Mexico nonetheless.An unusual group of main characters, whom WInslow binds together in the woven fabric of Mexico's drug world. The story will take you from the streets of New York City to Mexico City and Tijuana to the jungles of Central America, and you'll learn more than you ever wanted about covert operations, back-door political deals, the "war on drugs" and the real, gritty world of international drug trade, power, money, and mayhem. The book can feel slow at times, but the ending gains speed and intensity and will keep you turning pages well into the night.

This is a long book, but the length (as Jane Smiley writes about in 13 Ways of Looking at the Novel) is a promise, not a threat.The action is quick, the tension is high and the conflict is believable. There are neither purely good guys, nor completely evil bad guys. It seems like Winslow covered everything from family to feigned friendship, from faith to agnosticism, from obsession to oppression. The War on Drugs plays a major role in this novel, as does the U.S.'s use of that travesty and failure to maintain a large distance from Communist countries: in other words, to keep them from moving in right next door. Winslow's characters are both likeable and not. Some, I wanted to side with initially, only to rethink my loyalty later. It really is a great ride through the psychology of trying to reach a goal that may be, when all is said and done, unobtainable: e.g. the War on Drugs. It's like a war against dirt, it is never-ending and demands constant vigilance (which, if truth be told, is a waste of time, i.e. dirt will win). I'm not making a judgment on drugs (or on dirt, for that matter), but on the ways in which the U.S. has "tried" to stop the flow of those drugs. Billions of dollars have been spent, and many of those billions have ended up in the pockets of the heads of the very drug cartels that were the targets of this fiasco called a war.Winslow does an excellent job of presenting the history necessary to tell his story without dragging in so much as to make it a boring read. He uses what is necessary, leaves out what isn't. At the very least, this novel has made me think about the U.S. relations with our neighbors to the south in North, Central and South America. Was the War on Drugs really just a way for the U.S. to keep Communists from moving in right next door? Did the U.S. supply anti-communist fighters, who also happened to be part of the huge flow of drugs into and money out of the U.S.? Will you read this book and wrestle with your own questions about these issues? That's all I can suggest: read it.

C’erano una volta l’America e il MessicoSergio Leone mi è venuto in mente soprattutto mentre leggevo l'ultima sfida al rallentatore che (a parte un breve post-finale) chiude questo potente romanzo: pare quasi di sentire le note di Morricone mentre l'inquadratura passa da un personaggio all'altro, ognuno col suo pesante passato imbrattato di sangue, con il suo odio incomprimibile, con la mente tesa all'imminente estremo tradimento che molti dei sette personaggi (gli unici sopravvissuti...) che compongono questa "Resa dei conti" stanno meditando per far concludere le cose diversamente dai patti ("patti" che mai sono stati tanto trasgrediti come in questa storia).Questo approccio è alquanto diverso dal modo che sono solito adottare per valutare un romanzo: perchè "Il potere del cane" è il classico libro per il quale occorre lasciare da parte l'analisi razionale e lasciarsi trasportare dall'impatto emotivo.Razionalmente è infatti un romanzo tutt'altro che privo di difetti: un debito ellroyano innegabile soprattutto nei contenuti senza la capacità di eguagliare lo stile del grande J.E., una componente melodrammatica a volte sovradosata, un carico di eventi forse eccessivo e di fatto estenuante.Però il romanzo possiede una forza emotiva straordinaria e soprattutto un ritmo in crescente accelerazione (soprattutto nell'ultimo quarto è impossibile per il lettore di tirare il fiato) man mano che lascia dietro di sè una scia ininterrotta di sangue e di crudeltà, che (a quanto riesco a ricordare) non ha eguali almeno nella narrativa recente.Pur in un'analisi dettata più dal cuore che dal cervello, è impossibile tralasciare il notevole talento con cui l'autore ha incastrato le vicende dei suoi disperati personaggi nel più ampio panorama dei rapporti fra il narcotraffico e la storia politica ed economica degli USA, del Messico e del continente americano intero. Il potere del cane, appunto.

This is a well written plot driven book. The characters do not feel like walking stereotypes, but they also aren't... fully rounded. It really bothers me that Bishop Romero is assassinated in Guatemala (not El Salvador). According to the LA Times, Don Winslow spent 6 years researching his next book, The Cartel. The research process is described as immersing himself in the pornography of violence (see the article) found on the internet. Okay, so he is very meticulous about getting the violence right, but not so much the history. What I don't understand is - even if he didn't catch the mistake of Bishop Romero's assassination, shouldn't the publisher correct it? While reading this book, my opinion fluctuated between 2 and 4 stars. 4 - it's a well written thriller 3 - bec. it's a story that I've read before 2 - it ultimately romanticizes the narco trade without taking the story in a new direction or adding depth to the conversation. Final Thoughts - (view spoiler)[Basically - DEA agents that won't play the game will suffer (mildly) at the hands of their superiors. Not exactly new territory here.  (hide spoiler)]Ultimately, I went with 2 stars. Getting the violence, but not the history right puts emotions over facts, while failing to tell a meaningful story about the drug trade. Did I mention getting Bishop Romero's assassination wrong really bothers me?

The Power of the Dog es una novela coral que habla sobre el tráfico de drogas proviniente de Méjico que llega a los Estados Unidos. Es una novela con varios puntos de vista, algunos más interesantes que otros, pero todos con relevancia en el transcurso de la novela.Claramente Winslow se ha documentado exhaustivamente sobre la historia de Méjico, Perú, Colombia y otros países latinoamericanos y también sobre la historia de la DEA, que juega un papel importante en la novela.Es una novela muy larga. Demasiado larga. Este problema de paginitis no se debe a un exceso de infodumps sobre las circunstancias socioeconómicas o la historia de los países y organizaciones involucradas. Tiene demasiadas páginas porque Winslow ha metido demasiado en la novela. Hay mucho movimiento circular y, sin desvelar nada, a veces se hace un tanto repetitiva esta acción.Los personajes centrales están correctamente caracterizados, pero el agente de la DEA o el cura me han resultado un tanto estridentes. Bastante mejor personaje es Nora, la prostituta, a pesar de que inicialmente no generaba mucho interés.Quizás hubiera sido una novela que jamás hubiese leído de no ser por el audiolibro. El lector ha sido, sin duda alguna, lo mejor de la novela. La capacidad camaleónica para adoptar voces, acentos, dejes y demás me ha hecho dudar más de una vez que fuese un solo hombre. Increíble.No sé si me animaré con The Cartel, la última novela de Winslow. Esta no estaba mal pero me parece que estoy un poco saturado del tema para una temporada.

I rank this novel up there with some good, but not great, books that made fantastic movies, like The Godfather or The Right Stuff, so I hope a movie adaptation is coming soon. The story is tied piano-wire tight and the action scenes fly off the page. Winslow is strong on plot, without a doubt, and he clearly has intimate knowledge of the drug trade, narco culture, and the seamy underside of the U.S. "War on Drugs." He is less adept with character development and prose style, though it seems just as likely that he has thrown such niceties to the wind, or the dog, as it were. Pretty prose might be more of a liability than an asset when describing the carnage that the cartels and drug wars have reaped. But character development is never dispensable in fiction, and here the characters lack originality, or spark, or... something. The cop who ruins his family in a ruthless pursuit of justice and revenge. Street kids fashioned into mini-mobsters. The hooker with a heart of gold. A whiskey priest (except he chain smokes instead.) It was a bit much when the hooker hooked up with the priest, but I kept reading because I had to find out what happened next. And that's where Winslow gets ya... But I'm still pulling for the movie version.

Il n'est pas surprenant de voir l'immense James Ellroy encenser "la Griffe du Chien" tant son ombre plane avec insistance sur tout le livre de Don Winslow. Car avec ce roman choral aux ramifications tentaculaires, l'auteur New yorkais se place en digne héritier d'Ellroy et plus particulièrement de sa trilogie Underwolrd USA. Avec La griffe du chien, Winslow brasse pas moins de 3 décennies de "guerre contre la drogue" en variant les points de vue avec une constante, la frontière : physique, entre différents pays, morale entre le bien et le mal et toujours aussi ténue, aussi insaisissable... Tout comme Ellroy, il imbrique avec finesse faits historiques et fiction, tant et si bien qu'on ne sait plus ce qui est vrai et ce qui l'est moins et tout comme Ellroy, il remise sa naïveté au placard et n'hésite pas à mettre le nez des USA dans sa propre merde notamment en rappelant tout un pan de sa politique nauséabonde en Amérique centrale. Hélas (ou fort heureusement) n'est pas James Ellroy qui veut, et là où l'oeuvre de ce dernier est régulièrement traversée de fulgurances stylistiques saisissantes , la plume de Winslow est beaucoup plus directe là, paradoxalement plus légère compte tenu de la violence et de l'horreur (extrêmement bien documentée) qu'il décrit. Et c'est d'ailleurs tout à son honneur.

I have been intending to read Don Winslow for many years. Now I finally did and I am hooked. The Power of the Dog is the first of his three books about Mexican drug cartels. If you are curious about this scourge of criminality your curiosity will be entirely rewarded. It is a fairly long book but I read it in a little over three days. Winslow can do propulsive, addictive plot with the best of them.Art Keller, DEA agent, began with a loyal commitment to the US War of Drugs. His concurrent disillusionment with the agency and obsession with taking out the key family in Mexico's drug empire contribute equally to the demise of his marriage and his success in the mission he sets for himself.Just as in real life, the development, the evolution from pot to heroin to cocaine to crack is complex, driven by greed for wealth and power. The Power of the Dog could have been just another thriller about organized crime. In addition to his serious writing chops though, Winslow manages to convey the intricate intersections between the criminals, the law, and the citizens who dance around each other.He shows us the violence that is as big a part of life as the hopes and dreams of mankind. I was impressed and left with much to ponder.

Wow. Action packed thriller, packed with fascinating characters (all fictional), but set in the very real wars on drugs and terrorism the US has been fighting and financing for decades in Mexico and Central America. If you want some historical perspective on Trump's "caravans" of illegal immigrants heading to the US borders, but don't want to wade through a typical fact filled history book, this is for you. Just want a great thriller--this is also for you.The plot follows the intersecting stories of a DEA agent, the leader of one of the Mexican drug cartels, a high end sex worker, and a New York crime family as their lives become increasingly entangled, and they become obsessed with each other, in various ways and permutations.The action is non-stop, and every time you think the book has reached an apex, it takes an entirely different turn, and the tension again begins to build. I literally could not put it down for hours at a time, and stayed up way too late a couple of nights unable to stop until the words literally blurred before my eyes.Can't wait to start the second in the series.

An epic violent yarn. I'm not sure Winslow's book and the movie Savages can top this book which came first. Why didn't they make this into a movie or even a mini-series? Probably because it's so disturbing. If this were a movie it would be like The Godfather meets Scarface meets The Winds of War. So many different characters meeting each other over the course of two decades. It's about obsession and vengeance and once it's over you are left pondering if anything even changed. Was it worth it? I particularly enjoyed the familiar location of San Diego County but it's set in Colombia, El Salvador, Hong Kong, and Mexico as well. It's all about drugs and it mirrors historical events like the kidnapping and murder of a DEA agent, Iran Contra, El Salvador Civil War, and the assassination of the cardinal in Guadalajara as well as Mexican presidential candidate Luis Colosio. The body count is high and the moral calculus is Machiavellian with the intrigue. Art Keller, the DEA agent, is the central character and he is absolutely unrelenting in his quest to do the right thing and he pays dearly for it too. So many folks in the wrong place at the wrong time in this book.

Wat ... een ... trip! Don Winslow gooit je vanaf de openingsbladzijden snoeihard midden in de Amerikaanse War on drugs en sleurt je in een waanzinnig tempo meer dan 500 bladzijden lang genadeloos mee in die al even genade- als hopeloze strijd. Met drugsbestrijder Art Keller en de gebroeders en drugsbaronnen Adan & Raul Barrera als voornaamste protagonisten, vlecht Winslow een geloofwaardig, goed uitgewerkt en confronterend verhaal in elkaar en toont de lezer hoe politiek, opportunisme, geldgewin, kansloosheid en corruptie vanop het laagste tot het hoogste niveau het falen van die War on drugs orchestreren. Mexicaanse drugsbaronnen, Colombiaanse vrijheidsstrijders, communistische rebellen, CIA, Ierse criminelen, Italiaanse maffia, ... allen hebben ze hun vinger in de pap en boter op het hoofd, laat Winslow zien in een leestrip in hoog tempo die 3 decennia overspant, vol geloofwaardige, goed uitgewerkte personages, met oog voor detail en een spanningsboog die nooit minder dan strak gespannen staat.Straf. Heel straf.Met The Cartel & The Border schreef Don Winslow nog twee sequels, die hoogstwaarschijnlijk ook op ons nachtkastje zullen belanden.

Os recomiendo mucho que os leáis "EL PODER DEL PERRO" de Don Winslow. El libro engancha y no quieres parar de leer intentando averiguar los hechos que se van sucediendo y los numerosos personajes que aparecen. Me ha sorprendido gratamente. Drogas y geopolítica. Un libro de los que no te dejan indiferente.

This is the first book in a three part trilogy which is important to read in the order it was written as it begins a narrative plot that unfolds over the three volumes. It is the violent and very disturbing story of the war on drugs, the one we have been fighting for many years and never win. These three novels explain the many reasons why despite millions of dollars spent, things never change. There are too many people making money, too many politicians taking advantage of the situation to meet their own ends and no sensible, cohesive and well-coordinated plan among the many competing agencies tasked with solving the problem. All the efforts made are time limited, affected by whatever officials and political party is in power, how well the agencies tasked with the mandate share information and work together and how well the justice system cooperates to charge those who are guilty, take them to trial and incarcerate those guilty for the prison terms for which they were sentenced. This story, which evolves over decades, reveals the amount of corruption, deal making and subterfuge that exist at all levels in government, the justice system and the military that ensures the war is never won. It is too profitable for too many people. So they dabble at the edges with code named operations that may achieve some small success, but whatever parts of the system that grows, transports and distributes drugs is affected by their efforts, is soon put back in operation. If a drug leader is captured, the vacuum created is quickly filled with someone ready to take the positions of the one who fell. The drug business is a dangerous game, but its allure so great and the profits so large that thousands are ready to risk their lives to be a part of it, especially those who are poor and have little to look forward to in life. This story begins in the 1970s and ends in May of 2004, played out against the background of cocaine trafficked through what is known as the “Mexican Trampoline”, the route from Mendellin to Honduras to Mexico and then to the States. There are three separate plot lines beginning in different geographical locations that ultimately converge in Mexico. Special Agent Art Keller is with the DEA, a former CIA operative and a veteran of Vietnam who took part in the takedown of the Vietcong leadership. During that tour he saw much he wishes he hadn’t and has since tried to forget but many ugly things remain stuck in his memory. Keller is half Mexican and half American. He grew up in a barrio in San Diego, saw what drugs did to the people in his neighborhood and is determined to help get them off the street. The combination of his American citizenship and his fluency in Spanish has landed him on assignment in Culiacán Mexico where he ends up in a difficult relationship with his boss Tim Taylor. He ultimately aligns himself with Miguel Angel Barrera (AKA Tio), an influential officer with the Mexican Sinaloa State Police and the two work together to burn the poppy fields of the reigning drug lord Don Pedro Aviles (El Patron). It is only later that Keller realizes that Tio Barrera had used him to eradicate his opposition in the drug world and laid a clear path to replace Don Pedro as the head of the Federation. He ruthlessly eradicates his competition and uses his nephews Adan and Raul to help maintain control over his empire. The cousins are very different, Adan is the studious business man comfortable with numbers and Raul the ruthless one who recruits the kids off the streets, settles scores with violence and keeps everyone in line. It is not long before Tio Barrera is a powerful, wealthy man, feared by everyone.Sean Callan, a poor Irish teenager living in Hell’s Kitchen in New York City is forced to kill a thug who threatened his best friend and Callan is now a teenage killer on the run. He carries out a number of brutal killings, evolves into a stone cold hit man and aligns himself with the mob. The names of his buddies are classic names that draw a smile, names like Big Peaches, Little Peaches, Johnny Boy and Big Paulie. Callan eventually ends up doing contract assassinations for both the Barreras and the U.S. government. Nora Hayden is a beautiful and intelligent woman from California who has learned how to use her body to get what she wants from men. She is recruited by Hayley Saxon an ambitious woman who is building up her business as a madam with a client base that targets rich and powerful men. Hayley has taught Nora all she needs to know to be a high class call girl and Nora saves her money, keeps in shape and enjoys living her life servicing men who would do almost anything to sample her charms. Hayley supplies girls for both the Barreras and the mob and thus a plot path is created to connect Adan Barrera, Art Keller and Sean Callan. Hayley becomes Adan Barrera’s mistress while at the same time, after years of having men use her, develops a platonic relationship with Archbishop Juan Parada, a man who tries his best to support the poor in Mexico. Keller tries to exploit her affection for Parada to get at the Berraras. Although this is a novel of fiction, readers will recognize many references to actual people and events. Some have different names but their identity is blatantly obvious. Winslow's descriptions of the drug trafficking world also prove authentic. He describes how drug lords protect their profits and their way of life through torture, mass executions, bribery and corruption. His lays out how the Mexican cartels, the New York mafia, the CIA, DEA, prostitutes and hired killers all form a vast network that provides the foundation for drug trafficking. He spells out the duplicitous relationship between the cartels and the police and how these corrupt entities support and fuel each other’s activities. And he lays out with shocking clarity how the drug wars have become linked with covert efforts to halt the spread of communism in Latin America as one government agency’s efforts are nullified by another. The DEA’s efforts are sabotaged by CIA operations in South America as the US government secretly provides Contra rebels with training and support, helps them smuggle guns and drugs to finance their work and ultimately helps the cartels deliver drugs across the border to America.Winslow does not skimp on sharing the shocking torture and violence that are a part of the drug world and how thugs cut off limbs, behead their enemies and slaughter entire families. These gory atrocities are not just payback for perceived wrongs. The mutilated dead bodies are left on public display and are an important way the narcos control their enemies and the local population.This novel is big (over 550 pages) and has a large cast of characters. Although some have only a short time on these pages, each has a distinct personality. It is a challenge to keep track of them all especially with their Spanish names and nicknames. This story can be complicated to follow at times, but presents a piece of realistic fiction that reveals the absolute absurdity of the war on drugs. The story moves between moments of shocking revelations, to moments of terror, sadness and grief, but it all combines to take readers on a terrific ride.

"Art can’t decide whether the War on Drugs is an obscene absurdity or an absurd obscenity. In either case, it’s a tragic, bloody farce."
Apologies to everyone who loved this, but when a book takes me two months to read, I just can't say that I liked this very much. I was daydreaming one day, getting all reminiscent of the trivial, but on second guess very enjoyable Boone Daniels books – thoughts of which led me to believe that I should read more by Don Winslow.  In theory, this is a wild ride: This novel throws you right into a world of betrayal and corruption, from New York and Mexico City over to the jungles of Central America. We meet broken and messed-up characters, from a high-class hooker to an obsessive DEA agent over to a powerful Catholic priest. Turns out I just don't care about money and drugs that much. I can't blame Winslow for this. The tone, the narration, the characters – all that felt in line with the world depicted. Everything felt violent, dangerous, calculated. In a way, it's easy to compare with a high-budget action thriller: it's a wild ride, it's a fast one, too, but then they never really stick to your memory, do they? (At least not in mine, but again, high-budget action thriller are also not my favourite genre when it comes to films).There's also a side to this book that makes you think. When you're not busy jumping from one brutal scene to the next, you've got some time to think about how far this actually derives from the real-world War on Drugs that the US government has been campaigning for for decades now. Winslow uses this as an opportunity to comment on the situation, even though I'm not entirely sure what he's criticising? Occasionally it felt like it wasn't the actual drug use he has a problem with, but the interdiction. But this is a problem that will have to find another platform to be discussed.

Scampami dalla spada e dal potere del caneTendenzialmente non è il mio genere letterario, non amo i libri d'azione e/o i thriller, ma ho visto diversi documentari sul narcotraffico messicano, più le bellissime serie Netflix Narcos e Narcos Mexico e così, invogliato dal tema trattato, mi sono buttato.Lo stile di scrittura è come me l'aspettavo, niente di elaborato, niente di rimarcabile, ma lo sviluppo narrativo è un vortice che ti trascina dentro e non ti lascia più andare fino all'ultima fottuta pagina! Per altro il romanzo è di fantasia ma nemmeno tanto ... molti dei personaggi riprendono per caratteristiche e per azioni compiute le gesta dei vari Amado Carrillo o El Chapo, passando dai Pablo Escobar ai Pacho Herrera, insomma un mix sapiente di realtà e invenzione veramente coinvolgente. E quindi in definitiva mi ha catturato e porca puttana mi toccherà leggere pure gli altri 2 romanzi ....Nessun messicano riesce ancora a spiegarsi perchè in America lo spaccio di pochi panetti di marijuana sia punito più duramente della vendita di un grosso quantitativo di armi.

Don Winslow's fiction is what you get if you take the traditional gangster narratives of The Godfather, the elegant pulp of Raymond Chandler, the exhausted paranoia of Dog Soldiers, and the world-weary bureaucratic pessimism of The Wire, and then set all of that to the jazzy, profane rhythms of James Ellroy and give it the relentless freight-train momentum of The Shield. (Scottish author Malcolm Mackay clearly went to school on Winslow's customary rat-a-tat style for his gangster noirs.)In this mammoth (in size and in scope) odyssey of the Mexican-American drug war, whose sequel The Cartel I'd already read, Winslow wears all of those influences on his sleeve, but they're so well synthesized that the result is something that feels original. It also feels like Winslow owns this territory so authoritatively that anyone else who tries to cover it would have to reckon with these books first, much the way anyone who writes a mob book is doing so in Puzo's shadow.I wasn't as enamored with his big cop novel The Force as other folks (witness its 4.11 rating on Goodreads) because its trajectory felt derivative (Denny Malone = Vic Mackey); in these drug war thrillers, Winslow is almost writing the history of our failed four-decade War on Drugs with more acuity and resonance than any nonfiction to date. It is also wildly entertaining.Bring on The Border!

Interesante punto de vista que aporta el autor al conflicto y los intereses económicos y sociales que supone el narcotráfico a gran escala (no los pequeños consumidores y camellos para lo que existe un género propio). Creo que está muy muy bien documentado y que el autor dedicó más tiempo a investigar que a escribir, eso se nota y de qué forma en el trabajo final. Tiene el ritmo narrativo adecuado para una buena novela de acción y da una panorámica de contorno del narco muy muy bueno, lo crees. Creo que por el momento de publicación debió ser pionera en este género, después han venido series, películas..No me ha gustado nada el final y mucho menos la traducción, me ha parecido poco presentable en una editorial del tamaño de R. House, sobre este asunto podría extenderme muchísimo y no viene al caso, pero ahorrar costes y presentar un producto devaluado y tan pobre no me ha parecido de recibo. El lector (iguaal que el contribuyente) a todo se acaba por acostumbrar, pero como digo la traducción es muy mala.

The Power of the Dog by Don Winslow is a tour de force of betrayal, violence, loyalty and above all else; truth. If you prefer your take on the drug war and on the politics of the drug war glamorized by Hollywood and the deceptions of either political party, then The Power of the Dog will have a sobering and hopefully lasting effect. ****SPOILERS**************SPOILERS****************SPOILERS********************"...Art looks at Ernie's naked corpse. Lying fetal inside a sheet of black plastic in a ditch off a dirt road in Badiraguato. His dried blood is caked flat black against the shiny black plastic . The black blindfold is still around his eyes. Otherwise he's naked, and Art can see the open wounds where they jammed an ice pick through his flesh and scraped his bones, the electrode burns, the signs of anal rape, the needle marks from the lidocaine and heroin injections up and down his arms.  What have I done? Art asks himself. Why did someone else have to pay for my obsession? I'm sorry, Ernie. I'm so goddamn sorry..."Art Keller is a Mexican American, born and raised in the barrios of Southern California. He was recruited out of college by the CIA and after a stint in Vietnam, he wanted out. Art wanted to do something good, be a real force, and hopefully wipe away the blood and stench of what happened in Vietnam. What he becomes is a DEA agent working in Mexico. At first it's pretty boring. No one will speak with him. He isn't trusted by the Cartels, to them he has Narco written all over him. He isn't trusted by the DEA, his time as a CIA spook has them questioning how much of a real cop he is. But a chance encounter with the Barrera brothers gives him an in with what would become, the most powerful drug cartel in Mexico."...Would you happen to have an extra cigarette?' the priest asks. 'I don't smoke.' 'Puritan.' 'It'll kill you,' Art says. 'Everything I like will kill me,' the priest answers. 'I smoke, I drink, I eat too much. Sexual sublimation, I suppose. I'm Bishop Parada. You can call me Father Juan.' 'You're a madman, Father Juan.' 'Christ needs madmen,' Parada says, standing up and dusting himself off. He looks around and smiles. 'And the village is still here, isn't it?' Yeah, Art thinks, because the gomeros started shooting. 'Do you have a name?' the priest asks. 'Art Keller.' He offers his hand. Parada takes it asking, 'Why are you down here burning my country, Art Keller?' 'Like I said, it's-' 'Your job, ' Parada says. 'Shitty job, Arturo..."Bishop Parada was born in Texas, on the United States side of the border, to migrant workers. What many Americans would refer to as illegals. Parada returned to Mexico and joined the priesthood, rising up the ranks to become a Bishop. He is well acquainted with the violence and corruption of the country he loves. He has been priest to politicians, drug runners and villagers alike. He has a calling to serve the poor and oppressed and in Mexico, he has found so many. Parada will unwittingly become a player in the rise to power of Adan Barrera and the war between Keller and Barrera. A part that will end in blood."...Fabian lowers his head and lifts his foot and plants it right on the crucifix on Parada's chest and kicks, sending the priest sprawling back against the car, and the Fabian lifts the gun's barrel again and sends fifteen bullets smashing into Parada's chest. Parada feels his life draining out of him as his body slides down the side of the car. Callan kneels down by the dying priest. The man looks up at him and mumbles something Callan can't make out. 'What?' Callan asks. 'What did you say?' 'I forgive you,' Parada murmurs. 'What?' 'God forgives you..."From Vietnam to California, to Hell's Kitchen, to San Diego and to the poppy fields of Mexico and South America, The Power of the Dog is the story to the rise of power one of the most brutal and brilliant drug kingpins the world will ever know. Adan Barrera. It is also the story of a lone DEA agent who will do anything to bring Barrera to justice. But in the end it will be what Art Keller is actually willing to sacrifice that will cost him the most. The Power of the Dog is a force to be reckoned with. This is the type of novel so rooted in the truth that you will forget you are reading fiction because, truthfully you are not. It is bloody and brutal and pulls no punches. That is good because this is a subject matter that demands stark honesty. The violence of the drug trade that comes into the United States is stained on everyone's hands. From the dealers to the cops to the governments to the consumer. We are all corruptible. Winslow is writing a documentary of a time and place that is hiding behind the entertainment of a novel. Maybe because that is the only way we can accept it. We need this to be fiction. We need to believe that these acts are the imaginings of a lone author. But they are not. They are the truths of our addictions and the cost of those weaknesses. Keller is an amazing and complex character. A man who strays so often from what he once thought to be right and good in his quest to stop the drug trade. But so is Adan Barrera, a man so horrible and cruel but yet the reader will identify quite often with his desire to keep what is his. To protect those that he feels are entrusted to him. To his sense of love and loyalty. In the end, the fine line between the two is too often muddied and blurred.Winslow does that fine of a job as a storyteller and The Power of Dog is that good of a book.A really powerful and good read and not to be missed!

I don’t quite know where to begin with this review. The novel is so in-depth and detailed about the cartel lifestyle and Mexican/American political systems that enabled it. It that it is incredibly hard to breakdown. The characterisation is brilliant, the author slowly builds the characters up as the plot unravels. You are left under no illusion what an immensely tough job it must be to enforce DEA law and attempt to stop the cartel’s flow of drugs. Not only are the police facing a criminal network that spans the globe and is savage and violent in its approach. But they also face dirty cops, bribed officials and people who would put themselves above the good of the country and its citizens. ‘A lot of money goes into bribes. silver or lead’The prologue opens in El Sauzal, Mexico 1997. Art Keller our protagonist and US operative is at the scene of a violent and bloody murder. 19 bodies lay slain, including a mother and baby. The death toll is 10 men, 3 women and 6 children. The victims were lined up against the patio wall and shot, execution style. Some of the family members show signs of torture, leading the cops to believe this is gang/cartel related. One lone victim remains, who was forced to watch the violence take place. The novel goes on to describe the various methods of torture for crime committed. For example, traitors are shot in the back of the head and informers in the mouth. Life is the cartel is far from easy. ‘El poder del perro’ – The power of the dogFrom the start the novel has a violent and explosive opening. However, the novel does go on to detail various areas of Mexico, who is affected by the cartel trade which includes the poor and just trying to get by citizens. But it also covers the policing, how a multidisciplinary team approach is desperately needed. But no one trust each other. Art Keller is new to Mexico at the opening of the novel, but the end he is accustomed to the harsh way of life/death the cartels live by. At the beginning he is suffering flashbacks from his tour in Vietnam. I wondered myself, which would be worse war or the war on drugs?The DEA has been in operation 2yrs and Nixon has recently declared his ‘war on drugs’ stance. This is as the same time Art find himself recruited from the CIA to the DEA. Art is an experienced soldier, but I believe at the beginning he was naïve at just how integrated the cartel structure is into everyday life. His boss Tim Taylor hates him, and he is isolated and alone in and new to Mexico. This is when he first meets Adan Barrera. . . ‘Years later, Art would have given anything in the world to have just killed Adan Barrera on the spot’ ‘A partnership made in hell’ – Art Keller & Tio Barrera There are a wealth of characters from Father Juan to Nora Hayden, it would be impossible for me to break down all the details of who fits into the plot and where, just know that each individual mentioned is relevant and they all play a part no matter how big or small in the formation of a divide. Which will sit Art on one side of the fence and the cartel on another. Art is also dealing with his own new marriage and personal problems. He is a complex character and there is so much more to Art than first meets the eye. ‘The only redemption for having a bad father is being a good one’ Art has adapted the motto YOYO aka you’re on your own. A motto that when dealing with the cartel will serve him well, as you never know who you can trust. When Art’s colleague Ernie Hidalgo goes missing, all hell breaks loose the DEA will stop at nothing to return one of their own. “If I have to. . . I’ll start a fucking war” – Art Keller Adan Barrera’s character also evolves. He is quite the strategist and manages to ensure he is top-dog of the cartel empire. But how long can that last for? And how quickly can you be taken down or killed?Adan also has a daughter that suffers a rare genetic condition. He personally feels responsible for this and it causes a huge rift in his marriage. With both him and his wife, ready to accept full responsibility for the condition. ‘neither god nor science can help his daughter’ The novel goes on to explain Adan’s rise within the organised infrastructure of the cartel drug trade. ‘Adan Barrera has reinvented the drug business’ The cartels are comfortable with the situation of buying the very police sent to stop them, they see it as a franchise, a business expense. ‘Just look the other way, be someplace else, see no evil, hear no evil, speak no evil and the monthly payment will be there in full and on time’ The cartel trade runs into profits of $8million a WEEK, yes that is a WEEK!!!!!! It is easy to see that every man, woman or child just has a price tag attached. Except one man, Art Keller can not be bought and will not be put on the pay roll. It just might be his downfall and he knows it. . . ‘He’s only sure that either he will kill Adan or Adan will kill him, and those are the only two ways this thing can end’ – Art Keller This novel has a deeply layered plot, that covers politics, corruption, flow of drugs, cartel wars, deception and violence. The last 20% is very intense and sets the scene perfectly for the next novel in the series The Cartel. Which I already have sat on my tbr pile. A fantastic insight into the real ‘war on drugs’.

The Power of the Dog by Don Winslow is Scarface and the Godfather rolled into one. You live as the good guys the bad guys and the people in between that are casualties of the drug war. This looks at both sides like I have never read before, it shows the good guys having to cross lines they never thought they could cross and the bad guys crossing those lines to keep what they have. There's a scene that will leave you floored as a bad guy does the unthinkable to take down a rival, think Red Wedding from Game of Thrones. This book goes through 3 decades of drug traffic starting in the 1970's to the 2000's, from Mexico, Columbia and the United States. This is the first in the Power of the Dog Series, it continues in The Cartel, and in The Border. I have read the Cartel and it is just as excellent as The Power of the Dog. Winslow has this writing style that feels so real, he can take you to the past in a blink of an eye while wrapping up the narrative. His writing style reminds me of Mario Puzo meets James Ellroy. The fiction blends perfectly with real events, making the novel feel so real. This is My third Don Winslow novel, and I have been blown away each time. I t was just announced that the novel The Force will star Matt Damon and be directed by James Mangold, who just directed Damon in Ford v Ferrari. Winslow has previously had the Secret Life of Bobby Z and The Savages who both starred John Travolta.The Plot: Art Kellar a soldier in Vietnam War takes a job at a newly formed organization the DEA. His job is to stop the flow of heroin from Mexico to the US. Art makes friends with the Tio Barrera a local cop with a lot of influence and his nephews Adan and Raul. Adan and Kellar are fast friends and the reason he now has the influence he has in the organization. Kellar and the Barrera's take down the drug kingpin of heroin in Mexico. Which the DEA calls job well done. Only the Barrera's had an ulterior motive to take up the distribution and use it for a cheaper new drug cocaine. Art Kellar has to convince his superiors of the new drug and new power players, Kellar feels responsible for giving power. Kellar dedicates his life to stopping his former friends the Barrera's. It will take a Priest, a prostitute, and a member of the Irish mob to all play a part.What I Liked: The history in intertwined in the novel elevates it to the next level. The way the CIA plays both sides and the motive that is given. The ups and downs of good guys to bad guys. This side characters that are explored and make sense when you see the whole puzzle in how they fit into it. The way people are described really sets them apart. There's easily over fifty characters and I was never once confused on who they were and who's side they were on. The twist and turns of people flipping, of plans not working out, of people having hidden agendas, and of how connected they really are, is what makes this novel so great. The story flows so seamlessly despite how complex the storyline is. Nora and Callan's arcs are my favorites to good supporting character's that are more than they seem. The bridge scene is, the scene that will stick with me for a while, it's tension filled, it's a do or die moment for one character, and it was so horrific, so shocking, that it made me cry with grief. This is the Red Wedding moment in Game of Thrones.What I Disliked: Understanding of Columbian politics, I feel like I need a whole book to understand Columbian politics, and the book takes a shot at it and I still came away confused. I feel like it is more of the complexity of the situation than the explaining of it, it didn't get in the way of my enjoyment of the book, and I still took a lot a way from it. Recommendation: The Power of the Dog is a book that feels like a great gangster movie as your reading it. There's too many trigger warning's too list, If you enjoy gangster movies or Game of Thrones the series or the books then you can handle the brutality of this. This is my third novel by Don Winslow and it will not be my last. I read the Cartel first before knowing it was a series and was blown away and not too lost, I now plan on rereading it, to get the impact of everything that happened before, and eventually read the Border the newest entry in the series. The Power of the Dog by Don Winslow gets the same score as the Cartel 5 out of 5 stars. Do yourself a favor and check out Don Winslow's work, if you can handle it.

I’d heard great things about this one, and it delivers. This is noir writ large, but it’s also social commentary. It’s an experiment in large-scale political thriller, but it comes with a conscience. At its best it can almost stand next to James Ellroy or even – though, of course not quite – Roberto Bolano.One feature of noir is that it cuts out the fluff. Going back to Hammett and Chandler, the noir voice pares away extra words. It refuses to give you the extra padding that can insulate you from the despair it’s navigating.That makes it tough for noir to be long. The best of it starts a story, moves it along, and then wraps it up quickly. So, outside of Ellroy, you rarely see anything as intertwined and ambitious as this. It spans close to a decade, two sides of the border, and seven or eight central characters.That would be enough to make this a powerful work within the genre, but it goes a lot farther than that too. Unlike some strains of noir – again, Ellroy – it doesn’t let its exploration of nihilism drive it to conservative politics. Instead, after it strips away so much, it still finds glimmers of a potential good. U.S. anti-drug agent Art Keller may get corrupted into actions that he regrets, actions that cost him much of what he loves, but he maintains a sense of what it means to bring the Mexican drug agents down.We watch as Art begins by cultivating some young cocaine dealers, following their leads to take out their rivals and then establishing himself as a rising figure within the D.E.A. Those young dealers rise as well, one of them in particular a Pablo Escobar level international boss. Throw in a young Irish gangster who gets caught in international intrigue, a beauty who becomes a high-class courtesan, a priest who becomes an Archbishop like Romero, and several others who appear and re-appear in a weave of narrative threads.In the course of the different stories separating and coming together, we see endless brutality. (Stay away, far away, if blood makes you queasy.) At times, it’s as concussive as 2666, and to similar purpose, if not to the same soaring desperate end. The constant reports of violence, particularly against the powerless, horrify, then numb, then anger, and finally rise to a sense that someone somewhere has to do something about it. The result is a novel that, while ultimately adhering to the conventions of the genre, pushes against them as well. It does invite us to care about particular characters in a way that Bolano resists, but it also reminds us that there’s no promise that virtue will win. I don’t want to risk spoilers, but evil – known her as “the power of the dog” – isn’t something that just goes away. People with the impulse to help others can get corrupted, and those who seem heartless can, having had enough, push back.But there’s a tar baby quality as well. Everyone who touches the evil gets infected by it, even those who think they’re resisting. And, given that the crimes here (often indistinguishable from the efforts to stop those crimes) are often the work of U.S. government-linked forces, even those of us just reading it are guilty as well.This is the first in a trilogy, and I have begun the second. Still, this one stands satisfyingly alone. I can’t imagine the sequel being at this level, but even down a peg should still be worth checking out.

"A Farmer in the Fields of the Dead" I find two varieties of five-star reads. Page-turners both, there are those that hit you like the best action movies - a quick rush, great fun while they last, a lightning shot of adrenaline - and all but forgotten a month or so down the road. And then there are the very special books that deliver all the thrills, the action, all the suspense while at the same searing an unshakable image in your soul that you know will stay with you for a very long time. Don Winslow's remarkable "Power of the Dog" is firmly in the latter camp.Contemporary history buffs my remember US DEA Special Agent Enrique "Kiki" Camarena who, while assigned in Mexico in 1985, was abducted, tortured, and brutally murdered by Mexican drug lords. While Winslow changes the names, the events leading to and subsequent to Camarena's murder play a central role in this epic tale of the violence, corruption, love, betrayal, and vengeance surrounding three decades worth of the trafficking of cocaine and heroine by Mexican drug cartels. So grand in scope, so exhaustively researched, and so authoritative in its delivery of the facts, and comparisons or analogies are strained. But for a starter, consider a role up of "Traffic", "The Godfather", and "Bring Me the Head of Alfredo Garcia". Winslow manages to demystify the shady politics and clandestine operations of Nicaragua and the Sandanistas and the Iran-Contra affair, the 1994 assassination of Mexican Presidential candidate Luis Colosio, NAFTA and others in enough detail to qualify as a docudrama, while the unspeakable brutality, depravity, and evil that travels alongside the drug trade is, well, plainly spoken. Winslow weaves tight story lines from Mexico's deserts and poppy fields to the Tijuana/San Diego borderland battlegrounds to New York City's Hell's Kitchen and Bensonhurst. His characters are much too real to be expected between the pages of pop fiction - all too believable in their flaws, weaknesses, vulnerabilities, and failures.In the end, it would not be giving anything away to say that the vaunted war on drugs is ultimately a war of futility. Drugs pour into the US in ever-greater quantities while drug lords get richer and the American taxpayer pours increasingly more money to fund corrupt politicians and dubious strategies. Notwithstanding, "The Power of the Dog" is a powerful and unapologetic tale of bitter fatalism, of redemption that rings ultimately hollow. If you are squeamish, or intend to keep naive delusions of our "noble" fight against drugs intact, this is probably not the book for you. But for what is bound to become a classic, plumbing the depths of evil in this dark history we'd probably all prefer to ignore, you simply must read this novel.

This was a monumental story of the history of drug trafficking from the early 1970's until the late 1990's. Told in the format of a battle between a DEA officer Art keller and two brothers 'the Barrerras ' it gives us the story of how the drug cartels formed in that period. The opening sees Keller a young officer just out of Vietnam overseeing the torching of poppy fields with the support of Angel Barrera , police officer and uncle of the two brothers. A loner Keller becomes friendly with Adan and Raul through boxing and when Keller turns a blind eye to Angels brutality an apparent blood bond is formed.As the book moves on the Mexican cartels develop the smuggling of cocaine from war torn central American states and the book expands to cover those wars and the CIA's involvements in supporting right wing groups fight communist insurgents. The revelation of American action revealed later in congressional hearing is frightening. The story also covers the involvement of New York mafia as they receive the crack cocaine and a chain of supply develops.There are some brilliant characters in the book including priest Juan Parada who struggles with catholic church corruption, Nora Hayden the high class prostitute, and Sean Callan the Irish hitman.The book moves at an incredible pace and is full of absorbing scenes which frequently had me on the edge of my seat and with excellent characterisation and constant mral dilemmas I was totally hooked. 15 minuti di applausi per un libro che è un autentico CAPOLAVORO.Quando chiudi l’ultima pagina hai il cuore che ancora ha le palpitazioni, ma è nulla al confronto di quello che Winslow ti fa provare nell’arco di tutta la storia.Oltre 30 anni raccontati con dovizia di particolari, con trasporto, con uno stile spettacolare, crudo, violento, erotico, romantico.Come ha già detto qualcuno.. “perché certi libri finiscono? Perché?”Carlitos Way, Blow, Scarface, Il Padrino, Quei Bravi Ragazzi, Casinò, Trafic, Donnie Brasco…. Film che hanno segnato la mia adolescenza.. e poi arriva questo libro, che prende tutto questo e lo migliora… ma non solo, quei film li guardi e gli adori, qua la storia la vivi, la respiri…Winslow sin dalla prima pagina ti porta dentro a una storia eccezionale e a volte ti domandi se stai leggendo un saggio storico per quanto verosimile e ricca particolari. Ideali, tradimenti, guerra, politica, intrighi internazionali, narcotraffico, omicidi, stragi, sesso, amore, droga, rapimenti, torture, fughe, agguati…. 700 pagine in apnea, dove più volte il cuore sobbalza e l’anima piange, perché certe cose vorresti non accadessero, che sia solo finzione e invece lo sai che certe cose succedono, sono successe e continuano ad accadere..Ogni personaggio è caratterizzato, analizzato, descritto, vissuto… i personaggi sono vivi e non esiste il bene e il male ma solo chi ha potere e chi non ce l’ha.Art Keller, Miguel Angel “Tio” Barrera, Adan Barrera, Raul Barrera, Sean Callan, O’ Bop, Sal Schachi, Guero Mendez, Pilar, Jhon Hobbs, Nora Hayden, i fratelli Pesche, Juan Parada… tutti a loro modo personaggi stupendi, nella loro malvagità, nella loro fragilità, nella loro vita e nelle loro morti.Libro potente che mi ha folgorato, (ora voglio leggere tutti i libri di Winslow), capolavoro totale che VA letto, ma solo se si ha lo stomaco forte.

La prima volta che ho sentito parlare di questo libro è stato leggendo questa recensione http://gruppodilettura.wordpress.com/...… Poichè però questo tipo di storie non è esattamente il mio genere, non l'ho preso in considerazione. Poi però ho letto anche questa: http://gruppodilettura.wordpress.com/...… e ho cominciato a pensarci. Quando infine ho trovato chi poteva prestarmi il libro, mi sono arresa e ho cominciato a leggere. Siamo negli anni Settanta in Messico. Art Keller - ex agente Cia reduce da una disastrosa esperienza in Vietnam - si trova qui come agente della Dea, in appoggio al governo messicano nell'ambito di una colossale guerra alla droga (nello specifico, l'eroina). La decisione di entrare nella Dea (all'epoca appena costituita) rappresenta per Art la possibilità di redimersi, di combattere una battaglia migliore. Quando però, dopo numerosi fiaschi, Art riesce a trovare un informatore, la violenza e le innumerevoli morti che accompagnano le missioni lo costringono a ripensare al Vietnam, trovando inquietanti parallelismi. Se Art riesce a trovare un senso in quello che sta facendo, e a continuare a farlo, è perchè sembra che la guerra alla droga stia dando veramente i suoi frutti. Fino a quando un eclatante episodio lo riduce, insieme all'intera missione, al ruolo di pedina, di fantoccio. Questo è un romanzo duro, ma appassionante e - purtroppo - veritiero. Consiglio a tutti di leggerlo, anche se le storie di narcotrafficanti vi fanno storcere il naso (come di solito lo fanno storcere a me).

The Power of the Dog, by Don Winslow, a-minus, narrated by Ray Porter, produced by Blackstone Audio, downloaded from audible.com.Publisher’s note:This explosive novel of the drug trade takes you deep inside a world riddled with corruption, betrayal, and bloody revenge.Art Montana is an obsessiveDEA agent. The Barrera brothers are heirs to a drug empire. Nora Hayden is a jaded teenager who becomes a high-class hooker. Father Parada is a powerfuland incorruptible Catholic priest. Callan is an Irish kid from Hell's Kitchen who grows up to be a merciless hit man. All of them are trapped in the worldof the Mexican drug Federación.From the streets of New York City to Mexico City and Tijuana to the jungles of Central America, this is the war on drugslike you've never seen it. This is probably one of the darkest books I’ve ever read. Nothing is as it seems. Everyone is using everyone else for their own ends. The DEA agent, Arthur Keller, is obsessed with getting rid of the drug trade, and especially with ridding himself of the gang who killed his friend, a policeman. While this book does detail the earthquake in Mexico City in the ‘80’s, you could really say that this whole book is one in which your feet are never on the ground and you are always being thrown topsy-turvy. The only thing you can say for sure is that in the drug wars no one wins. The book is extremely well written, including everyone’s sardonic thoughts.

La novela de Winslow es ilustradísima y punzante . Desde mediados de la década de 1970 hasta el cambio de siglo, la ficción histórica de Winslow ilustra la diferencia entre la política pública declarada de la guerra contra las drogas de Estados Unidos y el respaldo encubierto del tráfico de drogas para mantener el comunismo fuera de América Central y del Sur. El agente de la DEA de carácter directo y agresivo; el jefe sin encanto del agente agresivo; y el capo de la droga que poco a poco se ensucia más y más las manos. Esta es una novela en la que puedes ver todos los Personajes están muy bien construidos . Desde la página uno, atrapado.Art Keller es un ex agente de la CIA que se disgustó con la ejecución de misiones de asesinato en Vietnam y saltó a la recién formada Agencia Antidrogas, donde pensó que podría hacer algo bueno. Art es asignado a México, donde conoce a la familia Barrera, que le da información para destruir la mayor parte del comercio de heroína y los campos de amapolas existentes. Más tarde, Art se entera de que los Barrera lo usaron para eliminar la competencia y darles la oportunidad de establecer una organización que se enriquecerá llevando cocaína desde Sudamérica a los Estados Unidos.Un Libro que cuenta la verdad de lo social, lo ilegal y lo corrupto de las drogas. Perfecto Winslow, lo lograste . Recomendación Total.

Quando um jornalista se propõe a escrever um livro, em geral o resultado é positivo. A objetividade inerente a sua profissão costuma proporcionar uma história coesa, direta e bem amarrada. Nesse sentido, “A Lei do Cão” se mostrava um desafio interessante: garantir essa estrutura por quase 700 páginas.Apesar do autor fazer (no final) um juízo de valor da política americana anti-drogas, fiquei positivamente surpreso pelo fato do livro ser muito mais um romance que um apanhado jornalístico do mundo das drogas. O foco fica mesmo na estória do agente Art Keller e seu combate incansável ao tráfico de drogas, em como isso afetou sua vida e se tornou uma obsessão. Aliás, essa é uma constante do livro, como o tráfico afeta a vida das pessoas. E não se trata do lugar-comum do vício em drogas, e sim em como esse ambiente molda a personalidade e o caráter, e define novos rumos pros protagonistas: o líder do cartel, um padre ativista, um matador de aluguel e uma prostituta de luxo. Vidas muito diferentes que se cruzam numa narrativa envolvente.Talvez o ponto chave do livro não seja a droga em si, mas a traição. Traição em diversos aspectos, em diversos momentos da estória, que transforma a vida das pessoas e garante emoção do começo ao fim do livro. Excelente leitura!

For big, thoughtful, hyper-critical views of America, Winslow is right up there with Ellroy and Lehane. The violence is over-the-top, the hero is flawed (although not in that grittier way that Ellroy manages), the set-pieces absolutely gorgeous and the plot is suitably epic.This book shares a thesis with the Wire that the War on Drugs is a terrible idea. It goes further with the idea that is really a Machiavellian ploy to fight communism/impose American will/maintain order. The blowback from the policy affects mostly marginalized groups, so who cares right? The book doesn't reach the levels of outrage that Ellroy summons, nor does he love his wicked, terrible characters in the way that Ellroy. Instead the wicked and terrible are mostly (Cullen is the exception and even his bad deeds don't reek of evil the way the rest do) out and out bad, while the good are just flawed.I grouse here. In reality, I stayed up late reading this, sweated out the horrifying scenes and re-thought my view point on American foreign policy. That doesn't happen very often in crime novels.I have the follow up on my bedside and will be picking up more of his books soon.

Whew! A graphic, gripping tale that left me wondering how close to the truth this story is - obviously, not with respect to specific names, events, etc., but concerning just how massive and powerful the "supply side" of the drug problem is. How much influence and control do the real cartels hold over the Mexican government - at the local level and higher? I personally believe that brave men and women of integrity are risking their lives to fight drugs at the source - but the drug lords are very powerful, as we all know, and are ruthless beyond belief.Which brings us to the "demand side" - that would be us. If we could put a major dent in the drug problem on the U.S. side of the border, our adversaries in the war on drugs would take a huge hit. Our president might do well to spend the money on his wall on a more aggressive multi-front war on drugs here at home - tougher sentences for domestic distributors, more effective and well-supervised treatment programs, much more on education for young people (including young adults).An intense book that I think is well worth reading.

What a powerful, epic, sprawling epic of drug crime! It covers about 20 years of fighting the drug czars in Mexico, the Barreras, against the DEA cop, Art Keller. This is a work of fiction and it has a great plot, and not only involves the War Against Drugs in Mexico but in Honduras, Nicaragua, Columbia, etc. I think this was well researched against the political backdrop of what was happening in the 80s and 90s time periods. In addition to the two main characters, Keller and Adan, there is also Callan, an Irish mobster and Nora, a high class prostitute. The narrator for the audiobook, Ray Porter, does one unbelievable job here, doing the accents for Mexicans, Irish guys, Italian Mafiao guys, etc. One of my favorite quotes points out that DEA agents may be doing the drug smugglers a favor: "The Americans take a product that literally grows on trees and turn it into a valuable commodity. Without them, cocaine and marijuana would be like oranges, and instead of making billions smuggling it, I’d be making pennies doing stoop labor in some California field, picking it."

This is the second Don Winslow book I've read, the first being SAVAGES. All I can say after reading it is there is no way Don Winslow writes without a serious outlining system (and I mean that in a very, very good way). The book has a large number of characters and weaves them in and out of the plot throughout the 560 pages. I totally enjoyed this book and its ability to entertain while also making a point, which, to me, was, "There's no way we will ever win a war on drugs." I was a little shocked that SAVAGES is the book Oliver Stone is making into a movie as I found THE POWER OF THE DOG to be much more powerful. I guess Oliver Stone is going for the borderline absurd/humorous nature of SAVAGES. I try to withhold the 5-star ratings for books that really stick with me, and this one does that. I enjoyed SAVAGES, but this book is why I am ripping through Don Winslow's entire catalog. Great read.

Don Winslow is the king of hardboiled crime fiction and his Power of the Dog series is his tour de force. Following DEA officer Art Keller's quixotic quest to stop the incredibly powerful drug cartels of Sinaloa and its most powerful family, the Bareras, Winslow is unrelenting in detailing not only the complex historical background that the drug cartels and the US's War on Drugs occurs in, but also shamelessly spares no detail of the incredibly violent consequences of the conflict. In the end, everyone's hands are covered in guilt and blood, but no one more than the forces of American imperialism, who have happily made friends with and propped up the drug cartels to further their interests in Central and South America. These books are not for the faint of heart, but if you choose to pick them up you will be rewarded by some of the most riveting storytelling out there.

I really love this guy's stuff. The couple of books I've read, the writing/voices feel very authentic to the characters/story. The research is either excellent or his imagination is very good—probably both. This book, unlike The Force, follows a whole mess of different characters. Four "main" characters, I'd say, plus a bunch of strong secondaries who get a lot of page time. Lots of location-hopping, too, so there's a lot to keep track of. All sorts of stuff going on. And a lot of time covered. I feel like I was with these guys forever.I was around for pretty much all of this but way too young to know what was happening—and I think most people didn't have any idea about it all. Super interesting stuff.Already looking forward to The Cartel, which I have right here, ready and waiting.

is this real life or is this just fantasy?Took me a while to review this book, but not so much to read it. A big punch to the stomach of this Mexican who's watched his country descend into madness and levels of violence unmatched by fiction. Winslow doesn't pull any punches. He builds fiction on the reality of the corruption and moral decadence in Mexico and USA that's left both countries submerged in a drug nightmare they won't be able to solve in a thousand lifetimes.We go from Sinaloa, to Mexico City, to New York City, San Diego, Tijuana, Central America, South America...everywhere the narrative is on point and the violence rules. The book is graphic and uncomfortable. It doesn't sanitize the drug business. It is raw, cruel, extremely filthy and a great read.

Winslow delivers this dark tale of the rise of the Mexican drug cartels with flesh-and-blood characters, both the narcos and the cops, mainly our protagonist, a rogue DEA agent. There are as many switchbacks in the plot as a mountain road, but satisfyingly so, with characters who seem as much driven by love (and lust) as they are by greed and power, which gives the whole enterprise a little Lifetime movie-of-the-week soapy patina that wore on this reader, but the action was so propulsive, and the revelations about the relationships between anti-communism, CIA, DEA, Mexican federales and state forces, and various branches of the cartel that I was willing to forgive a minor fault. Winslow is a helluva story teller. Is this not a movie? Why not?

This is completely outside of my normal book. I came to this book because I kept liking Don Winslow's tweets. So finally I decided to check his bio. Author. Ok. Pull up overdrive. His books are also available as audiobooks. So I checked this one out immediately.Mexican drug cartels. The DEA. The mafia. Whatever you call the Irish mob. Government muckity mucks who don't appear to good. Huge cast of characters. In this respect, Don Winslow reminded of Stephen King. He has a big cast of characters that aren't related at first. And slowly as things progress and spiral it all comes full circle and they meet.So not my usual read. But that's good. I really liked it. I will read more!

I first learned of this novel back in 2015 when THE CARTEL came out. I had just begun grad school and the more I heard about that novel and this one, the more interested I became. At some point, I bought THE POWER OF THE DOG and it has sat in my TBR pile until about a week two weeks ago, right after I finished grad school.This novel was great! Potato chips in book form. I couldn’t stop reading. It’s tough, violent, and full of humanity. Winslow’s research takes you into the Mexican drug cartels and applies a fictitious story with fictional characters in a very real history. It’s shocking and a page turner. I can’t wait to start THE CARTEL!

I was surprised how much I loved a book about a DEA agent, Art Keller, who becomes obsessed with taking down the Mexican Cartel. There's the Italian mob, corrupt politics, an escort, etc sterotype etc stock character. And yet it all works. There's a lot going on, so maybe just read the description. Then read this book. It's violent and prettyyyy graphic. Hell, the opening scene is pretty descriptive. But it grips you. Definitely going to pick up the sequel, and I'm not one to jump to the next book in a series. Also side note, Don Winslow was at my local library the other month doing a reading AND I WILLINGLY SAT IT OUT BECAUSE I HAD NOT FINISHED THIS BOOK AND I AM A FOOL.

4.5 estrellas Sobrecogedora y cruda novela que no se puede dejar de leer una vez que se comienza. Muy bien escrita y llena de detalles basados en la vida real. Se nota la profunda investigación que tuvo que hacer el autor para escribirla. No apta para todo el mundo: te deja una sensación de desesperanza, de decepción con la sociedad, y de abatimiento cuando te das cuenta de que las cosas eran así y de que, lamentablemente, siguen siendo así (o peor). Salvo por eso... totalmente recomendable.

I really did not enjoy this book. I wanted to love it. I was looking for something different to read and came across the second book, The Cartel. I decided to read this one first. Gosh, it was sooooooo boring. I am fascinated by the subject matter (War on drugs). I can appreciate how accurate the information was and the research that the author put into it. But this was so dry and repetitive and read almost like a dull textbook. Maybe it's too manly for me? It took me months to get through it and just wasn't for me. Darn.

It’s obvious that Don Winslow has put so much research into both this book and The Cartel. It’s also so frightening that this is what really goes on. Of course, personal stories are added to make it more interesting & cohesive.This book is not for the feint of heart. The drug trade is made up of hardened individuals with one goal in mind: making money, and it doesn’t matter who dies to reach the goal.Personally, I believe these two books are so well done, I wish our legislators would read them.

I’m halfway through this book and I’ve appreciated much of it. I think it’s a well stitched, extremely violent, historical-fiction set in a dark stretch of time at the desperate end of the Cold War. In the last scene I read, two young children were thrown off a bridge. The day before their mother had been decapitated after sex... with the man that killed them all.I’ve tried to pick this book up again many times. I’ve lost the will. And the book is due back at the library. DNF 54% No rating.

This was a fascinating gritty book about the drug war between the US and Mexico. There was so much corruption on both sides and angered me how our presidents talked about stopping drugs, then destroyed our chances through the adoption of NAFTA and Nicaragua's president, Manuel Noriega. It gave me a jaded view of our country's real objectives. I plan to read the next book in the series, The Cartel.

Hats off to Mr. Winslow. The characters are believable, some even endearing, and it's got a plot like barbed wire trapped in the tire of a super bike hitting terminal velocity on an empty interstate. And that's forgetting that the source material is a real, ongoing tragedy of the first order. Eye opening stuff, even slickly sheathed in a mile-a-minute plot. Don't even know what to say. A kind of blood-drunk enjoyable from front to back.

Vivid, brutal, immense, and raw. This book disturbed me, challenged me, and brought me to tears. Horrifying with moments of beauty and tenderness, I never would have picked up this book without a friend suggesting it for book club but I'm glad that I read it. Looking forward to reading the sequels.

This book does an amazing job of developing characters without adding so much extra information that you feel like you’re reading a screenplay. Every character is dynamic, the settings even more so, how Winslow connects storylines is fluid without feeling forced. I’m a huge fan of film and tv on this topic, I found reading about it just as captivating!

Wow what a book. I was a little sceptical after the first few pages, but once the story gets going it is unstoppable.Easily one of the best if not THE best book I have ever read. I have also read The Winter of Frankie Machine and really like Winslows style of writing. Well done. This is an epic.......

I had just finished Jane Austen's "Emma," and the transition from Victorian gentility to mobsters and F-bombs was abrupt, to say the least. Once I got into the story, I was hooked. Very engaging, suspenseful. Not for the faint of heart. Stick it through until the end when you will encounter one of the hottest sex scenes this side of Penthouse Forum. Fantastic novel. Bloody, Gory, Brutal. The story of Pilar Talavera will stay with me for years, even if it is a small part of this great book. The fact that this is all inspired or based on real events make it even scarier. Read this if you want to understand the so called "War On Drugs"

Mi motor vital ahora mismo es la idea de que HBO haga una serie de seis temporadas con este material o de retroceder hasta 1972, que Francis Ford Coppola se haga cargo de adaptar el texto y filme una trilogía épica. Ya, 'El poder del perro' no se publicó hasta 2005, pero soñar es gratis.

Loved this book. It IS a long read, but fascinating and engaging. I love stories about the rise of the cartels or mafia, so if you like those kinds of books, this is awesome. If you liked "Queen of the South", you'll love this book. Thumbs up.

WOW! The scoping of this book is amazing. Enthralling - every page. Truly felt like I was reading an action packed movie. The immense detail warrants a second read soon! Can't wait to read The Cartel next!

Excellent. The best way to experience a Don Winslow book is audio. The narrators are excellent and immerse you in the story. The Force was my first, and now Power of the Dog. Outstanding. Can’t wait for book 2 from the library.
Don Winslow is a damn genius. This book took him six years to research and write, and if you're the fortunate reader of it, it was worth every tortured second.

4.5 for me. Really enjoyable book/story about the war on drugs told from several different perspectives. I'll definitely read books 2 and 3.
