A very raw and sad historical novel about the drug cartels and the war on drugs during the 80's and 90's. "Gripping" and "shocking" could be used to define this book.

Una novela excesiva en todo, en lo bueno y en lo malo. Si la hubiera leído en 2005 a buen seguro habría alucinado con ella. Como en su momento me gustaban las novelas de Tom Clancy o de John Grisham. O de Follet. Tochazos con miles de personajes, acción a raudales, documentación y nombres técnicos de agencias secretas, turbios planes gubernamentales, violencia y sangre, escenas de sexo explícitas y personajes femeninos fatales. Un estilo que, hoy en día, sigue vigente. Dentro y fuera de nuestras fronteras. Y reconociendo el gran trabajo del autor (bastante peor el del traductor) pienso, como me pasa con muchos otros trabajos 'similares', que le sobra paja, trascendencia y tantas casualidades.Ahora mismo no me siento con fuerzas y/o ánimos para poner la segunda entrega de la saga en mi lista de futuribles. Y no creo que lo haga nunca.

Dense and sweeping. This is as close as I have got to repeating the feeling of reading American Tabloid for the first time. Winslow must have inhaled Ellroy's work, but he has also created something more political and less sensational than Ellroy. He's writing in a different key, but there was so much to love here. Leaving all the brutality aside, he makes a fantastic case for the synergy between the war on drugs and the drug lords it makes wealthy by driving the prices up. The book also makes the link explicit between America's funding of murderous drug cartels to keep Marxism out of South America, and specifically away from the Mexican border.Reads like true crime with gun battles, torture scenes and young children being thrown off a bridge. Not for the faint-hearted.

This was not an easy book to read, with continuous violence and depravity. But I think it is an important story. This author obviously has done a huge amount of research into the history of the drug cartels and drug wars along the southern borders of this country, as well as into other areas of Central and South America. He goes back in time to also tell of the U.S.'s interventions in revolutions in these countries, and our support of right wing and fascist's types of government, and how such actions have helped to develop the poverty and violence that predominate many communities in these countries to this day. This book is fiction, with an excellent development of plot and characters. But the stories it tells are too sadly based in history and fact. This is the first book in a series, and after I have let it rest for a time, I do plan to continue with the next book.

A cambio el diseño de los personajes es bastante plano y se nota que alguno de ellos no es más que una excusa para mostrarnos partes de la historia quedan fuera del campo de los narradores principales.

Winslow just loves the slap bang kaboom but there’s little build up to make the pay off sweeter. He’s not great at dialogue either as a lot of it is laced with expositions. Everything just moves at such a frantic pace, especially the latter halves, I felt a lot of tension and realism was missing. That being said, it’s well researched and it’s very cinematic literature. I enjoyed it greatly. I much preferred Frankie Machine. Only the second Winslow book I read. I’d definitely read more.

4.5 The back cover of the book reads:"You should try to get your hands on everything Winslow's written, because he is one of the best thriller writers on the planet." -EsquireI have to agree - I found it hard to put this book down! I can hardly wait to read The Cartel and The Border.

Il est vrai que j'avais déjà chroniqué « Cartel » de Don Winslow et pas « La griffe du chien » qui est le premier tome. Réparation effectuée avec ma critique ci-dessous pour ce pavé (un peu plus de 800 pages), lui aussi, mais on ne s'en rend pas compte.L'auteur : Don Winslow est né en 1953. Après plusieurs métiers, il a écrit au moins dix-sept romans, des best-sellers, qui ont été traduits dans une vingtaine de langues. A présent, il vit à San Diego, « le paradis du surf. »Le livre : un thriller que certaines âmes sensibles ne supporteraient pas (eh oui, il y en a et c'est leur droit comme c'est notre droit, à nous lecteurs qui aimons le genre, nous les amateurs de sensations fortes – ceux qui veulent aborder d'immenses problèmes causés, notamment, par la drogue. Et cela existe malheureusement : rien ne sert de se voiler la face).Il existe des pays, comme le Mexique (par exemple), où elle fait des ravages et où elle est reine. Mauvaise réputation. Mais qui dit drogue, dit cartels et ils sont nombreux, puissants, tous ennemis les uns des autres. C'est ce que Don Winslow nous raconte avec force détails et descriptions scabreuses.Ce qui frappe d'abord sur la couverture, c'est la remarque de James Ellroy : « Le plus grand roman sur la drogue jamais écrit. Une vision grandiose de l'Enfer et de toutes les folies qui le bordent. »Si ce n'est pas un bel hommage que celui-ci, de la part d'un tel écrivain que James Ellroy, c‘est une critique en elle-même et je vais essayer de rajouter quelques phrases.On découvre (hum, hum ! Comme si on ne le savait pas déjà), le trafic de drogue entre le Mexique et les États-Unis, avec l'histoire de Art Keller, surnommé : « le seigneur de la frontière », (agent de la DEA), tandis que Adán Barrera et Raúl Barrera, eux, sont surnommés : « les seigneurs des cieux. ». Adán, lui, un « seigneur de la drogue », a une vie familiale difficile car sa fille est handicapée mais il ne veut que son bien. Petite touche de tendresse. Or, Adán règne sur les sicarios.L'église est présente également avec « l'archevêque rouge », Juan Parada et une autre personne est à remarquer : il s'agit d'une prostituée, Nora Hayden, très intelligente et qui tient une bonne place.Mais Don Winslow ne s'est pas limité à nous offrir un gigantesque travail « documentaire ». Page après page, on découvre toutes les horreurs commises par les narcotrafiquants, les hommes de main des « grands de la pègre » - on découvre le nombre tellement important de ces cartels. Ce sont donc les agissements d'un agent de la DEA – ceux d'un gangster d'origine irlandaise – l'intervention d'une prostituée, ainsi que celle d'un prêtre mexicain – de la CIA …. bref, autant dire tellement de personnages aussi variés les uns que les autres qu'il est fort difficile de les détailler.Chaque élément est important et contribue à constituer cet ouvrage dont on tourne les pages les unes après les autres. On apprend ainsi cette terrible guerre des cartels que l'on continuera à lire dans « Cartel » (la suite).On assiste à une plongée passionnante mais terrible dans ce milieu de narcotrafiquants qui se livrent à une guerre sans merci. Des têtes tombent (au sens propre comme au figuré) – si certains flics sont incorruptibles, d'autres le sont moins : « money is money », et les pétarades se font entendre pour un oui ou pour un non. Non seulement ça flingue mais c'est également fait par erreur. On s'est trompé de cible, alors tant pis, un de plus ou un de mois, dans le tas, ça passera.Le rythme est trépidant – pas un moment de répit, ce qui tient le lecteur en haleine.On peut lire ceci (entre autres que j'ai relevé du titre « La griffe du chien » « El poder del perro » : « Art appuie sur la détente. C'est difficile, il faut appuyer plus fort que dans son souvenir.Tio lui adresse un grand sourire.Et Art sent la présence du mal, un mal absolu.La griffe du chien. «Au final car mieux vaut que je stoppe ici ma chronique : tout cela pour dire que c'est un vrai chef d'oeuvre. Inutile d'en rajouter sinon de le lire ou de le redécouvrir. C'est le moment … et vous voyez que James Ellroy avait bien raison…. de toute façon, il ne se trompe jamais.
Me ha encantado. Si bien es cierto que hay pasajes que se pueden hacer un poco lentos, en general, la historia es intensa y muy rápida. Un buen libro de acción policíaca.

I was reading some book reviews and saw The Border by Don Winslow being praised. As per usual, I went to Goodreads to add it to my To-Read pile (that will still be there after I die, it's so large) and discovered that it was third in a series. We all know my trouble with starting a series in the wrong spot.I did my research and ended up getting book #1, The Power of the Dog, from the library. Work is making it increasingly difficult to just sit down and read. My mind wanders, thinking about all the work I should be doing, instead of relaxing and escaping reality. The Power of the Dog caught me right from the start and tried so hard to make me just sit and read. It turns out, I had to read this in fleeting moments, mostly waiting in waiting rooms for appointments or kept in my car and purse for quiet minutes before a dinner or stuck in traffic. Any chance I had, I read.“Deliver my soul from the sword; my love from the power of the dog. Psalms 22:20” I would be incorrect to say this was just a novel about the Mexican drug cartel. It's Irish Mafia, Russians, American DEA, Italian Mafia, Hookers, Priests, drug lords, Columbians and the American government out for their own agenda. It's every-fricking-thing.It's Art Keller. A Mexican-American kid grown up to be DEA. It's Adan Barrera and his brother, Raul. Their uncle is in charge of Operation Condor, in 1975, that destroys the poppy fields in Mexico, taking out the main source of heroin. Tio Barrera delivers the main drug lord to the Americans and makes it appear the operation was a success. But Tio has other plans. Instead of heroin, he brings together a federation of drug dealers (suppliers, soon to be millionaires), including his nephews, to start producing crack cocaine and distributing it across the border to the US. Two thousand miles of border is split up so every area is covered. And soon, America has a crack epidemic. In New York, we have O-Bop and Callan, two Irish kids, who run into the wrong side of the Irish mob. The Italian Mafia wants to start bringing in crack to the area to make more money and run into the Irish kids. Callan turns out to be a killer...literally. O-Bop comes along for the ride but it's really Callan's show. The Italians start using and investing in the kids.The book moves along the years to follow all of the players, and there are a lot. Starting off in 1975 and ending 2004, we cover a lot of, often bloody, ground. I was amazed at the detail, not necessarily the gory details. The human beings caught up in events they really don't want to participate in, trying to get away from the mafia and have a normal life, agreeing to do things knowing that if they don't, the Barrera brothers will torture or kill them and their families. How drugs make it past the border (and don't you think a wall is going to help with this!), how the American government looks the other way when it needs something and how the Mexican government pretends nothing is wrong because of the drug money kickbacks being handed over by the Barrera's for "protection".Corruption is ripe in this novel and it's almost disheartening. Even our protagonist, Art, has to make some sketchy decisions that move him from the right side towards the more morally gray area. Damn good book. Really looking forward to continuing the trilogy.

I'm giving this book 4 ⭐What a brutal and intense book. One would think that it's just another book about drugs, but it's much more complex than that: politics, thriller, corruption, organized crime, revenge... One of the things that surprised me the most is the author's capacity to present us so many characters that might seem unrelated at first, and then seeing the connection that forms between them over the long period of time that this book covers. Very intrigued to see how the story unfolds in the following books!

Wow, talk about one epic, sprawling novel! I can’t remember the last time I read a book that was this broad based in scope, when dealing with the subject presented to the reader.THE POWER OF THE DOG is all about the war on drugs, primarily the Mexican cartel side of the war on drugs. Told from the perspectives of a DEA agent, a drug lord, a priest, a hooker and a Irish hitman, this story takes you through the entire web of drugs, from the meager beginnings of the DEA and it’s war waged by then president Richard Nixon in the 1970’s, to the days of the late 1990’s and billions of dollars of cash flowing through an intricate web of deceit, betrayal, murder, kidnapping, governmental manipulation, the Mob and so much more! Looking at all of this on paper, it would be easy to think that this story, spanning the globe throughout three decades, might be convoluted, but it’s actually not at all. Author Don Winslow masterfully tells a very deep and thorough story that gripped me in its mammoth jaws right from the first chapter. The way he takes real life scenarios, like NAFTA for example, and makes it a believable part of his fictional story, is nothing short of genius. This is like Breaking Bad, but broader and with a variety of drugs. Despite being undoubtedly one of the very best books I have read this year, if I had to be critical, the only real downside I could give to the book is that the characters are not deep. Some are better fleshed out than others, but certain characters I would have liked to have seen expanded upon a little further. Winslow doesn’t always take a lot of time to let us get into the characters intricacies and deeper passions, and usually this would be a bigger issue with me and a book, but with the amount of superb storytelling on all other fronts of this book, I can actually look past this here. There might have been a few small lulls in the proceedings and action of the story, but never was I not on the edge of my seat during the books 542 pages.I’m really surprised that I had never heard of this book until last week. With how good this book is, I would expect it to be on the lips and tongues of many people who enjoy crime books. Perhaps I just wasn’t looking in the right places? I actually stumbled upon it by accident while searching for the new book to read. While looking around at books recently at Barnes and Noble, I saw a cover that caught my eye to a book entitled THE CARTEL. After reading the synopsis, I really wanted to read it and only then did I hear about THE POWER OF THE DOG, as it is the predecessor to THE CARTEL, so I bought it and boy am I ever glad I did. I can’t stop here, now I MUST read THE CARTEL!If you like exceptionally dense books that weave a fictional story through real, true life happenings in our world, a story so expertly written and captivating that you’ll wonder how the author could concoct such novel, then definitely check this out. I easily give this book my highest recommendation and a 5/5!

There's something to be said about an author who takes the time to research their topic to such an extent that they are able to create a story that completely inhabits the world they researched. In the case of author Don Winslow, he's studied the intricacies of the drug trade on the Mexican border for over 20 years. Winslow has recently taken to Twitter as a vocal critic to President Trump's border control policies. Whatever your political persuasions, there is no denying that Winslow writes and speaks from a place of well-earned understanding and expertise. He may just write fiction, but he's lived in the worlds he writes about, studied the complex social and economic factors behind that world, and written some killer fiction in the process. The Power of the Dog is nothing short of a masterwork. Attempting to summarize the plot or characters would be an injustice to the narrative that Winslow has worked so diligently to present. Imagine the best elements of a police procedural wrapped up with the crime elements of Sicario or Narcos, and throw in a touch of The Godfather or The Sopranos for good measure. That is just barely scratching the surface of the scope of this novel. Despite the multiple decades covered, crimes committed, and the sheer amount of character lines running through the novel, it never feels confusing or overstuffed. The story flows effortlessly off the page, a true testament to Winslow's ability to present such an intricate world. At the heart of the novel lies Art Keller, a DEA agent who has worked the Mexico cartels for years. He is motivated to bring down the notorious cartel run by Adan Barrera. Interspersed amongst this main plot are the stories of a young prostitute, a priest, a Mexican cop, and some Irish mobsters. Each character is impacted either directly or indirectly by the drug culture or the fight against it. From the mid-1970s to the early 2000s, we see these characters advance through time and experiences that have inevitable physical, monetary, and emotional ramifications. It truly is an in-depth portrait of the cause and effect of the "War on Drugs."For all the large set pieces and action, and Winslow spares no detail in his graphic and striking actions scenes, The Power of the Dog is ultimately an intimate character study and a conclusive referendum on the inner workings of both the drug trade and the fight to stop it. It is a true testament to Winslow's authorial prowess that the novel manages to cover such a large period of time and characters while still being the kind of thriller that you can't stop reading. Moreso, the depth of Winslow's research brings an authenticity that grounds this novel in a reality that is undeniable. Several times I had to remind myself that I was reading a work of fiction. The Power of the Dog is the first in a trilogy that includes The Cartel and this year's The Border. It reads as a complete work, but I can't wait to see where these characters go next.

It took me a while to get into this one. The start is a bit rocky with a slow pace and a plot I wasn't sure I was going to fully commit to but the rocky gave way to the roll and this wound up being a really strong, solid book that I enjoyed. The best thing about this book is it's characters and their various moralities. You have the protagonist who essentially leaves his family behind to feed his obsession for justice and the way that sense of what is just and what isn't evolves as he falls deeper and deeper into his own mania. You have the antagonist who rides a fast and easy slope into money and power but unlike the man who chases him, his family is everything to him--as is love. He's the perfect contrast and the way these two men switch being the light and the dark, each informing the sense of justice and faith of the other is intricate and engaging.Then you have the cast of supporting characters. The humble priest, the reluctant gunman and the shrewd whore. Part of what makes this book rocky at it's beginning is the distance between these characters. They live in different corners of the world. They have wildly different experiences. But each of their worlds eventually collide and revolve around each other and the two main characters as they all devolve into chaos. The plot takes place over many years and it can be a bit jerky and disjointed at times. The transitions aren't always smooth and it takes some time to adjust. The pace at times is very slow but for the most part, it moves on at, if not a fast pace, at least a very steady one. There are places where it's easy to put this book down, but there are more places where you feel compelled to just read one more page, then another and another. It's an intense book. There isn't much in the way of levity or laughs and while it's not supposed to be funny by any means, what it is supposed to be is real. And real life, even life in dark places, in dark times with terrible people, there is levity and I felt this book could have used a few, well-placed, attempts at contrasting the onslaught of darkness. Sometimes, the way to emphasize the darkness is to show some light, it gives the grittiness depth.All in all, this is an easy one to recommend. It's really good. Don't let the beginning of it deter you. It's worth the set up when you get to the good stuff. 3.75 to 4 stars.

Fünf Sterne sind zu wenig! Wenn dieses Buch nur 5 Sterne bekommt, kann ich keinem danach gelesenen Buch mehr die volle Punktzahl geben. Um es kurz zu sagen: Für mich das beste Buch der letzten 2 Jahre!!Hammermäßige Geschichte mit zahlreichen Handlungssträngen und fantastisch beschriebenen Charakteren. Im Mittelpunkt des in der Druckausgabe knapp 700 Seiten starken Buches steht der US-Drogenfahnder Art Keller, der es sich zur Lebensaufgabe gemacht hat, einen Teil der mexikanischen Drogenmafia von innen heraus zu zersprengen. In diesem Roman beschreibt Winslow schonungslos die grausamen Methoden der Drogenkartelle und ihre Verstrickung in die Regierung der USA."Aus" diesem Roman fließt so viel Blut, dass es jedem den Atem verschlägt. Bereits die ersten Seiten fesseln ungemein und man kann nicht mehr zu lesen aufhören. Der Schreibstil von Don Winslow ist vergleichbar mit einem 100 Meter-Lauf. Man rast durch die Kapitel und muss anschließend öfters innehalten und Luft holen! Trotz aller Brutalität lebt dieses Buch auch von seinen hervorragend ausgearbeiteten Charakteren und den mit diesen Personen verbundenen Handlungssträngen, die auf unglaubliche Art und Weise irgendwie alle zusammen laufen. Ich habe mich beim Lesen immer wieder gefragt, wie Winslow sich solch eine handlungsintensive Geschichte ausdenken konnte und dabei trotzdem nicht unglaubwürdig wurde oder den Faden verlor. Jeder einzelne Handlungsstrang - und davon gibt es viele - führt letztlich zu einem großen Ganzen und gerade das macht am Ende den überwältigenden Gesamteindruck des Buches aus. Winslow beleuchtet jede Facette des weltweiten Drogenproblems. Vom kleinen Straßendealer, Mittelsmann, Großdealer über Ämter, Behörden, Wirtschaftsbosse, Regierung, Polizei und Militär beschreibt er detailliert und zu keiner Zeit unglaubwürdig wer wie und warum darin verstrickt ist. Art Keller hat gegen eine massive Gegenwehr von allen Seiten zu kämpfen um seinen Job zu erledigen und um vor allen sein Leben nicht zu verlieren.Tage der Toten - Der Titel ist zugleich Programm...Auf dem Buchcover steht "Hart. Brutal. Real. Einer der besten Thriller aller Zeiten". Dieser Aussage habe ich nichts mehr hinzuzufügen!! Absolute Leseempfehlung für hartgesottene Thrillerfans. Sabandi von MexxBooks

RATING: 4.25PROTAGONIST: Mexican drug family, DEA agent, prostitute, rebel priest and a hit manSETTING: Mexico and CaliforniaTHE POWER OF THE DOG is an astonishing work from the acclaimed author of the Neil Carey Series. Don Winslow has written a book of epic scope that deals with the drug trade in Mexico over a 30-year period.The cast of characters includes a Mexican family whose father establishes a drug operation and is later succeeded by his two sons; a prostitute; a rebel priest; a US DEA agent and a hit man. Starting in the early 70s, we see the Barrera family build a drug cartel that ultimately leads to their being the drug lords of Mexico. Starting as a local operation growing its own poppy plants, the Barreras eventually discover that there is more money to be had if they move cocaine from Colombia. Such power does not come without notice, and over the decades there are various operations and plots that attempt to knock them down. Along the way, there's conflict between the Latin American drug cartels, the US government and the Mob. Over the course of three decades, we follow the lead characters, all of whom are fully developed and emotionally complex. At different times, they all touch one another; at different times, good triumphs over evil or evil conquers good. There are no easy answers in the book. Winslow deals convincingly with the themes of power, love and corruption on a broad scale. My only gripe with the book is that the main characters are Teflon proof: they emerge from every battle relatively unscathed. This happened repeatedly throughout the book, which damaged its plausibility for me.THE POWER OF THE DOG was very good and likely to be touted as Winslow's masterpiece, but I prefer his standalones, such as THE DEATH AND LIFE OF BOBBY Z. That being said, the book is an amazing accomplishment with a complex narrative that is wide-ranging and fast-moving. It reminded me a bit of James Ellroy, but with more accessible writing. Winslow excels at presenting the narrative through multiple points of view in a wide variety of settings. The interconnections between the characters are always shifting. It's a long book, but well worth the time it takes to read it.

1973: cựu nhân viên CIA Art Keller được cơ quan chống ma túy DEA gửi đến một tỉnh của Mexico để hoạt động. Vào lúc ban đầu, ông không có nhiều việc làm vì bị cảnh sát Mexico và chính những đồng nghiệp của ông ngăn cản. Điều này chỉ thay đổi hai năm sau đó, khi Keller kết bạn với Adán Barrera, cháu của một sĩ quan cảnh sát Mexico, người là nhân vật quan trọng nhất trong tỉnh: Miguel Ángel Barrera. Keller được kết nạp vào "gia đình" và từ đó được "ông cậu" bảo trợ. Họ liên kết với nhau trong cuộc chiến chống những người nông dân trồng thuốc phiện và đập tan toàn bộ tổ chức mua bán thuốc phiện của Don Pedro Áviles. Nhưng Art Keller nhận ra quá muộn, rằng Barrera chỉ lật đổ những kẻ nắm quyền cũ để tự đưa mình lên thống lĩnh một liên minh kiểm soát toàn bộ việc buôn ma túy dọc theo biên giới Mexico-Mỹ. Những người là bạn trước đó đã trở thành những kẻ thù không đội trời chung, tiến hành một cuộc chiến tranh không khoan nhượng qua nhiều thập niên liền mà trong đó chỉ có người thua chứ không có kẻ thắng. Don Winslow đã cần hơn năm năm trời để viết quyển sách này, khởi điểm từ một bài báo viết về một vụ thảm sát trong giới buôn ma túy ở Mexico mà trong đó có mười chín người vô tội bị hành hình. Winslow trả lời cho câu hỏi tại sao với một quyển tiểu thuyết về một chương sử hết sức tối tăm của nền dân chủ Mỹ. Chuyện diễn tiến trong một khoảng thời gian là ba mươi năm, và dựa trên số phận của từng nhân vật một, Winslow đã phác hoạt nên một bức tranh toàn cảnh đẫm máu của cuộc "chiến tranh thuốc phiện" do Tổng thống Nixon tuyên bố mà cho tới ngày nay vẫn còn chưa kết thúc. Bên cạnh nhân vật chính Keller, Winslow đã tạo thêm nhiều nhân vật khác, tất cả có chiều sâu và mang nhiều tính thuyết phục, và để cho họ phản ứng tương tác với nhau. Tôi rất thích the Power of the Dog, một quyển thuyết thuyết với bối cảnh mang rất nhiều tính hiện thực, được tác giả dày công điều tra để dựng lên. Quyển tiểu thuyết không những rất căng thẳng lôi cuốn, mà qua đó còn mang lại cho người đọc một ít hiểu biết về nước Mỹ, về tình hình Nam Trung Mỹ, về cuộc chiến tranh chống ma túy trong ba mươi năm cuối cùng của thế kỷ vừa rồi.Tác phẩm đã nhận Giải thưởng Văn học Hình sự Đức năm 2011.

An epical story of the drug "industry" especially focusing on Mexico and the drug cartels from the 1975 through 2004. While I was familiar with nearly all of the basic events portrayed in the novel, reading it all at once brought home not just the ugliness of the story but the depth of corruption, violence, and pure evil associated with drugs and the people profiting from the drug industry. The failure of the War of Drugs was also quite apparent. Which raises the question as to what we should be doing? Is liberalizing drugs the answer? I think not. Here is a summary from the novel:"The War on Drugs. I've fought it my whole goddamn life, and for what? Billions of dollars, trying unsuccessfully to keep drugs out of the world's most porous boarder? One-tenth of the anti-drug budget going into education and treatment, nine-tenths of those billions going to interdiction? And not enough money from anywhere going into the root causes of the drug problem itself. And the billions spent keeping drug offenders locked up in prison, the cells now so crowded we have to give early release to murderers. Not to mention the fact that two-thirds of all the "non-drug" offenses in America are committed by people high on dope or alcohol. And our solutions are the same futile non-solutions - build more prisons, higher more police, spend more and more billions of dollars not curing the symptoms while we ignore the disease. Most people in my area who want to kick drugs can't afford to get into a treatment program unless they have blue-chip health insurance, which most of them don't. We're spending almost $2 billion poisoning cocaine crops and kids over here [Colombia], while there's no money at home to help someone who wants to get off drugs. It's insanity. Art can't decide whether the War on Drugs is an obscene absurdity or an absurd obscenity. In either case, it's a tragic bloody farce."I certainly could not say it any better than Winslow. It seems that we almost should try anything different as it certainly couldn't be worse than our current strategies.

Given that I have only a finite period of time in this mortal coil, I could not bring myself to finish this book. The Power of the Dog is not a bad book by any stretch of the imagination. Winslow has an ability to sketch out very cinematic set pieces. And his writing does not commit any major crimes against the English language (the low bar that I set for popular fiction). But Winslow's characters are one dimensional and colorless. Even worse, Winslow tries really hard to turn his characters into charismatic badasses...and fails miserably. For the protagonist Art, Winslow writes every sentence as if the character is auditioning for some campy nineties action flick. He often says such obvious and clichéd shit like "This wasn’t an arrest...it was an execution." Winslow also shamelessly abuses paragraph breaks in a vain attempt to make Art sound cooler, and ends up making him sound melodramatic and corny. For instance, when comparing Art's obsession with Tío to alcoholism, Winslow writes,I'm like an alcoholic, Art thinks. He’s heard reformed drunks talk about how they would drive to the liquor store, all the time swearing they weren’t going to go, then go in swearing they weren’t going to buy, then buy swearing they weren’t going to drink the booze they’d just bought. Then they’d drink it.I’m that guy, Art thinks, drawn toward Tío like a drunk to the bottle.Everything wrong with Winslow's writing can be seen in these few paragraphs. Note the gauche one-sentence paragraphs that give undue emphasis to lame quips; note how, despite already establishing that Art is like an alcoholic, Winslow feels compelled to repeat, in yet another clipped paragraph, that Art seeks Tío like a drunkard seeks alcohol.

Winslow is probably best known for "Savages," his spare and brutal thriller about the California drug trade. This book is its opposite, a sprawling, ambitious and impassioned novel about the War on Drugs and its abundant corruption and hypocrisies. It ranges from the 1970s to the 1990s and follows the criss-crossing paths of five main characters and a score or more of supporting players, but in the main it concerns the 20-year war between an obsessed DEA agent and two drug kingpin brothers, and Winslow's abundant research is obvious as he shows how the drug growers and smugglers work and how law enforcement tries (or sometimes tries not to) catch them. In places "The Power of the Dog" reminded me of James Ellroy and the way Ellroy uses particular characters to dramatize points he wants to make about America's delusions about its own history -- but without Ellroy's sometimes annoying writer's tics of alliteration for its own sake and rat-a-tat phrasing. It does have some weaknesses. The five main characters are pretty close to walking cliches: the lawman willing to bend the rules, the villian with a humanizing love for his family, the hooker with the heart of gold, the hitman yearning to get out, the priest who helps bolster others' faith as he doubts his own. Worse, one of the lower-level bad guys is into so much stuff -- he's in the CIA, the Mafia and at least two other organizations -- that he seems more of a plot convenience than an actual character. That said, I was compelled to keep reading, fascinated by the twists and turns of the unpredictable plot and by the power of Winslow's compelling vision of how often American diplomacy and South American drug-running have made a devil's bargain, to the detriment of all.

Credo che un libro come questo debba essere letto più volte. Innanzitutto, ha bisogno di essere letto con molta cura, in quanto ogni più piccolo particolare è fondamentale per capire a pieno il significato delle intricate relazioni che si snodano per tutto il libro. Leggendolo più di una volta si avrebbe una maggiore destrezza nell'affrontare temi (che a me sono apparsi) delicati e allo stesso tempo complessi come ad esempio quello politico o quello dello spaccio di droga che fanno da sfondo allo svolgimento della trama, ma anche dei singoli rapporti che intercorrono tra i personaggi.In secondo luogo, sarebbe importante rileggerlo facendo passare del tempo (magari anni) dalla prima lettura, perché credo che questo sia un libro che cresce di valore con l'aumentare dell'età. È fondamentale l'esperienza di vita al fine di valutarlo al meglio. Lo stile inconfondibile di Winslow rende il tutto vivo, credibile: è capace di catapultarti all'interno della scena, in mezzo a proiettili vaganti o sangue che sgorga. Attraverso la focalizzazione su personaggi diversi, apporta alla visione complessiva differenti quanto fondamentali punti di vista, lasciando però al lettore la libertà di prendere le sue parti, perché alla base vi è una spiegazione dettagliata ed esauriente del background in cui si svolge l'azione. Se vi sembra che la spiegazione non sia esauriente, non preoccupatevi, al prossimo colpo di scena tutto vi sarà di nuovo chiaro, benché abbiate letto con la dovuta attenzione. Tirando le somme, handle with care: dipende dall'attenzione con cui vi dedicherete alla lettura di questo libro, se questo vi piacerà o meno.

Ironically enough, I had read the sequel - The Cartel - before I got my hands on this one (and for those who are wondering whether the reverse chronology affects reading pleasure, well, it doesn't). I had my apprehensions starting out - The Cartel was a spectacular, five-star blockbuster; could the prequel live up to those first impressions I had developed about Don Winslow? Boy, it did, and how! Put in a larger context, the Power of the Dog is a relentlessly brutal and belligerent fictional account of America’s war on drugs. The central narrative is conceived around a cast of graphically developed characters - comprising DEA agents, drug-lords, mercenaries, hit-men, call-girls and priests - whose fates are irrevocably intertwined with that of one American agent's (Art Keller) obsessive-compulsive pursuit to put behind bars the kingpin of Mexican drug cartel (Adan Barrera). Played out over nearly four decades, the book motors along with incredible and graphic details of vicious savagery of drug cartel operations and the expeditious and vile nature of the political response against (and sometimes, in favour of) them. In my mind, the true achievement of Don Winslow, here, is not just in how vividly he portrays an engaging story on a relevant and persistent subject of the present era; rather, it is also, and particularly, in his ability to provoke the duality of every actor we encounter along the way and to question the very ethics of the response against organised crime. For lovers of organised crime and action thrillers, The Power of the Dog, along with its sequel, is thus an unmissable epic!

Todos son grises, todos tienen algo escondido, y son capaces de hacer lo que sea con tal de lograr su objetivo. La novela te plantea dilemas morales, juega contigo y te hace participe de las decisiones que ellos toman. Además, la evolución de esos personajes es extraordinaria. Veremos como quedarán marcados por sus actos, como sufren y ríen. Como matan y viven.📚Es uno de los mejores libros que he leído en la vida. Lo tiene todo: narcotráfico, mafia, poder político, corrupción, novela negra, amor, prostitución, etc. Y encima es adictivo. Es un libro que recomiendo al 100%. Te va a impactar muchísimo, y como dije, es tan cinematográfico, que será la mejor serie que verás/leerás en tu vida.

This book is amazing. If you are a fan of Narcos and/or Narcos: Mexico, you should try it.It's the first in a fiction trilogy about the drug wars in Mexico. You see the war through the viewpoints of an American DEA agent, a Mexican drug lord, an Irish hit man, and a high-class American call girl. All four are complex characters and while they may do things you don't like as a reader and human being (these things are pretty bad so I hope you won't like them!), the author is able to elicit sympathy for each character. They may do horrible things, but you care for at least a part of them despite that. At least, I did. I also appreciated that Don Winslow is skilled enough to create that emotional connection without dumbing anything down. None of that, oh he's a villain because he has a sad background. No, it's all about life choices and values. It's an adult view of life.As for the history, this novel is fiction, but knowledgeable readers will recognize the real-life events and persons who inspired the action. This author did his research.This book is episodic. It starts in the mid-70s and follows the characters through to the 90s. Nothing is untouched from assassinations to aid to the Sandinistas to drug involvement with FARC, etc. It's also fast-paced. The last fourth of the book is a particular thrill ride.There is violence and some of it is uncomfortable, but it is brief and not exploitative. The violence serves a story-telling purpose. I had to take breaks at times due to the tension of what may happen next, not because of the violence.Highly recommended!

This is an absolutely masterful narrative that spans decades and continents in telling the story of America's War on Drugs and its ripple effects in Latin America. Winslow creates a variety of fascinating characters, each with their own backstories and complex sets of values and motivations, and does a great job of explaining how the narcotrafficker cartels of Latin America developed and evolved, at times with the unwitting (or, at times witting) assistance of the U.S. government, depending on its policy priorities at a given time. This book is obviously very well-researched, and Winslow does a nice job of keeping the different narrative arcs moving at the same time and bringing them together, often in unexpected, surprising or explosive ways. One quick word of advice: if graphic depictions of violence make you uncomfortable, this is NOT the book for you. This is an extremely violent book, and characters are often tortured and/or killed in stomach-wrenching ways. This book features one of the most horrifying scenes I've ever seen, from the development of the scheme to its grisly execution. Winslow really pulls no punches in depicting the sheer brutality of how the cartels handle their business, and if you'd prefer not to read the full details, I would not recommend this book for you. Overall, I highly recommend this book for anyone with an interest in the history of US-Latin American relations in the late 20th century and the rise of the drug trade on a massive, industrial scale, and I can't wait to read the sequel, "The Cartel."

Unfortunately, like the lamest fan ever, my main issue with this book is that it isn't as good as "The Cartel" (and how could it be? It was written first!). I found this book quite confusing--I had trouble keeping track of who was who, especially all the Irish and Italian gangsters (why did they have to go by like three different names that were used interchangeably? :(). Ultimately I think Winslow excels most when he is writing from a very moral place--about something he is clearly EXTREMELY passionate about, like the plight of journalists in "The Cartel." In this book, I didn't find the Irish hitman, blonde escort, and the (sadly underdeveloped and under-used) liberal priest as compelling or gripping as the child sicario, blackmailed journalist, and female police officer in "The Cartel." I also don't think Adán (the main narco guy, who clearly becomes El Chapo in book two) is as fully developed as he later becomes. But I suppose that's what's good about writing--you grow into it and hit your stride. The most interesting parts of this book for me were the scenes that traced the history of the War of the Drugs in America, and that in itself makes this worth reading. Interestingly enough, this book was recommended by Sergio González Rodríguez (Mexican journalist who Bolaño wrote in as a character in "2666") as essential reading for understanding the contemporary situation in Mexico.

This train carries saints and sinners,This train carries losers and winners,This train carries whores and gamblers,This train carries lost souls.This train. Dreams will not be thwartedQuasi 30 anni di lotta alla droga, se la guardi dalla parte della legge.Quasi 30 anni di lotta alla legge, se la guardi dalla parte dei cartelli della droga.... e anche da una parte della leggesoldi, droga, politica.... si intrecciano e si spalleggiano a vicenda.E alcune pagine sono un pugno diritto allo stomaco, anzi una raffica di pugni. E devi sollevare gli occhi dal libro perchè non ce la fai a continuare.E pensi che dai, tanto è un romanzo, è tutto inventato... ma in realtà lo sai che è successo davvero, succede e probabilmente succederà ancora, mentre tutti giriamo lo sguardo come io lo sollevavo dalle pagine.I personaggi non sono nè tutti buoni nè tutti cattivi.Chi fa della lotta alla droga la sua missione nella vita provoca anche tanto male, perfino alle persone che gli stanno vicino, e viene comunque usato dalla politica e dal potere.Chi fa della droga e del crimine la propria missione nella vita, a volte lo fa per caso, altre volte perchè è il mestiere di famiglia, e viene comunque usato dalla politica e dal potere.Nessun buonoNessun cattivoSolo tante vittime700 pagine da leggere assolutamente, sapendo cosa vi aspetta

"The Power of the Dog" starts in 1975 and follows the DEA's involvement with the War on Drugs and various aspects of Operation Condor. It took the author over 6 years of writing and research before its publication. In every aspects it is evident the tremendous effort he has invested into his version of events and has provided us with a fast paced page turner that is impossible to put down.Set on the US/Mexican border, we witness mainly through the eyes of Art Keller the beginning of his operative work with the CIA on Operation Condor and through the next 29 years as he attempts to do his job while not becoming a victim.I was easily sucked into the whirlpool of characters in all shades of black and grey, into the corrupt agencies and the government underhand encouragement, actively financing the development of the drug cartel. This story is a tapestry of violence and depicts actual events some may remember, we are not spared the true ugliness of war, the word excruciating may be apropos during some sections. This is a dense novel, rather pessimistic but in no way does it drag. The prose is energetic, intelligent and has the right rhythm for the subject as the sprawling saga shifts points of view.This story may not be for everyone it is nevertheless a captivating read I would recommend

In one way, "The Power of the Dog" is nothing new. It is a novel about friends who become enemies. It is an epic novel that starts with a horrific scene with a dead mother and a dead Baby and then tells the Story about all that happened before that. But it's the way Don Winslow tells it, his language, often using present tense which creates the narratives pace and nervousness, that takes me a few dozen pages in and then turns this book into a pageturner. Winslow is even telling us the Story of a failed state. Mexico is corrupt and the Connection between the narcos and the government is clear. Different cartels use different police units who are deeply corrupt. But it is not an idea to just "build a wall to Mexico and make the Mexicans pay for it" as a candidate for the US presidency has put it.The US with ist different wars on drugs and on communism and on terrorism has no conscience either. Some of their representatives ranking highly up, support and train the death squadrons of El Salvador, Nicaragua and otber Central Americans. There's a lot of blood on everyone's hands in this gripping stories of betrayal, hate and there is even a love Story that spans over years between a man who has killed dozens and a woman who has sold herself to hundreds of men before she finds her guy.

First off, I loved the style of the writing in The Power of the Dog. It's direct and economical in it's style. In fact, at times I really liked it - at first, however, I hated it. The prologue was good but then the next twenty pages felt painfully like an info dump. I felt that they could have removed most or all of this section without damaging the novel.And after that it got great as we are introduced to Callan and O Bop and Peaches. And from there, Art and the Barrera's felt more real too. I was really loving the book here. And I think overall I loved most of it...But it was too long!For me the length of the book meant that the style that I admired at first, ended up working against it. In a book of that length I needed a bit more meat on the bones of the characters.The ending of the book was great but was so quick after the long build up that I didn't get the full climactic hit I was craving.Overall Winslow does lots of things brilliantly. His dialogue, his ability to focus on skillfully chosen detail, his knowledge and research. And I might well read another of his, but I would probably choose something shorter.

This is a very good book, although I debated giving it 5* - though it's certainly 4.5*. Many pages, many years, many characters, many locations... and yet Winslow seems to keep it moving along with a writing style which is often sparse, abrasive and immediate, and sometimes quite lyrical: "Gone also is the life we led. Gone in poison and flame. Our old lives are like the fragile dreams we dream in the waking hours, floating away from us like a wisp of smoke in the wind. We might like to call the dream back, to go on sweetly sleeping, but that is not life, that is a dream." It's been 40+ years since I read Puzo's The Godfather, but like others, I can see the parallels. The story is interleaved with the awful history of American drug wars from the 70's to the naughties, and I am assuming that even the more implausible government and authority interventions are based on fact. Albeit somewhat clichéd, I was absorbed by the characters. I think Winslow loses half a star because the principals' interactions too often depend on convenient coincidences. Recommended. (There are two more books in the series - I can't imagine there is any narrative left! I will find out soon enough...)

The Power of the Dog spans three decades, a handful of government agencies and several borders to give you powerful insight into the Mexican drug Federación and War on Drugs. Although the book is fiction the narrative is fact-based, therefore gripping and all-consuming. Any American who has followed politics and the news the past 30 years will find this book evocative.The Power of the Dog’s plot is complex and the characters equally elaborate, a testament to Winslow’s years of research enabling him to compose this narcos-charged masterpiece. This story is not for the faint of heart. It’s appalling, graphic, violent and spares no detail. But that’s how the Federación operates. Pay close attention because the cast is extensive and their betrayal unrestrained.I listened to the audiobook version narrated by Ray Porter. His narration is brilliant – the pronunciation, intonation, inflection, and delivery were on the money. I highly recommend giving this one a listen if you can stomach the details and keep the characters straight. Winslow is releasing the third book, currently untitled, in 2018 and I will be reading it!

OMG AWESOME!!!! I know there are three months left in this year, but this might be my favorite book of 2020. The audiobook was twenty hours of non-stop dark, gritty, suspense-filled action. The narrator did an excellent job because not once was I ever bored. I had to force myself to stop listening. I guess this story resonates with me so much because I was in elementary school in the 80s, and you could not turn on the evening news without hearing about the wars in Central America. Then as I got older I was fascinated by what really went down with Iran-Contra and how it lead to the crack epidemic. Mr. Winslow takes you there and then some. When I got to the last hour of the book I was actually kind of sad. I wanted to hurry up and see how the story ended, but I had become so invested in the characters I wasn't ready for it to be over. Crazy, right? I do have to warn readers that this story is not for the timid. The violence towards men, women, and children is rough. But I can tell you that the violence is an integral part of the story. Any attempt to tell this story without it, would be a betrayal. After all you are reading a book about a cartel.

There is a scene in an old Priyadarshan movie, 'Kilukkam', where an old judge is reading 'The Godfather' in his bed and he imagines the gunfire and the car chases and jumps out of his skin when the heroine comes into the room . Books , especially crime thrillers if well written have the power to do just that.I Have always loved crime fiction , Mario Puzo, Stieg Larsson, P. D. James, Michael Connelly, John le Carré and even Fyodor dostoevsky. They are my guilty pleasure. I have been meaning to read Don Winslow's Power of the Dog Series for some time now but other books kept vying my attention. I then decided to give into the guilty pleasure as it's Christmas time."The power of the Dog' is a heady read. This book takes you deep inside the Mexican drug trade. Beginning from 1975 and ending in 2004 this novel takes us on a Machiavellian tour de force of the drug wars between the Mexican drug cartel and US DEA. If you have loved the TV series 'The Wire' and 'Sopranos' this is a novel not to be missed . I finished the novel in a 400 page reading frenzy last night, I can't remember the last time I did that. Dense , gritty and unflinching. Brilliant novel.

The hardest thing in the world isn't to refrain from committing an evil, it's to stand up and stop one.The Power of the Dog explores the truth of this assertion. Art Keller, one of the main characters, devotes his entire career, and life, to standing up and stopping an evil: the drug cartel that took his colleague's life. Is it worth it? Is the cost of stranding up to this evil too high?This book, like a few other Don Winslow novels, fleshes out the farcical yet devastating nature of the so-called War on Drugs. Farcical in that the U.S. Government engages in doublespeak worthy of Big Brother himself. Devastating in the atrocities committed and perpetuated by the War on Drugs.There were flashes of brilliance in this novel followed by an overwhelming amount of violence. At times it read like a bloody action movie, people killing and dying right and left. The Power of the Dog is ten times more violent than Savages or The Kings of Cool, but it works. I couldn't put it down.Don Winslow's brilliance is his ability to pack so much meaning into five little words: the power of the dog.

Devastating. Enormous story telling. Don's Winslow really did a great job writing this story. I'm not an American, nor Mexican. But this book really dragged me as if I were living there. Feeling their pain and agony who lives their lives through the cruelty in the cartel world. Mafia. Organized crime that raging in America and the Gulf region. Arm trafficking, prostitution, narcotics, conspiracy, spy. All of those were written into one story with full graphic of violence. Even though there are no picture, the graphic description in this book are so detailed. Its violence, torture, and all the gore thing are so real. Remind me of the chopped-off-horse-head in the Godfather movie, Tortuga's chopped-off-head on top of tortuga's (turtle) shell in Breaking Bad, and 'what's in the box?' line in the se7en movie. And there are other... It gave you cringe. Reading this book, was like watching a movie. Which maybe (in my opinion) on par with Godfather, or maybe even more amazing. This is a 'must-read' book. Sadly, Goodreads didn't allow me to rate this masterpiece more than 5 stars. It should be deserve more than that.

This is normally not my type of story, or rather, not my type of book. Usually I love to read all kinds of stuff, but thrillers don't really fall into these "all kinds"-categories. I do love to watch crime and thriller on TV, though, which is probably why I bought this book in the first place.It took me some time to get into the story (as I've never read anything even remotely similar to this book, with its war on drugs), but it turned out to be a thrilling and amazing read. I really like Don Winslow's style - it's simple, but it fits the characters perfectly - and they are all very human, and thus very believable.It is not an easy read, because the story can become pretty hard to stomach, and certain events described (in very human, or sometimes inhuman cases) can leave a very bitter taste in your mouth (or might make your stomach churn), but I did still enjoy it very much (I've thankfully built a pretty strong stomach by being exposed to bloody incidents and the like through film or TV series).
